questions.text: 1. Identify the manoeuvre shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver, used for the delivery of extended arms in breech presentation.

The principle of this maneuver is based on the curved birth canal. The shoulder placement favorable for this maneuver is:

* anterior shoulder - above the symphysis pubis

* posterior shoulder - below the sacral promontory.

Rotating the trunk while keeping the back anterior and applying downward traction brings the posterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

The technique followed in Lovset's maneuver is 

* The baby is grasped with both hands using a femoropelvic grip, keeping the thumbs parallel to the vertebral column. The maneuver should start only when the inferior angle of the anterior scapula is visible underneath the pubic arch.

* The baby is lifted slightly to cause lateral flexion. The trunk is rotated 180°, keeping the back anterior and maintaining downward traction.

* The trunk is then rotated in the reverse direction, keeping the back anterior, to deliver the former anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

Lovset's maneuver can be employed in all types of arm displacement. It does not involve any intrauterine manipulation. These factors make it a preferred maneuver.

Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

* Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction



 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 



 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

* Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.

* When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.

* Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.



 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

* Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.

* Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.

* Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.

* Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.

* Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.



 

Mnemonic:

* Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)

* Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: 2. A 45-year-old man with abnormal gait and hearing problems presents with a cerebellopontine mass. Histopathological examination demonstrates Antony A and Antony B areas with Verocay bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological examination of a cerebellopontine mass showing Antony A and Antony B areas with Verocay bodies points to a diagnosis of Schwannoma.

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. They are commonly associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A and loose areas called Antoni B.

* The Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with nuclear-free zones between them, forming structures called Verocay bodies.

* The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The image below shows cellular Antoni A and paucicellular Antoni B areas in schwannoma:



The image below shows verocay bodies in the Antoni-A area of vestibular schwannoma.



Other tumors arising at the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) are:

* Meningioma (the 2nd most common tumor at CPA)

* Cholesteatoma

* Arachnoid cysts

* Glomus tumor

* Metastases

Other options:

Option B: Glioblastoma shows necrotic foci surrounded by pseudopalisading malignant nuclei along with prominent endothelial proliferation.

Option C: Oligodendroglioma shows the classic “fried‑egg” appearance with round nuclei surrounded by clear perinuclear halos and a delicate “chicken‑wire” capillary network.

Option D: Medulloblastoma shows sheets of small-round, blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, frequently forming Homer‑Wright rosettes.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.



Pearl PM1740: Pathological Named Bodies

questions.text: 3. Regarding different grades of binocular single vision. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Figure 1 describes simultaneous macular perception and figure 2 describes fusion
Figure 1 describes fusion and figure 2 describes simultaneous macular perception
Figure 1 describes stereopsis and figure 2 describes simultaneous macular perception
Figure 1 describes simulataneous macular perception and figure 2 describes steropsis

questions.solution:
The image depicts binocular vision. Figure 1 describes simultaneous macular perception, and Figure 2 describes fusion.

When a normal individual fixes their visual attention on an object of regard, the image is formed on the fovea of both eyes separately, but the individual perceives a single image. The visual axes of the two eyes intersect at the point of fixation. The images are aligned by the fusion reflex and combined by binocular responsive cells in the visual cortex. This is known as binocular single vision. It is a conditioned reflex that is not present since birth but is acquired during the initial months and is completed during the first few years of development, called the critical period of visual development. 

It has 3 grades:

* Simultaneous perception

* Fusion

* Stereopsis

Prerequisites for the development of binocular single vision are:

* Motor mechanism- Straight eyes starting from the neonatal period, with precise coordination for all directions of gaze

* Sensory mechanism- Reasonably clear vision in both eyes so that similar images are presented to each retina

* Mental process- Ability of the visual cortex to promote binocular single vision 

The field of binocular single vision can be tested using Goldmann perimetry, a tangent screen, or a Hess chart. It usually measures about 45° to 50° from the fixation point, except on the nasal side. It represents the parts of the visual field of each eye that overlap, and where bifoveal fusion of the objects occurs.



Pearl PM1014: Grades of binocular vision

I - Simultaneous perception                       

* Ability to see two dissimilar objects simultaneously

II - Fusion

* Ability to superimpose two incomplete but similar images

III - Stereopsis

* Ability to perceive depth

questions.text:
4. A 33-year-old man presents with a testicular bulky mass which was homogenous, grey-white and lobulated on the cut surface. It did not show hemorrhage or necrosis. Microscopic H&E image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?

H&E - Hematoxylin and Eosin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the H&E image, points to a diagnosis of Seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT). The peak incidence is in the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The image given below shows the gross cut-section of seminoma.



The H&E image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. This is characteristic of seminoma or seminomatous germ-cell tumor.



Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are the tumor markers that may be raised in a case of seminoma.

Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. The fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.

Other options:

Option B:  Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.  Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds.



Option C: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with a mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years. Schiller–Duval body is shown in the image below.



Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common testicular lymphoma, and the histopathological slide showing large lymphoma cells infiltrating between the seminiferous tubules is given below. Later, the lymphoma cells may infiltrate the seminiferous tubules. Necrosis can be seen commonly.



Pearl PM2277: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Seminoma

* Non-seminomatous GCTs

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type

* Choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma, post-pubertal type

* Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Spermatocytic tumour

* Teratoma, prepubertal type

* Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type

* Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

* Leydig cell tumor

* Sertoli cell tumor

* Granulosa cell tumor

* Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

* Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Pearl PM2279: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor


AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

questions.text: 5. A 45-year-old male presents with a complaint of pruritic rash over the elbows, knees and buttocks. He recently visited the gastroenterology OPD and was found to be sensitive to gluten. Skin biopsy showed IgA immunofluorescence. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of intensely itchy lesions on the extensor aspect of both elbows and knees with direct immunofluorescence (DIF) showing focal granular deposits along the basement membrane is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease is an auto-immune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with Celiac disease (Gluten-sensitive enteropathy). 

The clinical manifestations include grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, and scalp with symmetrical distribution and are associated with intense pruritus. 

The characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils, which is shown in the image below:



A gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment, but it takes months to years to show clinical improvement. Hence, dapsone is used for short-term management in these patients.

Pearl PM0224: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen


 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

* Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris

* Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus

* Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris

* Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus



Pearl PM0363: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

Bullous pemphigoid

* Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis

* Epidermolysis bullosa

* Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma

* Other disorders

* Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS

* Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis

According to Site

Intraepidermal

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris

4. Basal layer

questions.text: 6. A newborn is admitted to the NICU after 24hour with severe respiratory distress. What is the diagnosis from the given xray?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect in the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia, a posterolateral defect which usually involves the left side. 

Other options:

Option A: Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is a group of cystic and non-cystic lung lesions resulting from early airway maldevelopment. They can communicate with the airways and are frequently infected.



Option B: Loculated pneumothorax is a form of pneumothorax where a pocket of pleural air is trapped within a localised area.



Option D: Congenital lobar emphysema is a bronchial abnormality that results in a check valve mechanism causing progressive hyperinflation of the affected lobe.



Pearl PM0028: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

* Mediastinal shift

* Bowel loops in the left hemithorax



 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

* Low lung volume

* Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)

* Air bronchogram

* White-out lung (severe disease)



Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

* Hyperinflation

* Patchy infiltrates

* Coarse streaking



Pearl PM2134: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

* The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

* The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

* respiratory distress at birth

* grunting respiration

* chest retractions

* dyspnea

* cyanosis

* scaphoid abdomen

* decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH

* shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: 7. The hysterectomy specimen of a 65 year old patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this 65-year-old woman’s hysterectomy specimen is endometrial carcinoma.

In elderly, postmenopausal women, an irregular, friable growth filling the endometrial cavity with myometrial invasion strongly suggests endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial cancer may be localised or diffuse. It may appear as a nodule, polyp or diffuse lesion involving the entire uterine cavity. The risk factors include PCOS, HRT, obesity, hypertension and diabetes. 

About 7-10% cases are asymptomatic. Other clinical features include:

* Postmenopausal bleeding/discharge (most common)

* Menorrhagia or irregular periods in perimenopausal women

* Late features include pain and an abdominal lump

* On per vaginal exam, the uterus may be normal or bulky (due to tumour, fibroid, or pyometra)

* An adnexal mass may be present, usually feminizing ovarian tumour or metastasis

* Advanced disease presents as bulky cervix, patulous os, growth protruding through os

* Vaginal or suburethral metastatic nodules can rarely be present

Other options: 

Option A: Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrium in the walls of the uterus. The uterus appears symmetrically enlarged to not more than 14 weeks size. The cut section may show only a localized nodular enlargement. Most of the time, the affected area reveals a peculiar, diffuse, striated and noncapsulated involvement of the myometrium with tiny dark haemorrhagic areas in between. 

The hysterectomy specimen of adenomyosis is shown below:



Option C: Endometriosis refers to endometrium outside the endometrial lining(such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, or peritoneum), which causes chronic pelvic pain, menstrual irregularity and infertility. It does not involve the endometrium itself in hysterectomy specimens.

Option D: Fibroid (leiomyoma) is a benign smooth muscle tumour of the uterus that presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass with a whorled appearance and a pseudocapsule, rather than irregular endometrial masses. An image of gross specimen of fibroid uterus is given below:

Pearl PM1377: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II

  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy

  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction

questions.text: 8. A 55-year post-menopausal woman presents to the OPD for a routine BP checkup. Her BP was 170/100 mm Hg. She also complains of bloodstained discharge per vagina. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Reassure her that some discharge is normal at this age
Immediate pelvic examination, TVS and pap smear
Immediate referral to a cardiologist to control BP

questions.solution:
The next best step of management is immediate pelvic examination, TVS and pap smear. 

A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presenting with blood-stained vaginal discharge should be thoroughly evaluated to rule out endometrial hyperplasia and malignancy of the genital tract. Additionally, her hypertension (BP 170/100 mm Hg) is a recognised risk factor for endometrial carcinoma. Other risk factors include obesity, diabetes, polycystic ovarian syndrome, older age, early age of menarche, late age of menopause, nulliparity, and long-term contraceptive use. 

As part of the evaluation, a pelvic examination is performed, which may reveal any abnormality in the lower genital tract such as an enlarged uterus, abnormal cervix or adnexal mass. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is performed to assess endometrial thickness and detect any endometrial pathology like an endometrial polyp. An endometrial thickness of more than 4 mm indicates the need of endometrial biopsy. A Pap smear is done to screen for cervical abnormalities and exclude cervical cancer.



Other options:

Option A: Reassurance is not appropriate because postmenopausal bleeding is never normal.

Option C: Referral to a cardiologist is also not the immediate step, as her blood pressure, though high, is not an acute emergency in this setting.

Option D: Proceeding directly to hysterectomy without confirming the diagnosis is incorrect. The appropriate next step is to establish the cause of post-menopausal bleeding and exclude malignancy.

questions.text: 9. A 40-year-old female, on administration of a neuromuscular blocker, developed erythema, flushing of face, neck, trunk, and hypotension. Which of the following drugs is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of histamine release. Atracurium is the most potent histamine releaser among the given options and was likely administered.

Based on the chemical structure, non-depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMR) can be classified into two groups: 

* Steroidal compounds: Pancuronium, Vecuronium, Rocuronium

* Benzylisoquinoline compounds: d-Tubocurarine, Atracurium, Cis-atracurium, and Mivacurium

Erythema, flushing, and hypotension are manifestations of histamine release. Histamine release is most likely associated with benzylisoquinoline compounds, except cis-atracurium, as compared to steroidal compounds. Cis-atracurium is a stereoisomer of atracurium and has negligible histamine-releasing potential despite being a benzylisoquinoline compound.

Management includes stopping or slowing the infusion of the NDMR and giving antihistamines. Hypotension can be prevented by giving antihistamines and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Pearl PM0247: Muscle relaxant with histamine release.

Muscle relaxants causing histamine release leading to hypotension, tachycardia, flushing:

Most likely: d-tubocurarine

Likely: 

* Atracurium

* Mivacurium

* Succinyl choline

Least likely:

* Vecuronium

* Cisatracurium

* Rocuronium

* Pancuronium

questions.text: 10. A 32-year-old with gestational diabetes mellitus and fetal macrosomia is in labour, the head is delivered, but the shoulders are stuck even after 1 minute. What is the sequence of manoeuvres?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a delay in delivery of the baby's shoulders for more than 1 minute after delivery of the head indicates shoulder dystocia, and the correct sequence for managing shoulder dystocia is: McRobert’s manoeuvre → Rubin manoeuvre → Gaskin manoeuvre → Zavanelli manoeuvre.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis or on the sacral promontory. The diagnosis is made on the basis of:

* Definite recoil of the head back against the perineum (turtle neck sign)

* Failure of spontaneous restitution of fetal head

* Fetal face becomes plethoric

* Failure of shoulder to descend

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:

*

McRoberts Maneuver: Abduct and sharply flex the maternal thighs onto the abdomen, which straightens the lumbosacral angle, rotates the pelvis, frees the impacted shoulder, and increases the available space (image below). Along with this maneuver, suprapubic pressure is applied, which directs the fetal head posteriorly to reduce the shoulder diameter and rotate it into the oblique plane.



* Rubin’s Maneuver: Rotate the easily accessible fetal shoulder, usually the posterior shoulder, to help release the impacted shoulder (image below).



* Woods Corkscrew Maneuver: Rotate the posterior shoulder 180° in a corkscrew fashion to align it for delivery (image below).



* Extraction of the posterior arm is done with the help of Jacquemier maneuver.

*

Gaskin Maneuver: Place the mother on her hands and knees (all fours position) to increase pelvic dimensions and allow downward traction on the posterior shoulder to free it.

* If other measures fail, the fetus can be pushed back into the uterus for cesarean delivery (Zavanelli manoeuvre), the clavicle can be fractured to reduce shoulder girth (cleidotomy), or, rarely, symphysiotomy may be performed. The images showing Zavanelli manoeuvre and cleidotomy is shown below:

questions.text: 11. A patient underwent surgery for a duodenal ulcer. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally injured a structure posterior to the epiploic foramen, and the patient started bleeding copiously into the peritoneal cavity. Which is the most likely structure injured by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava (IVC) is the most likely structure injured by the surgeon as it is present in the posterior part of the epiploic foramen.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the right free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac.





Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.



Pearl PM1129: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate process of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum


 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: 12. In which of the following structures will the following epithelium be seen?
questions.solution:
The epithelium shown in the above image can be found in the ureter.

The ureter is lined by transitional epithelium (also called urothelium), similar to the urinary bladder. This specialized epithelium allows stretching, which is crucial as the urine passes through. The presence of transitional epithelium is characteristic of structures in the urinary system, such as the ureters, bladder, and part of the urethra. In the relaxed state, the superficial cells appear cuboidal and protrude outward, with occasional binucleate cells observed within this layer.

Given below is a cross-section of the ureter showing the transitional epithelium and the layer of smooth muscle.



Other options:

Option A: Gall bladder: The gall bladder is lined by simple columnar epithelium, which facilitates the absorption of water and electrolytes from bile.



Option B: Trachea: The trachea is lined by pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium with goblet cells, which helps trap and remove particles from the respiratory tract.



Option D: Duodenum: The duodenum is lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells, aiding in digestion and nutrient absorption.

questions.text: 13. A patient presented with the following findings in the left lower limb. Identify the true statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: Sclerotherapy is the treatment of choice for this stage

questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb and suggests stage C2 as per the CEAP classification. The patient will develop eczema/ pigmentation. 

Varicose veins are characterised by the tortuous dilatation of subcutaneous veins resulting from venous insufficiency. Patients have heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, which increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. If the corrective measures are not taken, the varicose veins can progress to develop pigmentation, eczema and even venous ulcers. 

Risk factors (Option D):

* Females>males

* Increasing age

* Increasing body mass and height

* Pregnancy

* Family history

* Occupations involving prolonged periods of standing

Investigations include: 

* Clinical examination

* Venous duplex ultrasound

* Site of reflux

* Size of vein

* Location of perforators

* Presence of obstruction in the deep venous system

* Indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction

* MR venography

* Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management can be done through various methods, and it depends on the surgeon. Many times, the procedures are grouped. (Option B)

* Endovascular procedures

* Endovascular laser ablation

* Radiofrequency ablation

* Ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy

* Catheter-directed sclerotherapy and mechanochemical ablation

* Endovenous glue

* Open surgeries

* Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous vein stripping

* Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous vein stripping

* Non-surgical procedures like Compression stockings

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).



The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers, respectively.





Pearl PM2292: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

C1

C2

to chronic venous disease

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

A

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Anatomic classification (A)

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Po

Pr,o

Pn

Note:

* The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

* Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.

* Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm

* Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text:
14. A 28-year-old female presents with multiple cervical lymphadenopathies. IHC markers were positive for CD10 and BCL-2. Peripheral smear shows a large number of small cells (centrocytes) and occasional large cells (centroblasts). What is the most common genetic defect in this condition?

IHC - Immunohistochemistry
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features, along with the IHC findings, are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) BCL2-IGH translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

Follicular lymphoma results from a chromosomal rearrangement, t(14;18) BCL2-IGH, which is the translocation of the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus (IGH) on chromosome 14, resulting in the overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions (in most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes): 

* Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm

* Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

The following image shows the histopathological findings of follicular lymphoma, along with strong IHC positivity for BCL-2 in the follicular centre B-cells, a feature that is typically present in mantle zone cells.



Other options:

Option B: t(11;18) MALT1 is seen in MALT (Muocsal-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) Lymphoma

Option C: t(2;5) ALK is seen in Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma.

Option D: t(11;14) Cyclin D1-IGH is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: 15. A patient came with complaints of palpitations and dyspnea for 4 hours. On ECG, he was found to have atrial fibrillation with no other cardiovascular symptoms. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Look for left atrial thrombus with carotid doppler

questions.solution:
In the above scenario with atrial fibrillation, the patient is hemodynamically stable (no other cardiovascular symptoms) and hence, the next best step in management is ventricular rate control.

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: the duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke. The patients who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. 

The patient presenting within 48 hours (4 hours in this case) can be managed  by following the following algorithm:



Those who present with an unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This can be done in 2 ways, as shown below:

questions.text:
16. A 48-year-old male presented with an asymptomatic lesion on the right cheek with central atrophy, which had been slowly progressive over the last 2 years. CXR reveals apical calcification. How will you confirm the diagnosis?

CXR: Chest X-Ray

PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction
questions.solution:
PCR is used to confirm the diagnosis.

The above clinical scenario of a slow, progressive, painless plaque over the cheek and side of the neck and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris and chest X-ray showing apical calcification suggests healed pulmonary tuberculosis. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitised individuals, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative. A chest X-ray will help to analyse the pulmonary involvement.

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation, such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, most of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative and hence, culture may be more helpful.  Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

The image given below shows lupus vulgaris in the axilla:



Other options:

Option A: Probe test is generally used to detect bone involvement in osteomyelitis, not in lupus vulgaris. 

Option C: Slit smear is used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae in leprosy, and is usually negative in cutaneous tuberculosis. 

Option D: Mantoux test is often positive in tuberculosis, but cannot confirm active disease, as it may also be positive in healthy exposed individuals.

Pearl PM1971: Classification of cutaneous tuberculosis

The classification of cutaneous tuberculosis is based on the mode of acquisition.

Type Pathophysiology AFB

Exogenous

Through broken skin or mucosa
Tuberculous chancre Occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB Multibacillary
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity Paucibacillary

Endogenous

Direct spread from a focus of infection
Scrofuloderma Contiguous spread from affected parts like lymph nodes, joints Multibacillary
Periorificial tuberculosis Autoinoculation at mucocutaneous borders from infected secretions Multibacillary

Hematogenous

Spread from a distant primary focus of TB
Acute cutaneous miliary tuberculosis Occurs in severe disseminated TB Multibacillary
Lupus vulgaris Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity. Mostly hematogenous spread, sometimes exogenous. Paucibacillary
Tuberculous gumma/ abscess Occurs in immunocompromised patients Multibacillary

Tuberculids

Hypersensitivity reaction
Lichen scrofulosorum (micropapular) Hematogenous spread of M. tuberculosis antigens to the skin causes type III hypersensitivity which triggers type IV reaction with granuloma formation Very rarely seen
Papulonecrotic tuberculid
Erythema induratum of Bazin (nodular)

questions.text: 17. A patient with bullous keratopathy has corneal guttata in the other eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral progressive endothelial cell loss. It is usually seen in middle age and is more common in women, with a slightly increased prevalence in patients with glaucoma. It is mostly inherited sporadically, with occasional autosomal dominant inheritance. Mutations in the COL8A2 and TCF4 genes have been noted. 

There is a gradual blurring of vision, more commonly in the morning, due to corneal oedema. There is development of guttata, which are excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular microscopy). 

Signs of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy are:

* Cornea guttata, which are irregular warts or excrescences on the Descemet membrane secreted by abnormal endothelial cells 

* Subtle corneal endothelial radial lines

* Specular reflection shows tiny dark spots caused by disruption of the regular endothelial layer. It progresses to a ‘beaten metal’ appearance

* Central stromal oedema 

* Epithelial oedema develops in more advanced cases, with the formation of microcysts and bullae that cause discomfort

* Bullous keratopathy 

* Rupture of bullae associated with marked acute pain secondary to the exposure of nerve fibres.

* Subepithelial scarring and peripheral vascularisation in longstanding cases

Conservative treatment includes topical sodium chloride 5% drops or ointment, reduction of IOP and use of a hair dryer for corneal dehydration. Use of bandage contact lenses, cycloplegics, antibiotic ointment and lubricants helps to treat ruptured bullae.

Posterior lamellar keratoplasty and penetrating keratoplasty are useful. A topical Rho-kinase inhibitor with prior transcorneal endothelial cryotherapy seems to stimulate endothelial cell proliferation and improve function.

Corneal endothelium on specular microscopy, as shown below-



Light microscopic appearance of the corneal endothelium, Descemet membrane, and the adjacent corneal stroma showing guttae is shown below.



Other options:

Option A: Trachoma presents with conjunctivitis associated with a mucopurulent discharge.

Option B: Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism.

Option D: Herpes keratitis presents with redness, photophobia, watering, blurred vision and ulcers, which can lead to corneal scarring.

Pearl PM0711: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

* Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)

* Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy

* Meesman’s dystrophy

* Lisch’s epithelial dystrophy

* Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy

Bowman’s Membrane

* Reis Buckler’s dystrophy

* Thiel-Behnke corneal dystrophy

* Grayson-Wilbrandt corneal dystrophy

Stromal Corneal Dystrophies

* Lattice corneal dystrophy

* Granular dystrophy

* Macular corneal dystrophy

* Schnyder corneal dystrophy

* Fleck corneal dystrophy

* Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy

* Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois

Descemet membrane and Endothelial corneal dystrophy

* Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy

* Posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD)

* Congenital hereditary endothelial

* X-linked endothelial corneal dystrophy

questions.text: 18. A primigravida at 37 weeks presents with decreased foetal movements for 1 day. NST showed one acceleration in 20 minutes and no decelerations. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step is to continue NST for 40 minutes. 

At 37 weeks, a non-stress test (NST) with only one acceleration in 20 minutes is considered non-reactive. However, before confirming any abnormality, the NST should be extended to 40 minutes. 

In non-stress test (NST), a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with recording of fetal movements (cardiotocography) is undertaken. There is an observed association of FHR acceleration with fetal movements, which when present, indicates a healthy fetus. 

When two or more accelerations of more than 15 beats per minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation, it is intrepreted as reactive. On the other hand, a nonreactive NST is not always ominous and can be seen with a sleeping fetus. Hence, before concluding that a test is nonreactive, a 40 minute or longer tracing should be performed.

Other options:

Option A: Induction of labour is not indicated at this stage because the NST has not yet been confirmed abnormal. Reactivity may still occur with extended monitoring.

Option C: Emergency LSCS is indicated only if there is clear evidence of acute fetal distress, which is not present here. 

Option D: Instrumental delivery applies when the woman is in the second stage of labour. This patient is not in labour, so it’s not appropriate.

questions.text: 19. A 40-year-old woman presents with dry eyes, dry mouth, and dry cough. She requires frequent sips of water while eating. Schirmer test was positive. Laboratory investigations revealed ANA, anti-Ro/SSA, and anti-La/SSB antibodies. What are the characteristic features seen in this condition?

choices.text: Destruction of salivary glands due to neutrophilic infiltration
Destruction of salivary glands and lacrimal glands due to lymphocytic infiltration

questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the positive Schirmer’s test and the presence of ANA, Anti-Ro/SSA, and Anti-La/SSB antibodies, suggest a clinical suspicion of Sjögren’s disease. Salivary and Lacrimal glands are the major targets of this disease, where there is characteristic destruction of salivary glands and lacrimal glands due to lymphocytic infiltration, as shown in the image below:



It is an autoimmune disorder that has a 10-20:1 Female-to-male incidence ratio. Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, where there is a characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) due to lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.

Diagnosis by testing for antibodies against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La). Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on an immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is the investigation of choice.

Other options: 

Option A: Destruction of salivary glands due to neutrophilic infiltration can be seen in acute bacterial sialadenitis.

Option B: Malar rash and arthritis are seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

Option D: Amyloid deposition in salivary glands can be seen in amyloidosis.

questions.text:
20. A patient presented with a brain abscess in the parietooccipital region. Lab findings showed GPB with filamentous bacteria. On modified ZN staining, it showed branching filamentous bacteria which was acid-fast and grew on paraffin bait culture. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

GPB- Gram-Positive Bacilli
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and modified ZN staining showing acid-fast filamentous bacteria with growth on paraffin bait culture is suggestive of Nocardia.

Nocardia species appear as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are aerobic, gram-positive, and catalase-positive. They are weakly acid-fast.

Infections caused by Nocardia can manifest as cutaneous, systemic lesions and metastatic. It may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. Systemic nocardiosis occurs more often in immunodeficient persons and is usually caused by N.asteroides that manifests primarily as pulmonary disease, pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Metastatic manifestations may involve the brain, kidneys and other organs.

Diagnosis:

* Direct microscopy:

* Gram staining reveals gram-positive branching and filamentous bacilli 

* Modified acid-fast staining using 1% sulphuric acid as decolourizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli 

* Histopathology of the granules shows multilobulated with a sun-ray appearance

* Culture

* Selective media: Buffered yeast extract containing polymyxin and vancomycin and Sabouraud dextrose agar with chloramphenicol

* Paraffin bait technique: Media using paraffin as the sole carbon source have been shown to be effective for isolation of Nocardiae from soil and clinical samples ™

* Lowenstein–Jensen medium: Produces moist glabrous colonies (differentiates from mycobacteria)

Cotrimoxazole is used in the treatment of infections by Nocardia.

The image given below is a smear of modified acid-fast Kinyoun staining showing filamentous red-stained partially acid-fast rods suggestive of Nocardia.



Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 21. A man on long-term hydrochlorothiazide presents with cerebellar ataxia, horizontal nystagmus, bilateral symmetric sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy and right heart failure. No history of alcoholism present. Which of the following deficiencies is associated with this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Thiamine deficiency.

Cerebellar ataxia and horizontal nystagmus suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, while bilateral symmetric sensory motor peripheral neuropathy and right heart failure suggest Beriberi. These suggest Thiamine deficiency. Long-term hydrochlorothiazide administration has also been shown to cause thiamine deficiency.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to the following conditions:

* Wernicke encephalopathy: It is characterised by ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia

* Beriberi: It can present with-

*

* Dry beriberi: CNS manifestations like peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbance leading to complete paralysis. Walking becomes difficult. 

* Wet beriberi: Cardiovascular manifestations are prominent. The patient presents with edema of the legs, face, trunk, and serous cavities. Palpitation, breathlessness and distended neck veins are observed. Death occurs due to heart failure

* Korsakoff psychosis

Option A: Selenium deficiency leads to Keshan disease. It is characterised by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac enlargement.

Option C: Zinc deficiency leads to poor wound healing, lesions of skin, impaired spermatogenesis, hyperkeratosis, dermatitis and alopecia.

Option D: Deficiency in Vitamin B12 (also known as cobalamin) can lead to megaloblastic anaemia, subacute combined degeneration, and achlorhydria.

Pearl PM1154: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: 22. A 55-year-old male presented with a pulsative swelling in the neck. The swelling was compressible and refilled on removing of pressure. The digital angiography image is given below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the image showing splaying of internal and external carotid arteries, suggest the diagnosis to be a carotid body tumour, also called a chemodectoma.

Carotid body tumors are mostly benign, neurogenic tumors or paragangliomas arising from the chemoreceptor cells of the carotid bulb. They are related to catecholamine-secreting neuroendocrine tumors like pheochromocytomas and occasionally occur concurrently with them. Familial cases are caused by mutations in the SDH gene. The pathophysiology is believed to be chronic hypoxia in high-altitude states.

Clinical features are a painless, slow-growing, pulsatile lateral neck mass, usually in the 5th decade, firm in consistency moves from side to side but not up to down. The tonsil may be displaced medially. A bruit may be associated with the tumor and sometimes the mass can be emptied and slow refilling occurs.

On the angiogram, splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries at the common carotid bifurcation can be seen. This is known as Lyre's sign, as shown below:



FNAC is absolutely contraindicated. The Shamblin classification is utilised to assess the resectability of these tumors.

Other Options:

Option A: Carotid aneurysm is a swelling in the neck at the level of the thyroid cartilage, below the angle of the mandible. It is pulsatile, smooth, soft, nontender, horizontally mobile, with bruit. Neurological features due to embolic episodes, hoarseness of voice, Horner's syndrome, and dysphagia due to swelling extending into the tonsillar bed may also be present. 

Option C: Strawberry hemangiomas are capillary hemangiomas that may be present at birth or present a few weeks after birth.

Option D: AV fistula is an abnormal communication between an artery and a vein.

questions.text:
23. In a patient, ileal resection led to fatigue with Hb = 8 g/dL, MCV = 110 fL. Peripheral smear showed macrocytic anemia. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely?

Hb - Hemoglobin MCV - Mean Corpuscular Volume
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, given the history of ileal resection, macrocytosis, and low hemoglobin level.

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate. The ileum is the site of vitamin B12 absorption; hence, ileal resection predisposes the patient to develop a vitamin B12 deficiency.

In vitamin B12 deficiency, laboratory findings typically show reduced hemoglobin, indicating anemia, raised mean corpuscular volume (MCV), indicating macrocytosis (>100 fL), increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), normal mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), elevated red cell distribution width (RDW), and decreased reticulocyte count. Both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels are elevated.

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly presents with fatigue, glossitis, and angular cheilosis. Gastrointestinal symptoms such as anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation may occur. Hematologically, patients often show ineffective erythropoiesis leading to anemia, sometimes with mild jaundice. Neurological manifestations, including peripheral neuropathy and paresthesias, are also characteristic of B12 deficiency.

The peripheral smear shows macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, as shown in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by a low hemoglobin level and microcytic anemia (low MCV). Iron is essential for hemoglobin synthesis, and its deficiency leads to reduced hemoglobin levels. Iron is absorbed primarily in the duodenum.

Option C: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is mainly associated with neurological syndromes such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. It can be associated with thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia. Thiamine is absorbed in the proximal small intestine.

Option D: Folate deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia, but folate is absorbed in the proximal jejunum; hence, its deficiency is less likely after ileal resection in this patient’s condition.

questions.text: 24. A 25 year-old female has regular 28-day cycles. Which of these hormonal patterns will be seen during day 21-25 of her cycle?

choices.text: Increased estrogen, decreased progesterone, low LH, high FSH
Decreased estrogen and increased progesterone, high FSH and low LH
Increased estrogen and progesterone, low FSH and LH
Decreased estrogen and increased progesterone, low FSH and LH

questions.solution:
During days 21-25 of her menstrual cycle that is, during the luteal phase, there will be increased estrogen and progesterone and low FSH and LH.

The menstrual cycle is characterized by distinct hormonal changes across its different phases:

* In the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, the endometrium is under the control of oestrogen. The Graafian follicle secretes 17-β-oestradiol, which produces proliferative changes in the endometrium. This oestrogen produces proliferative changes in the endometrium, secretes inhibin which inhibits further secretion of FSH, and stimulates LH receptors in the theca cells while also stimulating the anterior pituitary to secrete LH.

* At ovulation (which occurs around day 14), the maximum peak of oestrogen secretion is seen about 48 hours before ovulation, whereas the LH surge occurs about 24–36 hours before ovulation. LH causes rupture of the follicle and formation of the corpus luteum.

* In the luteal phase (in this case), the ruptured follicle forms the corpus luteum, which secretes progesterone. As a result, progesterone levels rise markedly, while oestrogen is also moderately increased. These high levels exert negative feedback, so FSH and LH remain low.

* In the menstrual phase, in the absence of pregnancy, the corpus luteum regresses, leading to a decline in both oestrogen and progesterone levels. This fall removes the negative feedback, and gonadotropins begins to rise again, initiating recruitment of new follicles for the next cycle.

questions.text: 25. A patient was brought to the ER with an acute onset of neck stiffness/ rigidity and fever, who later succumbed to the illness. Given is the image of the post-mortem of the brain, which contained petechiae. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests meningitis, and the most probable causative organism is Neisseria Meningitidis.

Neisseria Meningitidis spreads from the nasopharynx to the meninges by travelling directly along the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve, through the cribriform plate or through the bloodstream to the subarachnoid space. It leads to a suppurative lesion in the meninges, involving the surface of the spinal cord as well as the base and cortex of the brain. The cocci can be seen in spinal fluid, especially intracellularly in leucocytes. It can also lead to blindness and ·deafness. Some cases develop chronic or recurrent meningitis. 

Neisseria Meningitidis can also lead to meningococcemia that starts with acute fever, chills, malaise, and a petechial rash. It can progress to fulminant meningococcemia (earlier known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome), which involves disseminated intravascular coagulation, circulatory collapse and multisystem failure.



Other options:

Option A: Mycobacterium Tuberculosis can lead to tuberculous meningitis, but doesn't present with petechiae.

Option C: Cryptococcus doesn't present with petechiae and is usually seen in an immunocompromised condition.

Option D: Actinomyces does not lead to meningitis but leads to cervicofacial, thoracic and abdominal lesions.

questions.text: 26. An elderly male presented with epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and jaundice since 2 years. He had scratch marks over the body. On examination, the gall bladder was palpable, smooth and non-tender. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and jaundice for 2 years with a palpable, smooth and non-tender gall bladder suggests the most probable diagnosis to be carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas presents with jaundice that occurs secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct. It can also be associated with nausea, epigastric discomfort, weight loss, pruritus, dark urine and pale stools with steatorrhoea. In the absence of jaundice, symptoms are often non-specific, such as vague discomfort, anorexia and weight loss.

On examination, there may be evidence of a palpable liver and a palpable gallbladder. According to Courvoisier's Law, in a patient with jaundice, with a palpable, enlarged, non-tender gallbladder, the cause is unlikely to be due to gallstones and is more likely to be due to a periampullary malignancy. This is because the common bile duct obstruction by gallstones would lead to chronic inflammation, which causes the gallbladder to shrink and become fibrotic. The gallbladder is enlarged in conditions causing a slow occlusion, as in tumours surrounding the distal common bile duct, which implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas.

With widespread disease, a left supraclavicular node (Virchow node) and a periumbilical lymph node (Sister Mary Joseph node) may be palpable. In cases of peritoneal dissemination, perirectal tumour involvement may be palpable through digital rectal examination, known as the Blumer shelf.

Other options:

Option A: Choledocholithiasis is usually asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients with cholangitis have bouts of pain, jaundice and fever, known as Charcot’s triad. 

Option C: Patients with carcinoma of the gall bladder may be asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, they are usually indistinguishable from those of benign gallbladder disease, such as biliary colic or cholecystitis, particularly in older patients. Jaundice, palpable mass and anorexia are late features.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma is most commonly seen in men 50 to 60 years of age who complain of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, weight loss and have a palpable mass. Presentation at an advanced stage is often with vague right upper quadrant abdominal pain that sometimes radiates to the right shoulder. Other nonspecific symptoms that can be seen are anorexia, nausea, lethargy, and weight loss.

questions.text: 27. A city has 70,00,000 urban population, 30% of which live in slums. How many U-PHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM norms?
questions.solution:
42 U-PHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM norms.

The total urban population of the city is 70,00,000, out of which 30% live in slums. This means the slum population is 30/100 x 70,00,000 = 21,00,000.

According to National Urban Health Mission, one Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC) is required for every 50,000 people living in slum and vulnerable areas. By dividing 21,00,000 by 50,000, we get 42, which means the city would require 42 U-PHCs to adequately cover its slum population.

Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC) are functional for a population of approximately 50,000 and may be located preferably within a slum or near a slum within half a kilometer radius. At the U-PHC level services provided will include OPD (consultation), basic laboratory diagnosis, drug/contraceptive dispensing, apart from distribution of health education material, delivering RCH services and counselling for all communicable and non-communicable diseases. In order to ensure access to the urban slum population at convenient timings, the U-PHC provide services from 12 noon to 8 pm.

The urban health care facilities under the National Urban Health Mission are shown in the image below:



Pearl PM0158: Primary Health Centres-PHC

* HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas

* Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000

* Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s Bed distribution:

Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds


Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds. The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

* Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 

* Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services

* Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services

* Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services

* Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes

* General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments

* Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases

* Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems

* Basic Oral Health Care

* Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services

* Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma

* Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27
