questions.text: 28. A sewage worker presented with symptoms of fever, jaundice and conjunctival hemorrhage, he later succumbed to the disease. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Weil's disease (leptospirosis).

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by Leptospira interrogans. Humans are infected when the leptospirae in water contaminated with the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva. Hence, a sewage worker is at an increased risk of it.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease). There are two clinical types of leptospirosis: icteric and non-icteric. 

The life cycle of Leptospira is depicted below:





Laboratory tests: 

* Microscopy -

* Examination of blood - Leptospirae may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from the blood after 1 week

* Examination of urine: Leptospirae appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposits of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination

* Culture - With semisynthetic media like Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.

* Serotype-specific tests:

* Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

* Macroscopic agglutination test  

* A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae-specific IgM antibodies in human sera

Other options:

Option A: Brucellosis can be acute or chronic. Acute Brucellosis presents with muscular and articular pains, asthmatic attacks, nocturnal drenching sweats, exhaustion, anorexia, constipation, nervous irritability and chills. Chronic Brucellosis presents with sweating, joint pain, with minimal or no pyrexia, and the illness lasts for years.

Option C: Dengue hemorrhagic fever- Clinical criteria of dengue fever plus hemorrhagic tendencies evidenced by one or more of the following:

* Positive tourniquet test

* Petechiae, ecchymoses or purpura

* Bleeding from the mucosa, gastrointestinal tract, injection sites or other sites

* Thrombocytopenia, a more than 20% drop in haematocrit following volume replacement treatment compared to baseline 

* Signs of plasma leakage (pleural effusion, ascites, hypoproteinemia) 

Option D: Hepatitis A- The majority of infections are asymptomatic. The clinical disease consists of two stages: the prodromal or preicteric and icteric stages. Onset can be acute or insidious, and the patient presents with fever, malaise, anorexia, nausea, vomiting and liver tenderness. These usually subside with the onset of jaundice.

questions.text: 29. A 65-year-old woman presented with abdominal swelling and discomfort. Ultrasonography showed ascites and a multiloculated, predominantly cystic swelling with papillary projections. CA-125 was 1035IU/mL. The gross image of the resected mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is serous cystadenocarcinoma, a common epithelial ovarian cancer seen in postmenopausal women.

This patient’s presentation with abdominal swelling, ascites, ultrasonography showing a multiloculated cystic mass with papillary projections and the gross image showing a large, multilocular cystic mass is most suggestive of serous cystadenocarcinoma. The markedly elevated CA-125 level (1035 IU/mL) further supports the diagnosis, as this tumour marker is typically raised in epithelial ovarian cancers like the serous type. 

Other options: 

Option A: Granulosa cell tumor are sex cord-stromal tumors that are hormonally active and often produce estrogen, leading to symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding or endometrial hyperplasia, which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, granulosa cell tumors rarely cause massive ascites, and they typically secrete inhibin, which is a marker for this tumour.

Option B: Sertoli–Leydig cell tumour are rare ovarian tumours that are androgen-producing, which causes defeminization followed by masculinization. They usually present with features such as flattening of breasts, amenorrhea, hirsutism, enlargement of the clitoris, and even breaking of the voice. Imaging often shows a gross appearance like that of other mesenchymomas, and CA-125 is usually not markedly elevated.

Option C: Immature teratoma is a rare tumour containing elements from multiple germ layers. They are mostly solid tumours with a trabeculated appearance. The solid part of the tumour contains cartilage, bone, and muscle, whereas hair and sebaceous material are found in the cystic spaces. A rudimentary eye can also be seen. They are generally malignant, whereas mature teratomas like dermoid cysts are benign. They are not commonly associated with papillary projections, massive ascites, or markedly raised CA-125, which are hallmarks of epithelial ovarian cancers like serous cystadenocarcinoma.

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right).



Pearl PM1433: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

* Serous tumors

* Mucinous tumors

* Endometrioid tumors

* Clear cell 

* Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

* Seromucinous

* Undifferentiated carcinoma

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

* Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor

* Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor

* Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

* Dysgerminoma

* Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Polyembryoma

* Non-gestational choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma (Mature/immature)

* Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

* Pure

* Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary VI. Miscellaneous tumors VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors VIII. Tumor-like conditions

Pearl PM1872: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell


Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

* D: Dysgerminoma

* P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)

* L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: 30. An 8 year old girl presented with follicular hyperkeratotic papules over the elbow, knees and buttocks. She has dry skin and lusterless hair. Which of the following is the next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ocular examination is the next step in evaluation. 

This child’s presentation with follicular hyperkeratotic papules over extensor surfaces, dry skin, and lusterless hair is characteristic of phrynoderma, which is a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency. The next important step in evaluation is to assess for ocular involvement (to look for conjunctival xerosis, Bitot’s spots, keratomalacia), since Vitamin A deficiency can lead to visual impairment if not detected early.

The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia), followed by xerophthalmia. Aberrant keratinization in the oral and nasal mucosa may result in hyposmia and hypogeusia. Patients also often complain of generalized xerosis.

Ocular complications range from night blindness, corneal xerosis and Bitot spots (white keratinized lesions) to corneal ulceration, keratomalacia, corneal perforation, iris prolapse and blindness. The most significant complication of severe vitamin A deficiency is blindness.

Cutaneous findings include xerosis and scaling, dermomalacia and phrynoderma. Phrynoderma is characterized by keratotic follicular papules involving the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and can spread to the extensor extremities, shoulders, posterior neck, back, buttocks and abdomen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot seen on the surface of the conjunctiva:



Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets/osteomalacia, not follicular keratotic papules.

Option B: Deep tendon reflex is relevant for neurological causes (e.g., B12 deficiency), not for keratotic papules.

Option C: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological signs, not dry skin with keratotic papules.

Pearl PM1940: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months


 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

* 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months

* 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months

* 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU


 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Pearl PM1463: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium


 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: 32. A 35-year-old assaults his co-worker in the office. He was of the opinion that his co-worker was going to kill him, as he heard from voices in his ear. The patient appears dishevelled, with disorganised speech. What is the best course of legal action?

choices.text: Declare him not guilty due to mental illness
Refer the patient for comprehensive psychiatric evaluation

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the best course of legal action is referring the accused for a comprehensive psychiatric evaluation.

As per the given scenario, the accused appears to be of unsound mind. According to section 368(2) of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS), previously, section 329 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), if, during a trial, the Magistrate or Court of Session finds the accused to be of unsound mind, they must refer such a person to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist for assessment and care. The concerned professional will then submit a report regarding the accused's mental condition, guiding further legal proceedings.

Other options:

Option A: As per Bharat Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 22, nothing is an offence if done by an individual who, at the time of the act, is of unsound mind. Hence, proceeding with a routine trial without establishing or ruling out unsoundness of mind is not correct.

Option B: The court cannot declare the accused not guilty due to mental illness without obtaining a report regarding the accused's psychiatric evaluation, as this would be a violation of section 368(2) of BNSS.

Option D: In this case, the patient's behavior points towards a mental illness rather than mere anger; hence, referring the patient for anger management is not the most appropriate legal course of action.

questions.text: 33. In an experimental study of insulin after glucose administration, blood glucose was brought to 300 mg/dL and maintained at that level. What will happen to insulin in this condition?

choices.text: Rapid increase in insulin initially and gradual decrease
Insulin increased inititally and maintained at that level

questions.solution:
The release of insulin after glucose administration is biphasic, in which insulin secretion increases initially and is maintained at that level.

After a rise in blood glucose to a level that is 2-3 times normal, there is a sudden increase in plasma insulin due to the release of preformed insulin. Since this preformed pool is limited, the peak insulin level is not sustained and gradually declines. With persistent hyperglycemia, insulin levels rise again, this time due to the secretion of newly synthesized insulin. This second phase is slower, more prolonged, and continues until a plateau is reached.

This can be understood from the following graphical representation of plasma insulin levels:

questions.text: 34. A primigravida suffers atonic postpartum haemorrhage during labour. After initial measures and medical management failed, what is the next best step of management that can be done in the labour room?
questions.solution:
In a primigravida with atonic PPH where initial measures like uterine massage and medical management have failed, the next best step of management that can be done in the labour room is balloon tamponade.

For balloon tamponade, Foley catheter, Bakri balloon, Condom catheter or Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is inserted into the uterine cavity and the balloon is inflated with normal saline (200-500 mL). It reduces PPH by stimulating uterine contraction and exerting direct hemostatic pressure (tamponade effect) to the open uterine sinuses. It is kept for 4-6 hours. This can avoid hysterectomy in most cases.

The given image shows Bakri balloon tamponade:





The following are the steps used in controlling postpartum haemorrhage:

* Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.

* In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 

* If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.

* Uterine massage and bimanual compression

* Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)

* Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:

* Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture

* Ligation of uterine arteries

* Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis

* Ligation of internal iliac artery

* Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel

*   Hysterectomy

questions.text: 35. A G2P1L1 suffers cord prolapse during labour. Cervix was 5cm dilated and cord pulsations were present. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Elevate buttocks, tilt head back and fill bladder
Push the cord back into the vagina and pack

questions.solution:
The best step in management of cord prolapse with pulsations present is to relieve pressure on the cord immediately. This is done by elevating the buttocks and tilting head back (trendelenberg position), and filling the bladder with fluid. These measures lift the presenting part off the cord and improve blood flow.

Vago's method is used in cord prolapse to alleviate pressure on the cord. Vagos method is also known as the bladder-filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

* Living or dead baby

* Viability of the baby

* Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

* If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 

* When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances, as it takes a longer time 

* Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction

* Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

*

When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible:

* Oxytocin infusion is stopped

* IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring

* Relieve pressure on the cord by:

* Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.

* Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.

* Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord.

* Funic reduction: Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.

* Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

* If the baby is dead -

*

* Reconfirmation with ultrasound

* Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed

* Destructive operations are rarely needed

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below:



Other options:

Option B: Wait and watch is not an option because ongoing compression can quickly lead to fetal hypoxia and death.

Option C: Oxytocin to accelerate delivery is not useful at 5 cm dilation because vaginal delivery will not happen immediately. The baby will not be delivered fast enough to prevent damage.

Option D: Pushing the cord back and packing is avoided as it may increase trauma and worsen compression, leading to more harm.

questions.text: 36. A boy sustained a fracture, and an X-ray was done. The lateral X-ray of the nasal bone shows a nasal bone fracture. Which forceps are used for immediate correction?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray is suggestive of a nasal bone fracture. Walsham forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

Nasal bone fractures usually result from direct trauma such as fights, falls, sports injuries, or road accidents. Clinical examination may show deformity, swelling, bruising, and nasal obstruction. Imaging may aid in the diagnosis, but the diagnosis is mainly made on the basis of physical examination.

Nasal fracture management involves closed reduction, ideally before the appearance of edema or once it subsides, using instruments like elevators and forceps to realign bones. Simple, non-displaced fractures may not require treatment, while unstable fractures need intranasal packing and external splints for support.



Open reduction is reserved for cases where closed methods fail or for complex injuries. Prompt drainage of a septal hematoma is essential to prevent complications.

Asch's forceps is used to reduce nasal septum fractures.



Other options:

Option A: Tilley’s forceps is used for anterior nasal packing in epistaxis.



Option C: Bayonet forceps are used to examine, grasp or extract tissues and foreign materials from within the ear and nasal cavities.



Option D: Luc’s forceps is used in the Caldwell-Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

questions.text: 37. A 10 year old girl presents with freckles on her face, neck, arms and hands. These lesions are sensitive to sunlight. She also has two basal cell carcinomas on her face. Which of the following defect is seen in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Xeroderma pigmentosum. A defect in Nucleotide excision repair is seen in this condition.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterised by a defective NER (nucleotide excision repair) mechanism. Ultraviolet rays (sunlight) cause the formation of thymine dimers, where covalent bonds are formed between adjacent thymine residues.

There is sensitivity to ultraviolet rays, and exposure to sunlight can lead to blisters on the skin. There are seven XP genes (A to G) necessary for the NER mechanism in humans, and a mutation in any one of them may lead to the condition XP. 

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration, suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyperpigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.



Patients with XP have a greater chance of developing skin cancer than do normal persons. Avoiding sunlight and using sunscreen ointment is beneficial. Death usually occurs in the second decade of life due to squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text: 38. A 10-year-old child presents with enlarged orange colored tonsils. There is a history of the death of a family member due to cardiovascular disease. Laboratory investigations show total cholesterol - 80mg/dL, triglycerides - 300mg/dL, and HDL 5mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of enlarged orange colored tonsils with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) suggest a diagnosis of Tangier's disease.

Tangier's disease is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to an absence of ATP-Binding Cassette Transporter-1 (ABC-1), which is involved in transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL. There is a defect in the efflux (flowing out) of cholesterol from cells, and a reduction of HDL and LDL levels in the blood. 

Cholesterol esters get accumulated in tissues. The patient presents with large orange-yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies and atherosclerosis.



The table below gives a range of normal parameters.

  Low risk (desirable level) Borderline risk High risk
Total cholesterol (mg/dl) <200 200-400 >240
LDL cholesterol (mg/dl) <130 130-160 >160
HDL cholesterol (mg/dl) >60 35-60 <35
Triglyceride (mg/dl) <150 200-400 >400


Other options:

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia characterised by the absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, or LDL because of a defect in the loading of apo B with lipid.

Option C: Niemann Pick Disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of sphingomyelin. There is a deficiency of the enzyme sphingomyelinase in this condition

Option D: Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterised by defective LDL receptors or a mutation in the ligand region of apo B-100. There is an elevation of LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia, resulting in atherosclerosis and coronary disease.

2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and tendon xanthomas

4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: 39. Which of the following is defined as "measuring the degree to which objectives and targets are met and the quality of the results obtained"?
questions.solution:
Evaluation is defined as measuring the degree to which objectives and targets are met and the quality of the results obtained, as per the WHO Expert Committee on National Health Planning in Developing Countries. 

The purpose of evaluation is to assess the achievement of the objectives of a programme, its adequacy and efficiency. It measures the productivity of available resources in achieving clearly defined objectives. It measures how much output or cost-effectiveness is achieved. 

Other options:

Option A: Monitoring is the day-to-day follow-up of activities during their implementation. It is a continuous process of observing, recording and reporting on the activities of the organisation or project. It keeps track of the course activities and identifies deviations. 

Option B: Planning is the formulation of a plan. A plan is the blueprint for taking action in order to achieve the goal. The planning cycle includes:



Option D: Supervision is a systematic activity for increasing the efficiency of health workers through direct contacts. It is an extension of training that serves to increase the knowledge, perfect the skills, improve the attitudes and strengthen the motivation of involved health personnel.

questions.text: 40. A 2-year-old child presents to the OPD with delayed developmental milestones, organomegaly, corneal clouding and weakness. Enzyme assay reveals alpha L-iduronidase deficiency. What of the following compounds will accumulate in this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with delayed developmental milestones and deficiency of the enzyme L-iduronidase suggests Hurler syndrome. There is an accumulation of Dermatan sulphate and Heparan sulphate. 

Hurler syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis I) is a severe, progressive disorder that involves a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. This results in the clinical manifestations of mental retardation, enlarged head circumference, joint stiffness, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and cloudy corneas. There may also be a presence of inguinal hernias.

Other manifestations that can be seen are:

* Recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge

* Valvular heart disease, with incompetence of the mitral and aortic valves, and narrowing of the coronary arteries

* Obstructive airway disease, especially during sleep

* Progressive ventricular enlargement with increased intracranial pressure caused by communicating hydrocephalus also occurs

The earliest radiographic signs are thick ribs and ovoid vertebral bodies. Skeletal abnormalities include enlarged, coarsely trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphyses and epiphyses. 

The given image below shows coarse facial features, an umbilical hernia, a claw hand, a thoracolumbar kyphosis and broad ribs.



The given image shows cloudy cornea in mucopolysaccharidosis.



Scheie Syndrome is also Mucopolysaccharidosis I. It is characterised by joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Patients have normal intelligence and stature but have significant joint and ocular involvement.

questions.text: 41. A medical college is organising a 'health mela' for the community. A group of students are deputed to a stall to show the 'Nalgonda technique' related to water. A student is sent to the store room to get two chemicals required for the demonstration of this technique. The following image shows the chemicals that she sees in the store room labelled A,B,C and D. Which two chemicals does she take?
questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is a method used for defluoridation of water, and it requires alum and lime (Image 1 and 4).

Nalgonda technique was developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment. The process used for the defluoridation of water involves the addition of lime and alum followed by, flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration. This process can be used for domestic and community water supplies.

The image given below depicts the Nalgonda technique:



Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.  Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake.

* Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling of dental enamel. The appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance in severe cases. Mottling is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth during its period of formation.

* Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. 

* Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

* Genu valgum: Characterised by genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limbs and observed among people whose staple is sorghum (jowar). It is a new form of fluorosis reported in some districts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. 

The given image shows skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification):



Interventions for Fluorosis:

* Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.

* The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique.

* Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.

* The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

questions.text: 42. A patient comes to the ER with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, sweating, and blood in stools initially, which later became watery. The patient also complains of throat pain followed by purging and vomiting. Vomitus contains bile and blood, and he also has a garlicky odour. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a garlicky odor is highly suggestive of acute arsenic (gastroenteric type) poisoning.

The gastroenteric variant of acute arsenic poisoning, which is the most common type, resembles bacterial food poisoning. Symptoms usually appear half to one hour after ingestion. The symptoms include:

* Constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing;

* Burning and colicky pain in the esophagus, stomach, and bowel.

* Intense thirst and severe vomiting, which may be projectile.

* Purging (within 1 to 3 hours) is usually accompanied by tenesmus, pain.

* The stools are expelled frequently and involuntarily, and are dark-coloured, stinking, and bloody, but later become colourless, odourless, and watery, resembling rice-water stools of cholera. 

* A garlicky odour of breath and faeces may be noted.

Oliguria, uraemia, and acute circulatory collapse are the causes of death. 

In fulminant cases, i.e., massive doses (3 to 5 gm) of arsenic when rapidly absorbed, cause death in 1 to 3 hours from shock and peripheral vascular failure.

Treatment of arsenic poisoning includes repeated stomach wash with warm water and milk, small doses of freshly precipitated hydrated ferric oxide to convert toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite, BAL with penicillamine, DMSA (succimer) or DMPS as superior alternatives, haemodialysis or exchange transfusion in renal failure, while chelation therapy is ineffective.

Other options: 

Option B: Acute phosphorus poisoning that is mainly caused by white phosphorus, which is the most toxic form of phosphorus, mimics arsenic poisoning with similar GI symptoms and garlicky odor. However, luminescent vomit and faeces are diagnostic.

Option C: In acute aluminium phosphide poisoning, the phosphine gas causes predominantly respiratory symptoms and distress, rather than GI symptoms.

Option D: Croton seeds (jamalgota) cause hot burning pain from the mouth to the stomach, salivation, vomiting, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death. Applied to the skin, it produces burning, redness, and vesication. There is no garlicky odor.

questions.text: 43. A 20 year old man from Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh presented with weakness in limbs and outward bowing of legs. His diet consisted of jowar roti and rice. He is diagnosed with osteoporosis. Which of the following interventions will you not do?

choices.text: Addition of alum and lime in drinking water
Provision of running surface water for drinking

questions.solution:
The intervention you will not do is fluoride supplementation.

The presentation of weakness in limbs, outward bowing of legs with a location in Chittoor, which is a fluorosis-endemic area, and osteoporosis-like bone changes points towards skeletal fluorosis due to excess fluoride in drinking water. A new form of flurosis characterised by genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limbs has been reported in some districts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. It is observed among people whose staple is sorghum (jowar) since a diet based on sorghum promotes higher retention of ingested fluoride than do diets based on rice. In such cases, the goal is to reduce fluoride intake, not supplement it.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.  Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake.

* Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling of dental enamel. The appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance in severe cases. Mottling is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth during its period of formation.

* Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

* Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

* Genu valgum with osteoporosis of the lower limbs in people whose staple is sorghum (jowar). It has been seen that diets based on sorghum promoted a higher retention of ingested fluoride than diets based on rice. 

The given image shows skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification):



Interventions for Fluorosis:

* Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content of 0.5 to 0.8 mg/L (Option C). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources (Option D).

* The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 

* Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.

* The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration (Option B). The image given below depicts the Nalgonda technique:

questions.text: 44. A young lady presents with jaundice and pruritus. She is antimitochondrial antibody positive and ANA negative. Biopsy shows portal inflammation and ductular proliferation with lymphocytic infiltrate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the biopsy findings, point to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is a chronic autoimmune liver disease characterized by the chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It is commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. 

Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites, may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in most patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas (shown in the image below).



Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC. Seladelpar and Elafibranor are newly approved drugs to treat PBC.

Other options:

Option B: Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. They are more common in females and are typically diagnosed in childhood. The most common form shows fusiform dilatation of the bile duct.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ↑ AST, and ↑ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia is a tumor of the liver commonly seen in young women. It shows a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar. On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout.

questions.text: 45. The given image is that of cardiac action potential. In which phase does Amiodarone act?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone acts mainly on Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential, that is, the repolarisation phase. 

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that blocks voltage-gated potassium channels. It acts by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period of cardiac cells, which is beneficial in managing tachyarrhythmias like ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation. It also has weak calcium channel blocking, sodium channel blocking, and adrenergic blocking actions.



Adverse effects of amiodarone are:

* Prolonged usage of amiodarone causes pulmonary fibrosis

* Bradycardia and QT prolongation

* Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism

* Corneal micro-deposits 

The image below shows skin pigmentation in a patient due to prolonged amiodarone therapy.

questions.text: 46. A child presents with visual disturbances and delayed growth. Imaging reveals a suprasellar mass and histopathology shows the presence of "wet keratin". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with imaging showing a suprasellar mass with histopathology showing "wet keratin," points to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has a bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Wet keratin refers to compact, lamellar keratin formation that is characteristically associated with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma. Papillary craniopharyngioma is differentiated from adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma by the absence of lamellar keratin, calcifications, cysts, peripheral palisading of squamous cells, and a spongy reticulum.

The following is an MRI showing a suprasellar mass, as seen in craniopharyngioma.



The following histopathological image shows wet keratin along with solid and cystic components seen in the tumor.



Other options:

Option A: Gliomas, which are the most common group of primary brain tumors, include ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, and astrocytoma.

Option C: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement. Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer-Wright rosettes.

Option D: Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in ­proteins (particularly GNAS). Depending on their size, they are classified as microadenomas (diameter < 1 cm) and macroadenomas (diameter > 1 cm). They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas is prolactinomas.

questions.text: 47. What is the order of closure in a mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.solution:
The correct order of closure in a mediolateral episiotomy is Mucosa → Muscle → Skin.

The repair of a mediolateral episiotomy is done in three layers. The repair is to be done in the following order

* Vaginal mucosa and submucosal tissues

* Perineal muscles

* Skin and subcutaneous tissues

The vaginal mucosa is sutured first. The apex of the episiotomy is identified, and an anchor stitch is placed. Thereafter, the vaginal walls are apposed by interrupted sutures with polyglycolic acid suture or chromic catgut, from above downwards till the fourchette is reached. A continuous suture may cause puckering and shortening of the posterior vaginal wall. Care should be taken not to injure the rectum. 

The principles to be followed are: 

* Perfect hemostasis

* To obliterate the dead space

* Suture without tension

 However, routine episiotomy is not recommended for the management of the 2nd stage of labour. The indications of an episiotomy are:

* Rigid inelastic perineum causing arrest or delay in descent of the presenting part as in elderly primigravidae

* Anticipating perineal tear due to a big baby, face-to-pubis delivery, breech delivery, shoulder dystocia, and persistent occiput posterior

* Operative delivery, like forceps delivery and ventouse delivery

* Previous perineal surgery, like pelvic floor repair and perineal reconstructive surgery

The image below shows the episiotomy scissors:



Pearl PM0044: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

* Posterior vaginal wall

* Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani

* Fascia covering those muscles

* Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves

* Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: 48. An old man complains of fatigue. On examination, there is generalised lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the investigation that differentiates cancers based on CD markers?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is the investigation that differentiates based on CD markers of different cancers.

Flow cytometry is a laser-based method that analyzes cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules, which are named according to the cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD-labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Given is a dot plot obtained after performing flow cytometry. The plot is divided into 4 quadrants based on the presence or absence of antigen A & B. Each dot represents a single cell. The position of the dot expresses whether the cell expresses antigen A, antigen B, both, or neither

* Quadrant 1: Cells positive for antigen B but negative for antigen A.

* Quadrant 2: Cells negative for both antigen A and antigen B.

* Quadrant 3: Cells positive for both antigen A and antigen B.

* Quadrant 4: Cells positive for antigen A but negative for antigen B.



Other options:

Option A: Gene typing or molecular genetic tests can detect specific gene rearrangements or mutations, but do not directly differentiate cell types based on CD markers.

Option C: Bone marrow biopsy helps in identifying morphological and histological changes associated with cancers. Additional immunophenotyping tests, such as flow cytometry, are needed to differentiate cancers based on CD markers.

Option D: Cytogenetics helps in studying chromosomal abnormalities but does not analyze CD markers.

questions.text: 49. A 35-year-old man is brought to the psychiatry emergency with bizarre symptoms. A social worker reports that the man lives in a nearby village that was recently hit by an earthquake. The man appears confused and does not know how he travelled the 110 km to this city. He is unable to recollect his personal details and has no history of any substance abuse or head trauma. The family members are worried about the patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis from the given clinical scenario is dissociative fugue. 

Dissociative fugue is characterised by sudden episodes of travelling away (usually away from home). The person usually adopts a new identity during the episode, with complete amnesia for the previous life. It usually occurs due to severe stress. The termination is abrupt and is followed by amnesia for the episode, but the patient recollects the memories of earlier life. 

Other options:

Option B: Dissociative amnesia is characterised by a sudden inability to recall important personal information. The patient has amnesia related to stressful or traumatic life events. There is no evidence of an underlying medical illness.

Option C: Transient global amnesia is caused by temporary cerebral ischaemia in the distribution of the posterior cerebral circulation. It has an abrupt onset and resembles amnestic syndrome.

Option D: Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states of which only one is being manifest at a time.  Usually, one personality is not aware of the existence of the other personality. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

Pearl PM0378: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 


ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

* Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Depersonalization-Derealization disorder

* Dissociative Amnesia

* Trance Disorder

* Possession Trance Disorder

* Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder

* Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: 50. A patient presents with carcinoma near the anal opening. Which among the following lymph nodes are most likely to be involved first?
questions.solution:
In a patient with carcinoma near the anal opening, superficial inguinal lymph nodes are most likely to be involved first.

The tumor in the given clinical scenario is located near the anal opening, which means that it lies below the pectinate line. Lesions below this line typically drain lymph to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making them the most likely site for metastasis.

The anal canal measures approximately 3.8 cm in length and extends from the anorectal junction to the anus. It is divided into three parts:

* The upper mucosal part is 15 mm long, is endodermal in origin, and contains the anal columns and anal sinuses. The pectinate line marks the junction between the upper mucosal part and the middle transitional zone.

* The middle transitional zone is 15 mm long, is also lined by mucous membrane, and is ectodermal in origin. The lower boundary of this part often appears whitish and is referred to as the white line of Hilton.

* The lowest cutaneous part is 8 mm long, is lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium, and contains sebaceous glands.

Lymphatic drainage from the region above the pectinate line is directed to the internal iliac lymph nodes (option B), whereas drainage from the region below this line is directed to the medial group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes. The pectinate line serves as the watershed line of the anal canal.



Pearl PM2214: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING

External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis


 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

questions.text: 51. Identify the type of suture material given in the image.
questions.solution:
Polydioxanone is a monofilament suture.

Polydioxanone is a slowly absorbing monofilament suture. Since they are monofilament sutures, they can resist infection better than braided multifilament sutures. It is used in abdominal wall closure.



An ideal suture material for abdominal wall closure should:

* Resist infection

* Provide adequate tensile strength to prevent abdominal wall disruption

* Reduce tissue damage

* Be an absorbable material

questions.text: 52. A patient presents with 2 months of amenorrhea with enlarged uterus. On examination, there is darkening of areola, prominent Montgomery tubercles, linea nigra is present and there is bluish discolouration of the vagina on PV. How would you categorise these signs in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings are categorised as probable signs of pregnancy.

The patient shows amenorrhea, breast changes (like darkened areola and Montgomery tubercles), linea nigra, and Chadwick’s sign, which are presumptive signs of pregnancy. However, the patient also has uterine enlargement, which is an objective physical change of the uterus and is classified as a probable sign of pregnancy, because it is detectable by the clinician. Although most features are presumptive, the presence of uterine enlargement, which is a probable sign, makes the overall signs of pregnancy beyond purely presumptive, and this patient’s findings can be categorised as probable signs of pregnancy.

The signs and symptoms of pregnancy can be categorised into: 

* Presumptive signs: These are primarily the features appreciated by the woman and include amenorrhea, frequency of micturition, morning sickness, fatigue, breast changes, skin pigmentation (like linea nigra and chloasma), quickening.

* Probable signs: These are mainly detectable physical changes in the uterus observed by the clinician. They include uterine enlargement, changes in shape and consistency of the uterus, Hegar’s sign (softening of the lower uterine segment), Jacquemier’s sign, ballottement, and immunological tests.

* Positive (absolute) signs: These are absolute indicators of pregnancy and include palpation of fetal parts, perception of fetal movements by the examiner, auscultation of fetal heart sounds, and ultrasound detection of the gestational sac or embryo. These signs confirm pregnancy beyond doubt.

Other options:

Option D:  In pseudopregnancy, there is no true pregnancy. It is also called as pseudocyesis, which is a psychological disorder where the woman has the false but firm belief that she is pregnant, although no pregnancy exists. The conspicuous feature is cessation of menstruation. Obstetric examination often excludes pregnancy. Examination with ultrasound and immunological tests for pregnancy is done to exclude pregnancy.

Pearl PM1824: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: 53. Benralizumab was given for the treatment of asthma in a patient. What does this drug act on?
questions.solution:
Benralizumab binds to IL-5 receptor and blocks the action of IL-5.

Anti–IL-5 and anti–IL-5 receptor (IL-5Rα) blocking antibodies inhibit eosinophilic inflammation in asthmatic patients. Benralizumab binds to IL-5 receptor and causes apoptosis and rapid resolution of eosinophilic inflammation in the airways.

Other monoclonal antibodies, generally approved for asthma, which act against IL-5, are Mepolizumab and Reslizumab.

Other options:

Option A: Anakinra acts on IL-1 and is used in the treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B: Dupilumab acts on IL-4, and it is effective in atopic dermatitis and asthma.

Option D: Adalimumab acts on TNF-alpha and can be used in the treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, plaque psoriasis, and psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: 54. A city experiences a chemical plant leak and toxic fumes are released into the atmosphere. What is your immediate recommendation to the local residents?

choices.text: Seal cracks and close all windows and doors

questions.solution:
In a chemical plant leak where toxic fumes are released into the atmosphere, the safest immediate step before evacuation orders is to prevent the toxic fumes from entering by sealing cracks and closing all windows and doors.

In the event of a toxic gas leak, the following measures are to be taken:

1. Before the emergency:

* Find out about evacuation plans and facilities

* Familiarize yourself with the alarm signals used in case of emergency

* Equip doors and windows with the tightest possible fastenings

* Prepare family emergency kits

2. During the emergency:

* Do not use the telephone; leave lines free for rescue services (Option A)

* Listen to the messages given by radio and other media. Carry out the instructions transmitted by radio or loudspeaker

* Close doors and windows (Option C)

* Stop up air intakes

* Seal any cracks or gaps around windows and doors with adhesive tape

* Organize a reserve of water (by filling wash basins, baths, etc.)

* Turn off ventilators and air conditioners

3. After the emergency:

* Comply with the authorities’ instructions and do not go out until there is no longer any risk (Option B)

* Carry out necessary decontamination measures

* Following these steps helps to minimize exposure to harmful gases, maintain safety indoors, and ensure a safe return to normal conditions once the danger has passed

questions.text: 55. A male comes to the casualty after an RTA with a midshaft fracture of the femur and undergoes surgery. In the ward, 2 days later, the patient presented with breathlessness, tachycardia, confusion and petechial rashes over the chest and conjunctival haemorrhage. What's the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with breathlessness, tachycardia, confusion and petechial rashes over the chest and conjunctival haemorrhage 2 days after a surgery for midshaft fracture of the femur after an RTA suggests the probable diagnosis to be Fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after the fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors:

* The release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats causes toxic vasculitis.

* Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

The early signs of fat embolism syndrome that occur within 72 hours of injury are fever and tachycardia. The presenting features can be classified into 2 types:

* Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and coma

* Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia

Petechial rashes can be seen on the front of the neck, anterior axillary fold, chest, and conjunctiva.

Other options:

Option A: DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) will present with thrombosis and bleeding.

Option B: Sepsis will present with fever, tachycardia, and hypovolemia.

Option D: Pulmonary embolism presents with a sudden onset of dyspnoea and usually occurs due to deep vein thrombosis.

Pearl PM1500: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria

* Petechial rash

* Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes

* CNS depression.

Minor criteria

* Tachycardia

* Pyrexia

* Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)

* Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)

* Acute thrombocytopenia

* Acute decrease in hemoglobin

* Fat globules in sputum

* Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: 56. A 30-year-old young man presents to the clinic with a recurrent history of disseminated gonococcal infection. Cultures of urethral discharge and synovial fluid from the knee showed growth of Neisseria gonorrhea. Which is the following immunodeficiencies is seen?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of complement components C5, C6, C7, and C8 can lead to infection due to Neisseria gonorrhea. 

The membrane attack complex consists of complement components C5 to C9 and is formed by the activation of the classical pathway. It can produce pores that lead to lysis of the target cells. Deficiency of this complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.



Other options:

Option A: C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency leads to Hereditary angioneurotic edema.

Option B: MPO (Myeloperoxidase) deficiency is an enzyme produced by neutrophils. Patients present with immune deficiency and recurrent infections, especially with Candida albicans.

Option D: Lazy Leukocyte Syndrome is a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis, which results in increased pyogenic infections such as gingivitis, abscess formation, pneumonia and neutropenia.

Pearl PM0410: Functions of Complement



* Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.

* C5a is also a chemotactic agent.

* Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.

* Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

Pearl PM1923: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency
C1, C2, C4 Immune- complex disease (SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1-inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema

questions.text: 57. The point B in the length-tension graph of the sarcomere depicts which among the following illustrations?
questions.solution:
Point B in the given length-tension graph corresponds to image (3).

The following table explains the length-tension graph for a sarcomere:

Point Sarcomere Length Muscle Tension Corresponding Image
D No actin-myosin overlap Zero muscle tension Image (2)
C Actin filaments overlap with all available myosin cross-bridges, but not yet reaching the center of the myosin filament Maximal tension Image (4)
B Sarcomere maintains full tension, actin filaments just beginning to overlap each other Full tension Image (3)
A Excessive overlap of actin filaments Reduced contraction strength Image (1)


With further decrease in the length of the sarcomere, there is a rapid decline in the strength of contraction.

questions.text: 58. A man is stuck in a tunnel for 5 days. He is still alive after 5 days without any food. Which metabolic process is the primary source of energy to his brain?
questions.solution:
The primary source of energy to his brain after 5 days of starvation is Ketosis.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl-CoA is converted to ketone bodies to meet the energy needs of the body. Metabolic adaptations during starvation are: 

* The first stage of fasting: The blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they begin to deplete.

* The second stage of fasting: Even before the glycogen stores are depleted, gluconeogenesis is accelerated. The amino acids released from muscle are the major substrate for gluconeogenesis.

* The third stage of fasting:

* Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by an increased glucagon: insulin ratio.

* Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. 

* Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place, which provides acetyl-CoA and subsequently ketone bodies.

* The brain starts utilising ketone bodies from the 3rd day of starvation

* The final stages of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Excessive production of ketone bodies leads to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis and dehydration, unless corrected efficiently, will lead to death.

questions.text: 59. A 3-year old girl presented with difficulty in walking and bowing of legs. She was undernourished and had minimal exposure to the sun. Which programme deals with nutritional deficiency in children below 6 years of age?
questions.solution:
For children below 6 years of age, the programme that deals with nutritional deficiency is the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS).

The scenario in this case points toward rickets due to Vitamin D deficiency which presents as difficulty in walking and bowing of legs with minimal sun exposure and undernutrition.

Integrated child development services was launched in October, 1975, with focus on early childhood services, which consist of supplementary nutrition, immunisation, health check-up, medical referral services, nutrition and health education for women and non-formal education of children upto the age of 6 years. 

The main objectives of the ICDS scheme are:

* Improve the health and nutritional status of children between 0–6 years, pregnant and lactating mothers 

* Reduction in the incidence of their mortality and school dropout 

* Provision of a firm foundation for the proper psychological, physical and social development of the child 

* Enhancement of the maternal education and capacity to look after her health and nutrition and that of her family

* Effective coordination of the policy and implementation among various departments and programmes aimed to promote child development

Other options: 

Option B: Anaemia Mukt Bharat targets iron deficiency anaemia mainly through iron–folic acid supplementation, deworming, and awareness activities. It covers children of 6–59 months, school-going children, adolescents, and women of reproductive age including pregnant and lactating women. Since it focuses on anaemia and multiple age groups, it doesn’t address this child’s condition.

Option C: There is no standalone programme by the name “National Nutritional Deficiency Control Programme.” Instead, this term is sometimes used as an umbrella description for multiple initiatives aimed at controlling specific deficiencies like iodine, vitamin A, and anaemia. It is not a single, targeted scheme for children under six, but rather a collection of separate interventions across age groups. It does not specifically address the child’s rickets or provide comprehensive early childhood nutrition support.

Option D: Mid-Day Meal Scheme, now known as PM Poshan Scheme, provides nutritious meals to improve the nutritional status of children studying in classes I-VIII in eligible schools. It aims to improve school attendance and nutrition, but does not cover pre-school children below six years, so it’s not relevant for the 3-year-old child in this case.

Pearl PM2152: Integrated child development services (ICDS)

  • Tetanus immunization
  • Supplementary nutrition

  • Nutrition and health education

questions.text: 60. Patient presents with cough, stridor, and dyspnea. On examination, there was lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination of the lymph node shows granulomas with giant cells and stellate concretions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as cough, dyspnea, dry eyes, and usually has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies (stellate concretions) and laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.





Other options:

Option A: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) occurs due to inhalational exposure to a number of antigens, causing inflammation of the alveoli and the small airways. The cause of the inflammation is dysregulated Th1 and Th17 immune response (type IV hypersensitivity). Lung biopsy shows the formation of noncaseating granulomas, but they are poorly defined.

Option B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) involves the skin, cardiac and gastrointestinal tract, and peripheral nervous system with associated eosinophilia. Biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltrates and eosinophilic granulomas.

Option C: Tuberculosis has more constitutional symptoms with granulomas showing caseous necrosis, abundant lymphocytes, and acid-fast bacilli.

Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis

questions.text: 61. A female presented with patches in the oral cavity with complaints of burning sensation after taking a drug for 6 months. Symptoms worsened on eating spicy food. Which drug is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Beta blocker is most likely to cause this condition. 

The image shows reticular white patches with erosions in the oral cavity, causing a burning sensation, especially with spicy food. The findings are characteristic of oral lichen planus, and among drugs that can trigger this condition, the most commonly associated drug is a beta blocker.

Lichenoid drug eruption is a type of adverse reaction to certain medications that causes skin or oral lesions resembling lichen planus. The drugs most commonly implicated in lichenoid drug eruptions include antimalarials, gold, NSAIDs, penicillamine, thiazide diuretics, mercury amalgam, ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, lithium, methyldopa, and other sulfonylureas. Out of the given options, beta blockers are considered one of the most potent generators for the drug-induced forms of lichen planus, compared to lithium (Option B). 

Lichen planus-like drug reactions usually develop months or even years after starting the medication. They manifest as shiny purple papules or plaques, sometimes with the characteristic Wickham’s striae (thin white lines on their surface), and can involve mucous membranes. Diagnosis relies on skin biopsy, which typically shows hyperkeratosis, hypergranulosis, saw-tooth acanthosis, and a band-like infiltrate in the upper dermis. Features that suggest a drug-related cause include necrotic keratinocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils.

Treatment centers on discontinuing the offending drug, which is crucial for resolution. Most cases improve with topical corticosteroids, while oral corticosteroids may be necessary for extensive or severe eruptions. Symptoms generally resolve within weeks to months after stopping the drug. 

Other options:

Option C: Fluconazole is an antifungal, used to treat oral candidiasis and other fungal infections. It does not typically cause lichenoid drug eruption

Option D: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone and can cause tendon ruptures, joint pain, gastrointestinal upset, and neurological side effects. Oral lichenoid lesions are not a well-known adverse effect.

questions.text: 62. A 20-year-old patient presented with salt craving, skin pigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of salt craving, skin pigmentation, along with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency, as seen in Addison's disease.

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis. It may also result from the destruction of the adrenal cortex due to hemorrhage, infection, or infiltration.

The symptoms of adrenal insufficiency are as follows:

* Glucocorticoid deficiency leads to:

* Fatigue, lack of energy

* Weight loss, anorexia

* Myalgia

* Hypoglycemia 

* Low blood pressure, postural hypotension

* Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to:

* Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

* Dizziness, postural hypotension

* Low blood pressure, postural hypotension

* Hyponatremia

* Hyperkalemia

* Adrenal androgen deficiency leads to dry and itchy skin, loss of libido 

* The hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas results from excess ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) secretion, which occurs in response to decreased adrenal cortical hormones.

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is confirmed using the short cosyntropin test. Acute adrenal insufficiency requires immediate management with intravenous saline and close cardiac monitoring. Treatment primarily involves glucocorticoid replacement, with mineralocorticoid therapy added in cases of primary adrenal insufficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin, brittle skin with easy bruising, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

Option C: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. It most commonly presents as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating, along with hypertension.

Option D: Conn syndrome refers to primary hyperaldosteronism. It usually results from an aldosterone-secreting adenoma. Excess aldosterone leads to increased sodium and water retention and potassium excretion, resulting in hypokalemia, volume expansion, and hypertension.

Pearl PM1419: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

* Anatomical destruction of gland

* Autoimmune (Addison's disease)

* Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)

* Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi

* Surgical removal

* Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)

* Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis

* Metastatic carcinoma

* Cytotoxic agents – mitotane

* Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole

* Congenital adrenal hypoplasia

* Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)

* Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)

* X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)

* Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

* Neoplasm

* Infiltration (sarcoidosis)

* Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

* By endogenous steroids from tumor

* By exogenous steroids

questions.text: 63. A 21-year-old female presents with amnesia for an event that occurred 2 weeks ago (the death of her father in an RTA, which she witnessed). She reports having flashbacks of the event repeatedly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Acute stress disorder.

Acute stress disorder is characterised by a relationship between an exceptional stressor (such as the death of a loved one, natural catastrophe, accident, or rape) and the onset of symptoms. It is characterised by the development of transient emotional, somatic, cognitive, or behavioural symptoms as a result of exposure to an extremely threatening or horrific nature. 

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and acute stress disorder both present with the same set of symptoms:

* Intrusive symptoms such as recurrent nightmares and flashbacks of the event, psychological distress due to stimuli that are reminders of prior trauma

* Avoidance of external reminders of trauma

* Negative mood or cognition related to the trauma

* Altered level of arousal, such as sleep disturbances and hypervigilance

A diagnosis of PTSD is made if these symptoms present ≥1 month following the traumatic event. If these symptoms are present for a duration of up to 1 month, then a diagnosis of acute stress disorder is made.

Pearl PM2336: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive


Pearl PM0378: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 


ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

* Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Depersonalization-Derealization disorder

* Dissociative Amnesia

* Trance Disorder

* Possession Trance Disorder

* Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder

* Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: 64. A 12-year-old child with chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with bowing of legs. He also had minimal sun exposure. Laboratory investigations reveal Serum Calcium: 7 mg/dL, Serum Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL (elevated), Alkaline Phosphatase: 370 mg/dl (elevated), and low 25(OH) Vitamin D levels. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
In this case, the most appropriate management is calcium and vitamin D supplementation.

The child with CKD has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, low vitamin D levels, and clinical signs of renal rickets such as bowing of the legs. The primary problem is reduced activation of vitamin D by the diseased kidneys, which leads to poor calcium absorption and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
