Supplementing with calcium directly corrects the hypocalcemia, while giving active forms of vitamin D (calcitriol/alfacalcidol) improves intestinal calcium absorption, suppresses parathyroid overactivity, and helps in bone mineralisation. Together, calcium and vitamin D address the core abnormalities driving the bone disease in CKD.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) refers to kidney damage that persists for at least three months, involving structural or functional abnormalities of the kidneys, which may occur with or without a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Disturbances in calcium and phosphate metabolism, impaired renal production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, chronic acidosis, and secondary hyperparathyroidism can lead to bone complications, collectively known as CKD-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD). Factors such as poor appetite, malnutrition, and skeletal abnormalities also contribute to impaired growth.

At the initial stage, management focuses on ensuring adequate nutrition and slowing the progression of kidney failure. Although the kidneys can regulate potassium levels until the later stages, their ability to quickly excrete a potassium load is diminished, so foods high in potassium should be limited. Calcium supplementation is typically provided as calcium carbonate or calcium acetate. Phosphate consumption is reduced by limiting the intake of dairy products. Phosphate binders are given if the patient is not responding to dietary restriction of phosphate (Options A and C). Supplementation with vitamins such as thiamine, riboflavin, folic acid, pyridoxine, and B12, along with vitamin D, is also recommended.

As the disease advances, addressing complications becomes necessary, and kidney replacement therapy, including hemodialysis or transplantation, may then be required (Option D).

questions.text: 65. Which of the following is used for syndromic diagnosis of infected cases like meningitis?
questions.solution:
Multiplex PCR can be used for syndromic diagnosis of infected cases like meningitis.

A syndromic diagnosis is a method of diagnosing infectious diseases that uses a single test to screen for multiple pathogens that could be causing a specific set of symptoms. 

Multiplex PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a variation of the standard PCR technique that allows simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single reaction. It uses more than one set of primers (specific to different target sequences) to amplify different DNA fragments at the same time. 

Other options:

Option A: Uniplex PCR is performed for the detection of each microorganism individually, targeting the conserved region in each bacterial genome. It is less effective than Multiplex PCR. 

Option B: Nested PCR involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification, and the second set of primers is used to amplify a particular region within the first target sequence. This ensures specificity. Used in GeneXpert to detect Mycobacterium TB and resistance to rifampicin.

Option C: RT PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesise a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA, and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR. Unlike conventional PCR, which can only amplify DNA, this one can even amplify RNA. It is used to detect H1N1 from a Nasopharyngeal swab.

questions.text: 66. The image shows a congenital cardiac defect. Abnormal development of which arch artery leads to this defect?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th aortic arch.

Usually, in term infants, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close results in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

PDA usually presents with a hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

In a majority of cases, PDA closes spontaneously. If spontaneous closure fails to occur, COX inhibitors like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be used. Surgical ligation is indicated in case of contraindications to medical management or failure of the same.

Other options

Option A: The 4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. 

Option B: The 4th left aortic arch gives rise to the arch of the aorta. Defects involving the 4th left aortic arch could cause a variety of aortic arch anomalies, such as interruption of the aortic arch, but not PDA.

Option C: The 6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery.

Pearl PM0894: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.



The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: 67. A new community based health initiative is designed to reduce neonatal sepsis. In a community, 20 PHCs follow standard care and 20 are designated to implement the initiative. What type of study design is this?
questions.solution:
The given scenario described the study design of a cluster randomised controlled trial.

This is a cluster randomised controlled trial because the unit of allocation in this study is not the individual patient but the primary health centre (PHC), which acts as a cluster. Instead of randomly assigning each newborn or mother individually, the researchers assign entire PHCs to either the intervention (new community-based initiative to reduce neonatal sepsis) or the control (standard care) group.

Other options:

Option A: This is not a quasi-experimental study because in quasi-experimental designs there is no true random allocation of participants or groups. In the given scenario, the 20 PHCs implementing the intervention and the 20 PHCs following standard care are assigned in a way that strongly suggests randomisation at the cluster level, which rules out a quasi-experimental approach.

Option C: This is not a case-control study because it doesn’t start with outcomes and look back for exposures. Instead, it begins with an intervention and follows forward.

Option D: This is not a cross-sectional study because it is not based on a single examination of a cross-section of the population at one point in time, but it involves an intervention with follow-up over time.

Pearl PM1146: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

* In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.

* Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.



2. Stratified random sampling

* In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

* For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.



3. Cluster sampling

* In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.

* In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.

* This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.

* This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.

* Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.

* Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.



4. Systematic random sampling

* In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.

* For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text:
68. A female patient with a known case of bronchial asthma is on levosalbutamol and Ipratropium bromide metered-dose inhalers. She now reports frequent nocturnal symptoms, including wheezing and breathlessness that wake her up several times a week. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

LABA - Long-Acting Beta-Agonist
questions.solution:
Since the patient has frequent nocturnal symptoms with wheezing and breathlessness that wake her up several times a week, the most appropriate next step of management is the addition of Long-Acting Beta-Agonist (LABA) and inhaled corticosteroid (ICS).

Drugs used in the treatment of bronchial asthma:

Bronchodilators

* Beta-2 sympathomimetics: Salmeterol, Formoterol

* Methylxanthines: Theophylline, Aminophylline

* Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide

Anti-inflammatory

* Corticosteroids (Inhalational): Beclomethasone, Budesonide, Fluticasone

* Corticosteroids (Systemic): Prednisolone, Hydrocortisone

* Mast cell stabilizers: Sodium cromoglycate, Ketotifen

* Leukotriene antagonists: Montelukast, Zafirlukast

* anti-IgE - Omalizumab

* anti-IL5 - Mepolizumab, Reslizumab

* anti-IL4 receptor - Dupilumab

* anti-TSLP (thymic stromal lymphopoietin) - Tezepelumab

As per GINA guidelines, ICS/Formoterol (LABA) is used as reliever therapy in all steps of asthma therapy. A stepwise approach is used for the treatment of Asthma, as shown in the image below.



Important Update - According to GINA 2019, Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) have no role in treating acute exacerbations. Even though SABA provides short-term relief of symptoms, there is strong evidence that SABA-only treatment increases the risk of exacerbations. GINA now recommends that symptom-driven (in mild asthma), a daily dose of ICS (inhaled corticosteroids) containing treatment be used to reduce the risk of serious exacerbations. This is said to be the most important change in asthma management in 30 years.

questions.text: 69. A patient presents with anaemia, ataxia and neuropathy and a positive Romberg sign. Lab investigations reveal elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Production of which of the following amino acids could be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with anaemia, ataxia, neuropathy, positive Romberg sign, with lab investigations revealing elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Production of Methionine will be affected in this patient.

There are 2 enzymes dependent on vitamin B12:

* Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase

* Methionine synthase

The conversion of Homocysteine to Methionine requires Methionine synthase. A deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to impairment of methionine synthase and also causes accumulation of homocysteine.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase catalyses the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, which is vitamin B12 dependent. When vitamin B12 is deficient, there is an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid (diagnostic test for Vitamin B12 deficiency).



Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration. Patients present with megaloblastic anaemia, ataxia, positive Romberg sign, peripheral neuropathy and positive Babinski sign.

Pearl PM1153: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level


Pearl PM2304: Homocystinuria



The concept for treatment:

* Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.

* As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text:
70. A patient is newly diagnosed with HIV and has had fever for 2 weeks with cough and dyspnea. Chest X-Ray showed cavitatory lesions in the upper lobe. The patient is to be started on treatment. What is the appropriate strategy?

CD4 cells = 150/μL

choices.text: Start ART after completing Anti-TB therapy
Start Anti-TB therapy after 2 weeks of ART
Start ART after 2 weeks of Anti-TB therapy
Start both ART and Anti-TB therapy immediately

questions.solution:
The most appropriate strategy for this patient is starting ART after 2 weeks of anti-TB therapy.

In a patient with HIV and TB, start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). In case of TB meningitis, ART initiation is delayed by at least 4 weeks.

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intrathoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

However, in patients with CD4 <50/μL, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore, ART should be started as early as possible.

Pearl PM2302: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: 71. An intern was assisting a delivery, and the resident asked the intern to comment on the umbilical cord. What is the normal vasculature of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
The normal umbilical cord contains two umbilical arteries with one large vein.

A normal umbilical cord consists of Wharton's jelly, which is a mesodermal connective tissue, and is covered by the amnion. It contains the following structures:

* 1 umbilical vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the foetus,

* 2 umbilical arteries  that carry deoxygenated blood from the foetus to the placenta,

* Remnants of the yolk sac and allantois.

Around 1 in 200 newborns have only a single umbilical artery. These infants have increased chances of having cardiac and other vascular defects.

The following shows the normal vasculature of the umbilical cord:

questions.text: 72. A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presented with secondary amenorrhoea for 1 year. She had elevated gonadotropic hormones (FSH 36 IU/L, LH 56 IU/L) and decreased AMH (0.05 ng). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is premature ovarian insufficiency, because the patient has secondary amenorrhoea with high FSH and LH (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) and very low AMH, indicating depleted ovarian reserve.

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is defined as loss of oocytes and the surrounding support cells prior to age 40 years. The diagnosis is determined by two serum FSH levels that measure greater than a threshold range of 30 to 40 mIU/mL and are obtained at least 1 month apart. This definition distinguishes POI from the physiologic loss of ovarian function, which occurs with normal menopause.

AMH is secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testis and granulosa cells in the ovary. In males, it inhibits the development of the Mullerian system and its absence can result in hermaphroditism. In the female, it helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation.

The estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in an infertile woman and a woman with secondary amenorrhoea. They strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. This makes AMH the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. The AMH values and their interpretation are given below:

* Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL

* Poor ovarian reserve : <1 ng/mL

* PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

The other indicator of ovarian reserve is FSH levels measured in the early follicular phase (between day 2 and day 4 of the menstrual cycle). A value of >10 mIU/mL may indicate significant loss of ovarian reserve.

Other options:

Option A: PCOS typically shows LH levels raised over 10 IU/mL and normal FSH, hence ruling it out.

Option B: Hyperprolactinaemia would cause amenorrhoea, but usually with high prolactin and suppressed gonadotropins, not elevated FSH/LH.

Option C: Hyperthyroidism can cause menstrual irregularity, but would not explain high FSH/LH with low AMH.

questions.text: 73. An old-age home resident's son, who is a farmer, brought food for all the residents. Most of them presented with abdominal pain and bloody stool soon after. On stool examination, polymorphonuclear cells and Gram-negative rods were noted. On epidemiological investigation, it was found that all the affected residents had drunk the same milk. What is the likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of consumption of milk leading to abdominal pain, bloody stool, and stool examination showing polymorphonuclear cells with gram-negative rods suggests that the likely causative organism is Campylobacter jejuni.

Campylobacter species cause zoonotic infections. Campylobacter jejuni can cause inflammatory diarrhoea on consumption of raw milk and undercooked poultry. It leads to gastroenteritis with acute onset of crampy abdominal pain, profuse bloody diarrhoea, headache, malaise, and fever. These organisms are usually present as commensal bacteria in the gastrointestinal tracts of various wild or domesticated animals. Poultry, cattle, and sheep are common reservoir hosts of Campylobacter jejuni.

C. jejuni is a curved, comma-shaped or S-shaped, gram-negative rod that does not produce spores (as shown in the image below). The stool is preferred to isolate Campylobacter in patients with gastroenteritis. It shows darting motility on dark-field microscopy. Skirrow's medium is the selective medium.



Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive organism that causes vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal cramps due to consumption of ham, poultry, salad, mayonnaise, pastries and dairy products.

Option B: C. perfringens is a gram-positive organism that causes diarrhoea and abdominal cramps due to consumption of beef, poultry, and legumes.

Option C: V. parahemolyticus is a gram-negative organism that causes dysentery due to the consumption of raw or undercooked shellfish, particularly oysters.

Pearl PM2350: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: 74. A malignant neck swelling was surgically removed from a patient, shown in the image below. What will the patient likely present with 2-3 days after the procedure?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests total thyroidectomy, and the patient is likely to present with carpopedal spasm 2-3 days after the procedure.

Thyroid surgery, particularly total thyroidectomy with a concomitant central neck dissection, is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism. There is transient hypocalcemia due to ischemia of the parathyroid glands, but permanent hypoparathyroidism is rare. Hypoparathyroidism can also occur after parathyroid surgery.

Hypoparathyroidism results in hypocalcemia. Acute hypocalcemia leads to decreased ionised calcium and increased neuromuscular excitability. Patients initially experience numbness in the circumoral and fingertip areas along with a tingling sensation. 

Other symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

* Chvostek sign: contraction of facial muscles that is elicited by tapping on the facial nerve anterior to the ear

* Trousseau's sign: carpopedal spasm that is elicited by occluding blood flow to the forearm with a blood pressure cuff for 2–3 minutes

* Mental symptoms like anxiety, confusion, and depression

* Laryngeal stridor

* Convulsions

Intravenous calcium infusion is rarely required and most patients with post-operative hypocalcemia can be treated with oral calcium and vitamin D supplements. 

Other options:

Option A: Deviation of the angle of the mouth is seen in injury of the marginal mandibular nerve and facial nerve palsy. 

Option B: Hoarseness of voice occurs in laryngeal disorders like tumours and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Option D: Migratory thrombophlebitis occurs in vascular diseases such as Buerger's disease.

questions.text: 75. A patient who had undergone knee replacement surgery 7 days back, now presents with complaints of sudden shortness of breath and tachycardia. What is the next appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of sudden shortness of breath, tachycardia, after knee replacement surgery 7 days back suggests the probable diagnosis to be pulmonary embolism. The next appropriate diagnostic test is CT pulmonary angiography.

Pulmonary embolism (PE) should be suspected in a patient who complains of sudden breathlessness and hemoptysis after prolonged immobilisation. Well's point score helps to estimate the clinical likelihood of PE. 

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It can provide exquisite detail, with ≤1 mm of resolution during a short breath-hold. It also helps to visualise the chambers of the heart. In patients who do not have a pulmonary embolism, it can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.



Other options:

Option A: D-dimer rises in PE because of the breakdown of fibrin by plasmin. Normal levels of D-dimer rule out the possibility of PE, but it is not specific. D-dimer levels also increase in patients with myocardial infarction, pneumonia, sepsis, cancer, postoperative state, and those in the second or third trimester of pregnancy.

Option B: Chest X-ray can be normal in PE, and hence it is not very reliable.

Option D: Ventilation/Perfusion scan has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Small particulate aggregates of albumin labelled with a gamma-emitting radionuclide are injected intravenously and are trapped in the pulmonary capillary bed. The perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

Pearl PM2392: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1


Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6


Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 


 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

* Age <50 years

* Heart rate <100 bpm

* SpO2 ≥95%

* No unilateral leg swelling

* No hemoptysis

* No recent trauma or surgery

* No history of venous thromboembolism

* No use of hormonal therapy.

Pearl PM0584: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.



Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.



Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.



Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text:
76. A patient came with a history of dyspnea, fatigue, and palpitations for 6 months. He gave a history of acute rheumatic fever in childhood. On examination, JVP was elevated, irregularly irregular pulse, hepatomegaly, and pedal edema were present. There was a left parasternal heave. On auscultation, opening snap with MDM murmur was present. All are true in this case except:

RHF - Right Heart Failure MDM - Mid Diastolic Murmur

choices.text: Presystolic accentuation of MDM is a hallmark of this condition
Increased risk of stroke is present

questions.solution:
All of the given statements are true except that presystolic accentuation of MDM is a hallmark of this condition.

The given clinical features are consistent with atrial fibrillation in a patient with mitral stenosis. Pre-systolic accentuation of the mid-diastolic murmur that is characteristically seen in mitral stenosis is absent in the case of Atrial Fibrillation.

On auscultating a patient with mitral stenosis, a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation and an opening snap is typically heard. The presystolic accentuation is due to the atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenosed mitral valve. The presystolic accentuation disappears and marks the setting in of atrial fibrillation. The absence of an atrial kick corresponds to the absence of a fourth heart sound.

The list of findings consistent with atrial fibrillation is as follows:

* Absent p wave on ECG 

* Absent a wave (option B) on JVP

* Absent S4 (fourth heart sound) on auscultation

* Absent presystolic accentuation in the patient with mitral stenosis on auscultation

In addition, elevated left atrial pressure in mitral stenosis leads to pulmonary venous hypertension, increased afterload on the right ventricle, and eventual right heart failure (option A). 

Furthermore, atrial fibrillation causes irregular and uncoordinated atrial contractions, resulting in stasis of blood in the atria. This predisposes to thrombus formation, which can embolize and cause ischemic stroke; hence, the patient had an increased risk for stroke (option D).

questions.text: 77. A schizophrenic patient responding well on haloperidol, for the past 2 years, presented with orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform, tic-like movements and possible dystonia. What is the probable diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a schizophrenic patient responding well to haloperidol for the past 2 years, presenting with orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform, tic-like movements, and possible dystonia, suggests the probable diagnosis to be Tardive dyskinesia, which is treated with Valbenazine.

Tardive dyskinesia occurs due to dopaminergic (D2) receptor supersensitivity. It presents with oro-facial dyskinesia after months to years of treatment with anti-psychotics. It can be treated with VMAT-2 inhibitors, such as Valbenazine and Deutetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option B: Acute dystonia is characterised by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back. It occurs within 1-5 days of the intake of antipsychotics

Option C: Akathisia consists of motor restlessness and occurs within 5-60 days of the intake of antipsychotics. 

Option D: Oral tremor is seen in Rabbit syndrome. Rabbit syndrome is an antipsychotic-induced rhythmic motion of the mouth/lips resembling the chewing movements of a rabbit. It occurs months to years after the intake of antipsychotics and is treated with Antiparkinsonian drugs.

Pearl PM0479: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: 78. A primigravida was prescribed Pritchard's regimen to manage pre-eclampsia. What is the total loading dose of magnesium sulphate given?
questions.solution:
14 g is the total loading dose of magnesium sulphate given in Pritchard's regimen to manage pre-eclampsia.

Magnesium sulphate is used to manage severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. It acts as a membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector. It also reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine and blocks neuronal calcium influx.

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion


Repeat injections are given only if the knee jerks are present, urine output exceeds 30 mL/h and the respiration rate is more than 12/minute. The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4-7 mEq/L.

Magnesium sulphate is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery, whichever is later. For recurrence of fits, a further 2 g IV bolus is given over 5 minutes in the above regimens. If the patient seizes, despite magnesium therapy, midazolam 1-2 mg IV is given. 

Magnesium toxicity manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, altered cardiac conduction and cardiac arrest. Calcium gluconate is the antidote to cardiac toxicity due to hypermagnesemia.

questions.text: 79. A patient presents with morning stiffness and tests positive for anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following histological features is most characteristic of the underlying disease?

choices.text: Basophilic deposition in the synovial cavity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with morning stiffness and anti-CCP antibody positivity suggests Rheumatoid Arthritis. This condition is characteristically associated with pannus formation due to synovial hypertrophy.

Histopathology of Rheumatoid Arthritis shows the presence of pannus, which consists of macrophages, fibroblast-like synovial cells, and inflammatory cells. Its formation over the cartilage results from synovial proliferation and hyperplasia.

Histopathological findings in Rheumatoid Arthritis include:

* Synovial hyperplasia and proliferation

* Dense inflammatory infiltrates of CD4+ T cells, B cells, plasma cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages

* Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis

* Fibrinopurulent exudate on synovial and joint surfaces

* Osteoclastic activity leading to bone erosion and subchondral cyst formation

* Pannus formation

As the disease advances, pannus bridges opposing bony surfaces, leading to cartilage destruction and eventually fibrous ankylosis.

Other Options:

Option B: Basophilic deposition in the synovial cavity occurs in Calcium Pyrophosphate Crystal Deposition Disease (Pseudogout).

Option C: Cartilage erosion with osteophyte formation is seen in Osteoarthritis.

Option D: Tophi with monosodium urate crystals are characteristic of Gout.

questions.text: 80. Caspases are involved in which of the following types of programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Caspases are involved in Pyroptosis and Apoptosis.

Pyroptosis is a form of cell death driven by the release of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1. When cytoplasmic innate immune receptors detect microbial components inside cells, they trigger the formation of a multiprotein complex called the inflammasome.

The inflammasome activates caspase-1, which in turn promotes the release of active IL-1. Caspases 4 and 5 can also contribute to this cell death. Unlike apoptosis, pyroptosis is marked by the release of inflammatory molecules.

Apoptosis involves both intrinsic (mitochondrial) and extrinsic (death receptor) pathways, which converge to activate a caspase cascade. The caspases involved in apoptosis include initiator caspases (8, 9 & 10) and executioner caspases (3, 6, & 7). The following image depicts the apoptotic pathway:



Necroptosis is a caspase-independent, programmed form of necrosis. It combines features of necrosis (ATP depletion, swelling, membrane rupture) with programmed regulation. It involves two kinases called receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 and 3 (RIPK1 and RIPK3)

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent pathway driven by lipid peroxidation. This disrupts membrane integrity and leads to cell death resembling necrosis.

questions.text: 81. A 30-year-old male reports that whenever he is outside, the birds communicate to him through flapping of wings and chirping. He believes that God sends him messages through the birds, guiding him to safety. These features are characteristic of :
questions.solution:
These features are characteristic of Delusional perception.

Delusional perception means a normal perception that has been given a private and illogical meaning. It is a first-rank symptom of Schizophrenia.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

* Hallucination:

*

* First-person hallucination 

* Second-person hallucination (voices directly addressing the patient) 

* Third-person hallucination (voices speaking about the patient)

* Thought phenomenon: 

*

* Thought withdrawal

* Thought insertion

* Thought broadcasting

* Made phenomenon:

*

* Made affect

* Made impulses or drives 

* Made volitional acts 

* Delusional perception

* Somatic passivity

Other options:

Option B: A sudden delusional idea is a false, fixed belief about an idea.

Option C: Visual hallucinations is a visual perception of something that is not actually there.

Option D: Delusional memory is a false, fixed belief about a memory.

questions.text: 82. The resident is performing a manoeuvre in the labour room. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure shown is controlled cord traction.

In the third stage of labour, the placenta is expected to be delivered spontaneously soon following the delivery of the baby. If the placenta is not delivered thereafter, it should be delivered forthwith by controlled cord traction (Brandt-Andrews) technique after clamping the cord while the uterus still remains contracted.

In controlled cord traction (modified Brandt-Andrews method), the palmar surface of the fingers of the left hand is placed above the symphysis pubis, approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment. The body of the uterus is pushed upward and backwards, towards the umbilicus, while with the right hand steady tension is given in downward and backwards direction, holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus. The procedure is to be adopted only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

The third stage of labour includes separation, descent, and expulsion of the placenta with its membranes. According to WHO guidelines, active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) has the following components:

* Administration of uterotonics within 1 min of delivery.

* Controlled cord traction and expulsion of the placenta.

* Delayed cord clamping for a minimum of 1-3 minutes to reduce anemia in the fetus.

* Intermittent assessment of the uterine tone for early detection of atony.

questions.text: 83. Group A streptococci is one of the most common organism causing pharyngitis in children. What component of the organism helps it adhere to fibronectin of the host cell?
questions.solution:
Lipoteichoic acid helps streptococci adhere to the fibronectin of the host cell.

Lipoteichoic acid helps in adhesion to pharyngeal epithelial cells, to other host cells and proteins such as fibronectin. Fibronectin acts as the ligand for binding Lipoteichoic acid.

Streptococcus pyogenes is classified under Lancefield’s group A Streptococcus (GAS). Virulence factors of Group A Streptococci are:

* Cell Wall Antigens

* Lipoteichoic acid

* C-carbohydrate antigens

* M protein- principal virulence factor of group A Streptococcus

* Fimbriae and F factor (fibronectin binding protein)

* M protein-associated protein (opacity factor)

* Capsule

* Toxins- Hemolysins such as streptolysin-O and streptolysin-S 

* Enzymes- like Streptokinase (Fibrinolysin), Streptodornase (DNase) and Hyaluronidase (spreading factor)



Other options:

Option A: Flagella are not present in Group A streptococci.

Option B: Lipoprotein is present in the cell wall of Group A streptococci. 

Option C: Capsule is composed of hyaluronic acid. It is antiphagocytic, but not antigenic. It helps group A streptococci to colonise the pharynx by binding to CD44, a hyaluronic acid-binding protein that is expressed on epithelial cells.

questions.text: 84. As per population strategy, what is the recommended dietary reduction of cholesterol to prevent coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary reduction of cholesterol to prevent coronary heart disease (CHD) is to reduce below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day.

Population strategy is based on a mass approach, focusing mainly on the control of underlying causes in whole populations. This approach is based on the principle that small changes in risk factor levels in total population can achieve the biggest reduction in mortality. 

Dietary changes under the population strategy in the prevention of CHD:

* Reduction of the fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake

* Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake

* A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day

* Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes)

* Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: 85. A 30-year-old female notices weakness in her right hand and difficulty while kneading dough. On examination, right arm tone and power are decreased, and reflexes are sluggish. What is the site of the lesion?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule
Right corticospinal tract in cervical cord
Anterior horn cell of the cervical spinal cord

questions.solution:
As per the given clinical findings, the site of the lesion is the anterior horn cell of the cervical spinal cord.

The given clinical findings, such as weakness in the hand, hypotonia, decreased power, and sluggish reflexes, are indicative of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion. Hence, the most likely site of lesion in this patient is the anterior horn cell of the cervical spinal cord.

LMN weakness occurs due to disorders affecting the lower motor neurons in the brainstem, the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, or due to dysfunction of their axons.

In contrast, upper motor neuron (UMN) weakness results from lesions affecting the upper motor neurons or their descending pathways in the spinal cord. This is characterized by increased muscle tone with spasticity, hyperactive reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign.

Lesions at the following sites can lead to UMN palsy:

* Motor cortex (precentral gyrus) - contralateral weakness

* Posterior limb of internal capsule - contralateral hemiparesis (option A)

* Brainstem (pons, medullary pyramid) - contralateral weakness with or without cranial nerve deficits (option D)

* Corticospinal tract in the spinal cord - ipsilateral spastic paresis below the lesion (option B)

Pearl PM2510: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: 86. A 68-year-old female with breast cancer with metastasis presented with breathlessness and poor health. The patient is awake and anxious. The oncology team believes that aggressive chemotherapy and radiotherapy will not be helpful. However, her daughter insists on 'trying everything', including ICU stay and mechanical ventilation. How should a doctor handle such a scenario?

choices.text: Convene a family meeting to discuss care goals and clarify the patient's preferences
Shift to ICU and start aggressive treatment
Explain no futher treatment is possible and discharge the patient to hospice
Start a placebo therapy to relieve anxiety

questions.solution:
In this case, the best way to manage the situation is to convene a family meeting to discuss care goals and clarify the patient's preferences.

Here, the patient is suffering from an advanced illness with a poor prognosis. The patient and her family are facing decisions regarding aggressive interventions such as chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and mechanical ventilation.

The recommended approach is to organize an early and structured family meeting. During this meeting, the patient's preferences should be identified, and goals should be set in collaboration with the family. This helps to reduce unrealistic expectations and may lead to shorter ICU stays when the outcome is likely to be poor. 

A 7-step protocol can be followed to decide upon the patient’s goals for care, ensuring high-quality palliative and end-of-life care:

* Collect Comprehensive Information: Make sure all medical details are complete, accurate, and clearly communicated to the patient, family, and healthcare team.

* Understand Patient and Family Hopes: Explore the hopes of the patient and family, and also identify the outcomes that are realistic and achievable.

* Present All Care Options: Share every possible intervention, explaining the benefits, limitations, and potential outcomes of each.

* Respond with Empathy: Support the patient and family emotionally as they process the situation and adjust expectations.

* Formulate a Practical Plan: Create a care plan that focuses on attaining the realistic goals aligned with the patient’s values.

* Implement the Plan: Ensure the plan is carried out consistently, coordinating with all members of the care team.

* Review and Reassess Regularly: Revisit the plan during each encounter to determine whether goals need adjustment based on the patient’s evolving condition or preferences.

questions.text: 87. A neonate was screened and was found to have congenital hypothyroidism. T3 and T4 levels were decreased, and there was no radioactive tracer uptake but thyroid gland was normal on USG. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause is defect in iodine transport.

The neonate has low T3 and T4, a structurally normal thyroid gland on ultrasound, but no radioactive tracer uptake. For radioactive iodine to be taken up by the thyroid, the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) must transport iodine into the gland. If this transport mechanism is defective, the thyroid gland will appear normal anatomically but will not concentrate iodine, leading to absent tracer uptake and hypothyroidism.

The steps of synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones are shown below:



Other options:

Option A: Iodine deficiency is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism worldwide, and maternal iodine intake is critical during pregnancy for fetal thyroid function. However, in iodine deficiency, the thyroid gland typically increases its trapping activity, so tracer uptake would be high rather than absent.

Option C: In thyroid agenesis, the thyroid is absent and the ultrasound would not show a normal gland. Since the gland is present, this is ruled out. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism. In one-third of cases of dysgenesis, no thyroid tissue is present, known as thyroid agenesis.

Option D: Dyshormonogenesis refers to defects in hormone synthesis after iodine is already taken up. Because increased TSH stimulation has a trophic effect on thyroid follicular cells, a goiter is often present. In such cases, the tracer uptake is usually increased, not absent, because the gland tries to compensate.

questions.text: 88. Indication of the given procedure
questions.solution:
The given image shows an Intracorneal stromal ring segment that is used in the treatment of Keratoconus.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as a characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism.

Intracorneal stromal ring segment helps to flatten the cornea, improves vision and facilitates contact lens tolerance in advanced cases of keratoconus.

Other treatment methods for keratoconus are:

* Spectacle correction

* Rigid gas-permeable contact lens

* Corneal collagen cross-linking - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitise the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light

* Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty and penetrating keratoplasty

Pearl PM2451: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

* Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze  Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

* Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.

* Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.

* Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.

* Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.

* Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.

* Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

* Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.

* Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Pearl PM0783: Vogt's striae



The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

* Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

* It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.

* It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.

* The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: 89. What is Zasko phenomenon?

choices.text: Gaping of wound after a stab injury
Seepage of blood through wounds after death

questions.solution:
Zasko’s phenomenon is the tendon reflex occurring after death.

Zasko’s phenomenon or Tendon reaction is the upward movement of the patella because of the contraction of the entire muscle of quadriceps muscle.

It is seen up to 1 to 2 hrs after death. It is elicited by striking the lower third of the quadriceps femoris muscle 10 cm above the patella with a reflex hammer.

questions.text: 90. A 2-year-old was brought to the ED following choking on a peanut. The child was unresponsive. What is the next step for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
If a choking child is brought to the hospital in an unresponsive state, immediately activate the hospital’s emergency response system and start CPR without delay, beginning with chest compressions.

When the choking child becomes unresponsive, CPR should be started with 30 chest compressions, followed by an airway examination to identify the presence of a foreign body. Two rescue breaths should be attempted. If the airway obstruction is still not relieved, then CPR should be restarted and continued until the airway obstruction is relieved.

For an infant or child with a foreign body obstruction, the next step depends on the severity and consciousness of the patient:

Group Severity Consciousness Recommendation
Child Mild Conscious Let the child cough to clear the airway while watching for signs of a severe obstruction
Child Severe Conscious Give abdominal thrusts (option B) repeatedly until the object comes out or the child becomes unresponsive
Infant Severe Conscious Give repeated cycles of 5 back slaps (option A) followed by 5 chest thrusts until the object is removed or the child becomes unresponsive
Infant/ Child Severe Unresponsive

Begin CPR with chest compressions (option D).

If the emergency response has not been activated, do so after 2 minutes of CPR.

When opening the airway to give breaths, remove any foreign object that you can see.

Blind finger sweeping may be hazardous as it can push the object further down the airway.


During laryngoscopy, if the foreign body is visible above the vocal cords, an attempt should be made to remove it with Magill forceps. If the foreign body is below the vocal cords, an attempt should be made to push the foreign body more distally to reestablish a patent airway. This will allow for rescue oxygenation and ventilation while preparing for more definitive management.

Demonstration of back slaps in an Infant:



Demonstration of chest thrusts in an Infant:



Other options:

Option C: Endotracheal intubation is an advanced intervention and is not part of routine first-line management.

questions.text: 91. A 55-year-old patient presents with shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following- pH: 7.22, PaCO₂: 66 mmHg, PaO₂: 45 mmHg, HCO₃⁻: 26 mEq/L. What is the most likely acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The most likely acid-base disorder in the patient is Respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.22 (normal: 7.35-7.45) signifies acidosis.

Step 2: An elevated pCO2 of 66 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) along with a low pH signifies respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: The plasma HCO3- is 26 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). This high HCO3- is due to compensation.

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula: Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 X ΔpCO2 (the patient has an acute onset of dyspnoea, hence this is taken as acute respiratory acidosis) Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 X (66 - 40) = 2.6 mEq/L (40 mmHg is the optimal value for pCO2) Expected HCO3- = 24 + 2.6 = 26.6 mEq/L (24 mmHg is the optimal value for HCO3-)

HCO3- measured is 26 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value), indicating that compensation is partial.

Thus, the ABG shows respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation.

Pearl PM1521: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis


Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: 92. A young man traveled from Delhi to Leh, which is at 3700 m above sea level and started to experience dizziness, nausea, discomfort, and headache. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the symptoms?

choices.text: Increased HCO₃⁻ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Decreased pO₂ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Increased H⁺ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Decreased pO₂ causing cerebral vasoconstriction leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space

questions.solution:
The symptoms experienced by the patient can be explained by decreased pO₂, causing cerebral vasodilation, leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space.

The patient's presentation is characteristic of acute mountain sickness (AMS), which is a neurological condition that appears 6-12 hours after going to a high altitude, resulting from reduced pO2. AMS is likely to be seen after an ascent to more than 2500 metres, but can also be seen at lower altitudes (1500-2500 m). It is mainly diagnosed based on symptoms such as headache, nausea, tiredness (discomfort), and dizziness, since there are usually very few physical signs. 

The low pO₂ leads to hypoxic cerebral vasodilation, which increases cerebral blood flow and raises capillary hydrostatic pressure. This, in turn, increases capillary permeability and causes fluid to leak into the brain tissues, producing symptoms such as headache, nausea, dizziness, and discomfort. This is known as high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE).

AMS minaly results from rapid ascent to higher altitudes and is best prevented by gradual ascent with time for acclimatization.

Mild AMS is managed by halting ascent, acetazolamide, and descent if needed. Moderate AMS requires descent, oxygen, acetazolamide or dexamethasone, and possibly hyperbaric therapy. HACE is treated with urgent descent, oxygen, and dexamethasone, while high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) requires descent, oxygen, warmth, and nifedipine, with hyperbaric therapy if evacuation is delayed.

Other options:

Option A: Following ascent to high altitude, there is hyperventilation leading to the washout of CO2, causing respiratory alkalosis. To compensate, the kidneys reduce the excretion of H+ ions and increase the excretion of HCO3-. So a decrease in HCO3- concentration is seen instead of an increase.

Option C: Initially, hypoxia-induced hyperventilation lowers pCO₂, producing respiratory alkalosis with reduced H⁺ in blood and CSF. Later, renal compensation increases HCO₃⁻ excretion, bringing CSF pH back toward normal with a relative rise in H⁺ compared to the initial state. However, this change in H⁺ is not the cause of cerebral vasodilation, which is primarily driven by decreased pO₂.

Option D: Decreased pO₂ (hypoxia) induces cerebral vasodilation and not vasoconstriction. Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction is seen in the pulmonary vasculature, leading to an increased pulmonary capillary pressure and development of pulmonary edema, also known as high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE).

Pearl PM1009: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: 93. A 65-year-old male came with complaints of a decrease in vision. There were white deposits on the anterior lens surface, seen during slit lamp examination. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a decrease in vision and the image showing white deposits on the anterior lens surface suggests the diagnosis to be pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.

The deposition of this exfoliative material occurs on the iris, ciliary region, and lens capsule. They appear as flakes on the anterior lens capsule and the edge of the iris. There is a radially indented peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material, separated by a clear zone maintained by pupillary abrasion. Pupillary dilation helps in visualising this peripheral capsular deposition.

The material can get collected in the anterior chamber angle and impede the aqueous humour drainage, thus developing secondary open-angle glaucoma. Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen. Treatment involves laser trabeculoplasty to remove this material deposition.

Other options

Option A: Iritis with pupillary deposits can be seen in uveitis, which usually presents with ocular pain and redness.

Option B: Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma presents as focal opacification of the lens due to epithelial cell necrosis. 

Option C: Anterior capsule opacification can occur postoperatively in cataract surgeries.

questions.text: 94. During resection of the submandibular gland, the following structure was encountered. Identify the same.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve.

Nerves at risk for injury during removal of the submandibular gland include:

* Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve

* Lingual nerve

* Hypoglossal nerve

During submandibular gland dissection, the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle serves as an important landmark. Retracting this border anteriorly exposes the deep lobe of the gland, which is then pulled downward while noting its connection to the lingual nerve via parasympathetic secretomotor fibers.

The hyoglossus muscle also acts as a key landmark in this region. Its superficial surface is related to the lingual nerve, the hypoglossal nerve (option A), and the submandibular gland. The lingual nerve lies superior to the deep part of the gland, whereas the hypoglossal nerve lies inferior, running deep within the submandibular capsule and needing preservation during intracapsular dissection.

The image below illustrates the relationship of the lingual nerve and the hypoglossal nerve with the hyoglossus muscle:



Complications of submandibular gland resection:

* Haematoma

* Wound infection

* Marginal mandibular nerve injury

* Lingual nerve injury

* Hypoglossal nerve injury

* Transection of the nerve to the mylohyoid muscle producing submental skin anaesthesia

Other options:

Option B: The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve runs in the superficial fascia, typically crossing the facial vessels near the lower border of the mandible, and must be preserved during surgery to avoid injury.

Option D: The facial artery passes deep to the posterior belly of the digastric and stylohyoid muscles and then either traverses through or superficially over the submandibular gland to reach the anterior border of the mandible.

Pearl PM1689: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

* Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.

* Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Percentage of malignancy

Major

Parotid

Common

10–20%
 

Submandibular

Uncommon

50%
 

Sublingual

Very rare

85%

Minor

Upper aero-digestive tract

Rare

90%

questions.text: 95. A P1L1 mother with BMI of 35 diagnosed with pre-eclampsia underwent LSCS. What is the ideal agent for prophylaxis of post partum venous thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
For a P1L1 mother with BMI 35, diagnosed with pre-eclampsia and who underwent LSCS, the risk of postpartum venous thromboembolism (VTE) is high. The ideal agent for prophylaxis in this setting is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH).

Subacutaneous administration of LMWH is used for thromboprophylaxis in immobilized medically ill patients or in those who have undergone major surgery. LMWH is the drug of choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because it does not cross the placenta to cause fetal malformations. It has better bioavailability, longer half-life, predictable dose response and reduced adverse effects like osteoporosis and thrombocytopenia and less frequent dosing.

For postpartum anticoagulation, LMWH is given subcutaneously once a day for 6-8 weeks. Oral anticoagulants may be considered postpartum based upon planned duration of therapy, lactation and patient preference. 

Other options:

Option B: Although effective for long-term anticoagulation, warfarin is not started immediately after delivery due to the risk of initial hypercoagulability, delayed onset of action, and the need for close INR monitoring.

Option C and D: Clopidogrel and aspirin are antiplatelet drugs, not anticoagulants. It has limited efficacy in preventing venous thromboembolism compared to LMWH.

questions.text: 96. Identify the structure marked with arrow as 'f':
questions.solution:
The given image is a barium swallow image of the hypopharynx, and the marked arrow (f) shows the Pyriform sinus.

The pyriform fossa lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It is bound laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, the posterolateral surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. It forms the lateral channel for food. 

The internal laryngeal nerve lies submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and is easily accessible for local anaesthesia. The pain is referred to the ear in the carcinoma of the pyriform sinus through the internal laryngeal nerve. Foreign bodies may lodge in the piriform fossa. 

The image below shows lateral and AP images of the pharynx demonstrating typical anatomy encountered during a barium swallow.

* a- Tongue base

* b- Epiglottis

* c- Vallecula containing a small amount of residual barium

* d- Hyoid bone

* e- Laryngeal vestibule coated in barium, consistent with laryngeal penetration

* f- Piriform sinuses containing a small amount of residual barium

* g- Vocal cords coated in barium

* h- Barium coating the anterior aspect of the trachea, consistent with tracheal aspiration



The image below shows a cut section of the human larynx.



Other options:

Option B: Valeculla are cup-shaped depressions lying between the base of the tongue and the anterior surface of the epiglottis.

Option C: Epiglottis is a leaf-like, yellow elastic cartilage that forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet. It is attached to the body of the hyoid bone. A stalk-like process of the epiglottis (petiole) attaches the epiglottis to the thyroid angle just above the attachment of the vocal cords. 

Option D: Thyroid cartilage has two alae that are fused anteriorly.

questions.text: 97. A 58 year old male with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus presents with high-grade fever and cough. He is diagnosed with COVID-19 and is admitted. He dies on the 7th day of illness. As part of surveillance, his death is recorded. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient’s death due to a specific disease (COVID-19) is recorded as part of an existing disease surveillance system. Since the information is collected from hospitals or health facilities without active searching, it falls under passive surveillance.

Surveillance is defined as continuous analysis, interpretation, and feedback of systematically collected data. It is continuous and ongoing, whereas monitoring is more intermittent or episodic. It can be of two types: 

* Active surveillance is a system employing staff members to regularly contact health care providers or the population to seek information about health conditions (Option A). Active surveillance provides the most accurate and timely information, but it is also expensive. 

* Passive surveillance is a system by which a health jurisdiction receives reports submitted from hospitals, clinics, public health units, or other sources. Passive surveillance is a relatively inexpensive strategy to cover large areas, and it provides critical information for monitoring a community's health. However, because passive surveillance depends on people in different institutions to provide data, data quality and timeliness are difficult to control.

Other options:

Option C: Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases that are not on the notified cases list. It is used for supplementing routine notifications. The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

Option D: Syndromic surveillance focuses on the clinical pattern and broad category of presentation, which is determined by paramedical personnel and members of the community. It is covered under the Integrated Disease Surveillance project and includes the following clinical syndromes:

* Fever

* Cough for more than 3 weeks duration

* Acute Flaccid paralysis

* Diarrhoea

* Jaundice

* Unusual events causing death or hospitalisation

These syndromes are intended to pick up all priority diseases at the level of the community.

questions.text: 98. Which of the following statements regarding orbital cellulitis is true:

choices.text: Inflammation is restricted anterior to the oribtal wall
Topical broad spectrum antibiotics are the first line of management
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups
Patient presents with proptosis, blurring of vision, normal pupillary and ocular movement

questions.solution:
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups is the correct statement.

Orbital cellulitis is the most frequent acute complication of ethmoid sinusitis. The lamina papyracea forms part of the medial wall of the orbit, is paper-thin and perforated by numerous foramina for nerves and blood vessels. Hence, ethmoid sinusitis frequently leads to orbital cellulitis.

It can present in the following 5 stages:

Chandler–Hubert classification
Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3  Stage 4  Stage 5

Preseptal cellulitis  

Postseptal cellulitis or orbital cellulitis without abscess (Option A)

Subperiosteal abscess

Orbital abscess

Cavernous sinus thrombosis/abscess

Inflammation does not extend beyond the orbital septum (where the medial orbital periosteal reflection attaches to the medial eyelid at the tarsal plate).

Inflammation extends into the tissues of the orbit.

There is abscess formation deep to the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically at the lamina papyracea from ethmoid sinusitis.

There is abscess formation within the orbit which has breached the periosteum.

The inflammatory process has extended into the cavernous sinus which thromboses and may progress to abscess formation.


Orbital cellulitis presents with extensive swelling of the lids with chemosis. There is proptosis of the eye and its mobility is impaired resulting in diplopia. Pain is severe and increases by movement of the eye (Option D).

CT/MRI should be done to delineate the extent of infection. Intravenous treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics is the the first line of management (Option B).

questions.text: 99. A patient presented with chest discomfort and palpitations. ECG shows PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia). What is the drug used in the prophylaxis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Oral Verapamil is the drug that is used for the prophylaxis of PSVT.

Verapamil and Diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT. They are class IV anti-arrhythmics. They block Ca2+ channels, resulting in slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure. However, they do not affect intraventricular conduction. They are primarily used to terminate attacks of PSVT and to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation and flutter.



Other options:

Option A: IV Esmolol is a quick and short-acting β1-blocker and is used for emergency control of ventricular rate in Atrial Fibrillation or Atrial Flutter.

Option B: IV Adenosine is the drug of choice for the acute treatment of PSVT.

Option D: Oral phenytoin is a Class IB antiarrhythmic, having action similar to Mexilitene, and is used in the treatment of ventricular arrhythmia.

Pearl PM0115: Anti-arrhythmic drugs
