questions.text: 100. A 65-year-old man came with complaints of cough, fever and dyspnea. On X-ray, he has old cavitatory pulmonary lesions and hilar lymphadenopathy. On HPE and culture on SDA, a yeast-like organism 2- 4 μm with narrow-based budding is seen. What is the most likely disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man with complaints of cough, fever, dyspnea, with x-ray showing old cavitatory pulmonary lesions, hilar lymphadenopathy and culture showing yeast-like organism 2- 4 μm with narrow-based budding suggests the likely disease to be Histoplasmosis. 

Histoplasmosis (Darling’s disease) is a granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic in the USA, in the states bordering the Ohio River valley and the lower Mississippi River. In India, it is reported from the region of West Bengal, along the Ganga River. The fungus inhabits humid and acidic soil that contains a large amount of bird or bat droppings.

H. capsulatum is transmitted by inhalation of spores (i.e. microconidia) which usually circulate in the air after the contaminated soil is disturbed. After the spores enter the lungs, they are engulfed by the alveolar macrophages and then transform into yeast forms. 

Clinically, the classical histoplasmosis ranges from asymptomatic infection (in immunocompetent people) to life-threatening illness seen in people with low CMI. The various clinical types include:

* Pulmonary histoplasmosis - Acute form presents with mild flu-like illness, pulmonary infiltrates in the chest X-ray, with hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Chronic cavitary histoplasmosis may be seen in smokers with underlying structural lung disease.

* Mucocutaneous histoplasmosis - Skin and oral mucosal lesions may develop secondary to pulmonary infection. Oral lesions are particularly seen in Indian patients.

* Disseminated histoplasmosis - It develops if CMI is very low (e.g. untreated HIV-infected people or following organ transplantation). The common sites affected are the bone marrow, spleen, liver, eyes, and adrenal glands. 

Diagnosis is by direct microscopy. Histopathological staining of the specimens reveals tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages, with an underlying granulomatous response.



Culture is the gold standard method of diagnosis. Specimens should be inoculated onto media such as SDA, blood agar, and BHI agar in duplicate and incubated simultaneously at 25°C and 37°C. 

* At 25°C, it forms a mycelial phase and produces white to buff brown colonies that consist of two types of conidia or spores - tuberculate macroconidia (with typical thick walls and finger-like projections, which is a characteristic feature) and microconidia( smaller, thinner, and smooth-walled).

* At 37°C, it gets converted into yeast form (creamy white colonies), which is best developed in special media like Kelley’s media.

Liposomal amphotericin B is the antifungal agent of choice in acute pulmonary and disseminated histoplasmosis. Itraconazole is recommended for chronic cavitary pulmonary histoplasmosis.

Other options : 

Option A: Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, which are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae.

Option C: Blastomycosis causes North American Blastomycosis/ Chicago disease. Pulmonary involvement is the most common form followed by skin. Histopathological staining shows thick-walled yeast, with single broad-based budding (figure 8 appearance).



Option D: Coccidioidomycosis is caused by Coccidioides immitis, which is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and as the mycelial form in culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: 101. During the autopsy of a 35-year-old female, the doctor noted bruises below the right angle of the mandible with a curved scratch on the right side and three grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage, and additional bruises over the head, shoulder blade, backside of the trunk, and left iliac crest. Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage is present. What is the likely cause of the death?
questions.solution:
The likely cause of death in the given case is throttling (manual strangulation).

Both bruising around the neck and the fracture of the thyroid cartilage are findings seen in throttling. Throttling/manual strangulation is when bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate.

Mechanism of death:

* Occlusion of blood vessels supplying blood to the brain (carotid arteries).

* Occlusion of the airway probably plays a minor role, if any, in causing death.

* Carotid sinus pressure may result in vagus nerve stimulation, resulting in cardiac arrest (vagal inhibition).

External examination findings in autopsy:

* Bruises on the neck: finger grip marks from the assailant, such as bruises below the right angle of the mandible and grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage.

* Abrasions/fingernail marks: curved scratch mark on the right side of the neck due to nail pressure.

* Petechial hemorrhages in the eyes: due to venous congestion from compression of neck vessels.

* Absence of ligature mark: rules out ligature strangulation, supporting manual compression of the neck.

* Additional bruises on the head, shoulder blade, backside of trunk, and left iliac crest suggest a struggle/assault consistent with homicidal violence.

Internal examination findings in autopsy:

* Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage is a classical finding in throttling.

* Carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma: further evidence of forceful neck compression.

* Inward fracture of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone may also be encountered

Thumb impression and finger marks, as shown in the image below, are seen in the case of throttling:



The following image shows the autopsy findings in a case of throttling:



Other options:

Option A: Garroting is a form of ligature strangulation where a thin string is thrown around the neck and is then tightened rapidly with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string to constrict the neck. The image below shows garroting.



Option C: Ligature strangulation is strangulation done by using a ligature, like a constricting band or rope. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth. 

Option D: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In a mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. The image below shows strangulation by mugging.

questions.text: 102. A 28 year old female who was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix presented with hydroureteronephrosis. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma cervix with hydroureteronephrosis is classified as Stage III B  according to Revised 2018 FIGO staging.

Stage III cervical carcinoma may involve the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, may present as hydronephrosis and/or pelvic/paraortic lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

* Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension

* Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney

* Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes

* Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only

* Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Carcinoma cervix can cause ureteral obstruction. Hydronephrosis and uremia can follow and may occasionally be the initial presenting finding. In these cases, ureteral stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy tube insertion is usually required. Kidney function is ideally preserved for chemotherapy.

Pearl PM1903: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

* A: Microscopic lesion

* A1 - stromal invasion ≤3mm depth

* A2 - a stromal invasion of >3 and ≤5mm depth

* B: Macroscopic lesion

* B1 - stromal invasion >5mm depth & tumor size ≤2cm 

* B2 - tumor size >2cm to ≤4cm 

* B3 - tumor size >4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement

* A1 - tumor size ≤4cm 

* A2 - tumor size >4cm 

* B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina

* B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)

* C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent

* C1: pelvic lymph node involved

* C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

* A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)

* B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Pearl PM2144: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: 103. A 55-year old woman presents with the following finding. She has a history of two home births with an untrained dai. Which of these ligaments could have been injured?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image show uterovaginal prolapse in a 55-year-old woman after two home births assisted by an untrained dhai, and it is most likely due to injury of the Mackenrodt’s (cardinal) ligaments, the chief supports of the uterus.

The descent of one or more of the genital organs below their normal anatomical position is called pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It occurs when the muscles and tissues that support the pelvic organs become weakened or damaged, leading to one or more organs bulging into the vaginal canal. The clinical types are:

1. Vaginal prolapse

a) Anterior vaginal wall: Cystocele in the upper two-third and urethrocele in the lower one-third

b) Posterior vaginal wall: Enterocele in the upper one-third and rectocele in the lower two-third 

2. Uterine descent

The ligaments forming the chief support of the uterus are shown in the image below:



Treatment options may include pessary, pelvic floor exercises, or surgery, depending on the severity of prolapse. The degrees of uterine prolapse is shown in the image below:



Other options:

Option A: Round ligament maintains uterine anteversion but provides no significant pelvic support and not responsible for prolapse.

Option C: Broad ligament is a peritoneal fold and not a primary support of the uterus.

Option D: Inguinal ligament connects the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle, which is unrelated to uterine support.

Pearl PM1349: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text:
104. If there is zero filtration across the capillaries, then what is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi), given that:

Capillary hydrostatic pressure: 18 mmHg Capillary oncotic pressure: 27mmHg  Interstitial oncotic pressure: 7 mmHg
questions.solution:
The interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) that results in net zero filtration across the capillaries is -2 mmHg.

The net filtration force across the capillary wall is determined by Starling’s equation:

Net force = (Pc - Pi) − ( πc - πi)

Where: Pc = capillary hydrostatic pressure = 18 mmHg Pi = interstitial hydrostatic pressure = ? πi = interstitial oncotic (colloid osmotic) pressure = 7 mmHg πc = capillary oncotic (colloid osmotic) pressure = 27 mmHg

Given that the net force is 0 (no net movement of fluid):

0 = (18 - Pi) − (27 - 7) Pi = -2 mmHg (option D)

The rate of filtration at any point along a capillary depends on a balance of forces sometimes termed Starling forces.

The two main forces are hydrostatic pressure and osmotic pressure. 

Hydrostatic pressure gradient: the difference between capillary hydrostatic pressure and interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure. Interstitial fluid pressure varies with tissues: it is positive in the liver and kidneys and can be as high as +6 mmHg in the brain.

Osmotic (oncotic) pressure gradient: directed inward, and calculated as plasma colloid osmotic pressure minus interstitial colloid osmotic pressure. The plasma osmotic pressure is largely exerted by plasma proteins within the capillaries.

Pearl PM0287: Starling Forces

Starling Forces

Forces favouring filtration

Pc =capillary hydrostatic pressure

πi=interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure

Forces opposing filtration

Pi=interstitial hydrostatic pressure

πc=capillary colloidal osmotic pressure


Factors that increase filtration

↑Pc- caused by increased arterial pressure

↓Pi

↓πc – caused by decreased protein concentration

↑πi – caused by inadequate lymphatic function

questions.text:
105. In a randomised controlled trial, what is the order of the following steps in a sequential manner from early to late?

* Randomisation

* Manipulation

* Statistical assessment

* Follow-up
questions.solution:
In a randomised controlled trial, the order of steps in a sequential manner from early to late is Randomisation → Manipulation → Follow-up → Statistical assessment (1, 2, 4, 3). 

Experimental studies are of two types:

* Randomized controlled trials (RCT) which involve a process of random allocation

* Non-randomized trials with no strict randomization

The basic steps in conducting a RCT includes:

* Drawing up a protocol which specifies the aims and objectives of the study, criteria for selection of study and control groups and size of the sample. 

* Selecting reference and experimental populations whose cooperation is assured to avoid loses to follow-up.

* Randomization which is a statistical procedure by which the participants are allocated into study and control groups. It eliminates bias and is the heart of a control trial. 

* Manipulation or intervention by deliberate application or withdrawal of the suspected causal factor. 

* Follow-up, which implies examination of the experimental and control group at defined intervals of time in a standard manner. 

* Assessment of outcome, which is the final step of the trial in terms of positive or negative results.

questions.text: 106. A district survey shows that screening of breast cancer increases the 5-year survival rate. However, autopsy studies showed no real change in mortality. Which type of bias is seen here?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes a situation where screening seems to improve survival time, but in reality, it only detects the disease earlier without actually reducing mortality. This type of bias is called lead-time bias. The lead time bias can overestimate the survival time by the early detection of a disease. 

Lead time is the time gained by screening. It is the time between diagnosis by a screening test and diagnosis by other means. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of a disease.

Lead time bias may arise when survival times are selected as endpoints in screening trials. Early diagnosis can lead to an overestimation of survival times because an early diagnosis through screening does not accurately represent delayed mortality. 

For example, a CT scan of the chest identifies a malignant tumor of the lung earlier than a traditional chest x-ray. However, early treatment does not significantly enhance overall survival in patients with lung cancer. Therefore, any apparent improvement in the 5-year survival rates of patients diagnosed through a CT scan compared to those diagnosed with an X-ray is attributed to lead-time bias. 

Other options: 

Option A: Berksonian bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases. It is seen in case-control studies. 

Option C: Detection bias arises in unblinded randomised trials and observational analyses when knowing the treatment assigned causes systematic differences in determining outcomes between study groups. 

Option D: Survival bias is the phenomenon by which individuals are excluded from analysis of a trait because of mortality related to the expression of that trait. For example, studying only cancer survivors ignores those who died early from cancer.

Pearl PM0361: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.



Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Pearl PM0266: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  


Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: 107. A patient presented with swelling of the lower left limb. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes were palpable and were about 1 x 2 cm in size. On FNAC of the lymph node, the following was observed. What is the likely mechanism for the presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of swelling of the lower left limb, with the image demonstrating sheathed microfilaria with nuclei-free tail tip, indicating Wuchereria bancrofti, suggests the likely mechanism to be lymphatic obstruction.

Wuchereria bancrofti causes blockage of lymph vessels and lymph nodes by the adult worms. It could be due to mechanical factors or an allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens and secretions. The vessel walls get thickened, and the lumen gets occluded, leading to lymph stasis and dilatation of lymph vessels. Increased permeability of lymph vessel walls leads to leakage of protein-rich lymph into the tissues. This produces hard pitting or brawny edema of filariasis.

Lymphangitis occurs in which, inflamed lymph vessels are seen as red streaks underneath the skin. Acute lymphangitis is caused by an allergic or inflammatory reaction to filarial infection. There is lymphadenitis, and the lymph nodes become enlarged, painful and tender.

Lymphedema follows successive attacks of lymphangitis. It usually begins as swelling around the ankle, spreading to the back of the foot and leg. It may also affect the arms, breast, scrotum, vulva, or any other part of the body. Initially, the oedema is pitting in nature, but gradually becomes hard and non-pitting. 

The disease can present as classical filariasis or occult filariasis. Clinical features include:

* Classical filariasis- Fever, lymphangitis, lymphadenitis, lymphedema, lymphangiovarix, hydrocele, lymphorrhagia, elephantiasis

* Occult filariasis- Massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, dyspnea, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, etc. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by the demonstration of microfilaria in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid.  The filarial species is nocturnally periodic,  hence it is preferable to collect night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

The image below shows elephantiasis:





Pearl PM1766: Filarial worms and their morphology



Pearl PM0657: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

* Tests for antigen detection

* Tests for antibody detection

Antigen Detection:

Antigen

Parasite

Galactose lectin antigen

Entamoeba histolytica

Giardia-specific antigen 65

Giardia lamblia

WKK and rk39 antigen

Leishmania donovani

HRP-2 antigen

Plasmodium falciparum

Vivax-specific pLDH

Plasmodium vivax

200 KD Ag and OG4C3 antigen

Wuchereria bancrofti


 

Antibody detection:

* Complement fixation test (CFT)

* Indirect hemagglutination test (IHA)

* Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFA)

* Rapid immunochromatography test

* ELISA test

questions.text: 108. A child presented with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. His father also has had a similar history. On peripheral smear, MCHC was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) and a family history, are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. Hence, childhood gallstones should raise suspicion for this diagnosis.

The laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is usually normal or slightly decreased, the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is characteristically increased (>34 g/dL), and hematocrit is decreased due to hemolytic anemia.

The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor (shown in the image below). Osmotic fragility test, acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test help in diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis.

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.



Other options:

Option A: Thalassemia is a hereditary hemoglobinopathy resulting from deficient synthesis of one or more globin chains. It is associated with microcytic hypochromic anemia (low MCHC), typically with low MCV and MCH.

Option B: Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene, replacing glutamic acid with valine. This leads to polymerization of deoxygenated HbS and the formation of sickle-shaped RBCs.

Option D: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is due to antibody and complement-mediated destruction of RBCs. Diagnosis is confirmed using the Coombs test. The direct Coombs test detects antibodies bound to RBCs, while the indirect test identifies antibodies in the serum.

Pearl PM1247: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune


2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

* Mechanical injury

* Trauma caused by cardiac valves 

* Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 

* Repetitive physical trauma

* Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)

* Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility

* Transfusion reaction  

* Drug-induced 

* Infections of red blood cells 

* Malaria

* Babesiosis

* Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

* Hereditary spherocytosis

* Thalassemia

* Sickle cell anemia

* Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

* G6PD deficiency

* Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: 109. An unusually tall 14-year-old boy with extremely long limbs came to the opthalmologist with complaints of diminution of vision. On examination, there was bilateral subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis). Which of the following defects is found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan's syndrome and the likely protein involved in this condition is fibrillin 1.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15.

It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. Ghent criteria is used for diagnosing Marfan syndrome.  The main features are tall stature, ectopia lentis and aortic root dilatation. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

* Tall stature and long limbs 

* Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum

* Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)

* Scoliosis

Cardiovascular manifestations:

* Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 

* Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm

* Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

* Ectopia lentis with upward and outward displacement of the lenses due to weakening of the ciliary zonules

* Myopia with blurred vision

* Retinal detachments

* Early cataracts and glaucoma

The image below shows ectopia lentis in marfan syndrome:



Other options:

Option B: COL5A/2 is mutated in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, presents with hyperextensible skin and joint laxity.

Option C: LDLR gene is involved in familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to high LDL and xanthomas.

Option D: PLOD1 gene causes a rare form of Ehlers-Danlos (kyphoscoliotic type) with scoliosis and fragile tissue.

questions.text: 110. An elderly patient presents with a painful right knee with no history of trauma. On synovial fluid analysis, there are rhomboid-shaped crystals seen and positive birefringence on polarised light. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals with a painful knee are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD) that trigger an acute inflammatory reaction within the joint. It predominantly affects the elderly. Knee, wrist, shoulder and ankle are the most commonly affected joints. There is swelling and pain, which may become severe over 6–24 hours. Fever may also be present.

Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage that are positively birefringent is diagnostic of pseudogout.



Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease. It occurs in old age, mainly in the weight-bearing joints like the knee and hip. There is a narrowing of the joint space of the affected joint.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of sodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. The image below shows needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals in gout.



Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory joint disease. It presents with symmetrical polyarthritis and tenosynovitis, morning stiffness, elevation of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and the appearance of autoantibodies (rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies).

Pearl PM1080: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: 111. Which of the following nerves does not pass through foramen marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is the jugular foramen. The nerve that does not pass through it is the Hypoglossal nerve.

The hypoglossal nerve passes via the hypoglossal canal.

The structures passing through the jugular foramen are as follows:

* Inferior petrosal sinus

* Meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

* Glossopharyngeal Nerve - IX (option B)

* Vagus Nerve - X (option A)

* Spinal Accessory Nerve - XI (option D)

* Sigmoid Sinus continuing as the internal jugular vein

* Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery





Pearl PM2139: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits

  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure

  • Frontal nerve (V1)

questions.text: 112. A 30 year old man presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident and is found to have a closed fracture of the shaft of tibia. Six hours later, he develops severe leg pain which was not relieved by analgesics and worsend on passive dorsiflexion of the foot. On examination, sensations over the first dorsal webspace were lost, but dorsalis pedis pulsations were present. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the limb and give Opiod analgesics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated with Emergency Fasciotomy.

In compartment syndrome, ischaemia occurs at the level of capillaries, so pulses may still be felt and the skin may not be pale. The earliest feature is severe pain or a bursting sensation.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

* Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 

* Paresthesia 

* Pallor

* Paralysis

* Pulselessness

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed. Only splitting the plaster is not helpful, and the limb must be kept flat. This is because elevating the limb causes a further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates muscle ischemia.

In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, fasciotomy should be performed. This involves opening all four compartments via medial and lateral incisions. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later. If tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured, but if there is muscle necrosis, debridement needs to be carried out.

The image below shows a fasciotomy.



Pearl PM2207: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 



 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: 113. A 45-year-old woman presents with delayed cycles and heavy bleeding for the past year. Ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next line of management for this patient with an endometrial thickness of 16 mm is an endometrial biopsy. 

In perimenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), the first priority is to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma, since risk increases with age. In this case, ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. For perimenopausal women, an endometrial thickness >10 mm is generally considered abnormal and requires further evaluation. Therefore, the next best step is an endometrial biopsy to establish a tissue diagnosis.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it exceeds 4 mm on ultrasound is considered abnormal and requires histopathological evaluation irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms to rule out endometrial carcinoma or hyperplasia. Immediate endometrial biopsy is indicated rather than waiting and watching or empirical hormonal therapy. Hysterectomy is not the first-line step without a tissue diagnosis. The approach to postmenopausal bleeding is summarised in the flowchart below:



The methods available to obtain endometrial tissue for histopathological examination are:

* Dilation and curettage (D&C) - It is a fractional curettage comprising separate scrapings of endometrium and endocervix not only allows the exact site of malignancy, if present, but also detects the extent of spread of the tumour and staging. It is the best investigation to rule out cancer. The curettage requires general anaesthesia and hospitalization.

* Uterine cavity aspiration for endometrial sampling - It is an outpatient procedure that has the additional advantage of avoiding anaesthesia. Pipelle aspirator or Vibra aspirator is used to obtain endometrial sample. 

* Hysteroscopy with endometrial aspiration

questions.text: 114. A 19-year-old female patient who is a known case of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presents to the casualty with diffuse weakness. She had stopped insulin 1 day before presenting, as per her mother. On examination, BP was 80/60 mmHg, her plasma glucose was 720 mg/dL, Na⁺ - 126 mEq/L, and K⁺ - 4.3 mEq/L. Which of the following is not a step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
NS 3% is not used in the management of the given condition.

The given clinical scenario, along with the laboratory values and a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious complication of uncontrolled diabetes.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Clinical manifestations of diabetic ketoacidosis include:

* Dehydration, tachypnea with deep, sighing respiration (Kussmaul breathing)

* Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that may mimic an acute abdominal condition

* Confusion, drowsiness, and coma in severe cases.

Initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC). Following that, an emergency assessment is done, which includes:

* Immediate measurement of blood glucose, blood or urine ketones, serum electrolytes, and blood gases

* Assessment of the level of consciousness.

* Two peripheral intravenous (IV) lines should be inserted.

The goal of therapy is to correct dehydration, correct acidosis, reverse ketosis, and gradually bring blood glucose concentration to near normal. Monitor for acute complications, and identify and treat any precipitating event.

Fluid replacement should always begin before starting insulin therapy. One or more boluses of 0.9% saline (option A) at 10-20 mL/kg are given to restore peripheral circulation. A bolus of 0.1 U/kg IV regular insulin (option C) should be given after the initial replacement of fluids. Insulin therapy with 0.05–0.1 U/kg/hr must begin at least 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy. Insulin of 0.05 U/kg/hr can be considered if the pH is > 7.15.

Potassium replacement is given only when potassium is <5.5 mmol/L. In rare cases of hypokalemia with potassium <3.0 mmol/L, defer insulin treatment. Electrolytes, especially K⁺, must be monitored (option D) every 4 hours for the first 24 hours.

Bicarbonate administration is not recommended except for treatment of severe acidosis (pH < 6.9) or in cases of life-threatening hyperkalemia.

questions.text: 115. A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency with a stab injury on the right iliac region. A few hours later, he developed hypotension, abdominal tenderness and peritonitis. Which is the next best management?
questions.solution:
The next best management in the given scenario of a stab injury to the abdomen is emergency laparotomy.

Emergency laparotomy is performed to explore and repair abdominal injuries in case of: 

* Hemodynamic instability

* Peritonitis

* Evisceration

The algorithm for the management of stab wounds of the abdomen is as follows:



Other options:

Option D: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is used to assess the presence of blood or contaminants in the abdomen. It is rarely used nowadays.

questions.text: 116. A male child in his 2ⁿᵈ decade presents with recurrent profuse nasal bleeding in the right nasal cavity and right nasal obstruction. Endoscopy shows a globular mass in the right nasal cavity occupying the posterior choanae and nasopharynx. MRI shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI findings and transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

The clinical features include epistaxis, progressive nasal obstruction, and denasal speech. Other symptoms include conductive hearing loss, broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis leading to frog-face deformity, cheek swelling, and involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves.

Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign), which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.



Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system. 

Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option B: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction with minimal to no bleeding. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by a gram-negative coccobacillus, Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It causes this progressive granulomatous infection starting in the nose and extending into the upper respiratory tract. It presents initially with foul-smelling nasal discharge, and then with granulomatous nodules in the nose, giving it a woody feeling. The last stage is the cicatricial stage, with stenosis of the nares and adhesions in the nose. 

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protist, Rhinosporidium seeberi, that is endemic in South India. It also presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge, but examination will show a mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots and subcutaneous nodules on the skin. The biopsy will show a sporangium with sporangiospores.

Pearl PM1297: Antrochoanal Polyp

* Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy

* Usually affects children

* Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum

* Clinical features:

* Usually single and unilateral

* Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana

* Mucoid nasal discharge

* Hyponasal voice

* Findings:

* Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy

* Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx

* Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.

* Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: 117. A primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation was diagnosed as HIV-positive, for which ART was initiated. She had a viral load of 1200 copies/mL. The baby of 2.5 kg was delivered at term through vaginal delivery and baby was healthy. What is the next step as per our setup?

choices.text: Syp Nevirapine plus Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding
Start Nevirapine prophylaxis schedule of 6 weeks and exclusive breast feeding
Single dose nevirapine to be given and do exclusive breast feeding
Stop breastfeeding and start formula feeds

questions.solution:
This scenario depicts a high-risk infant for HIV, and prophylaxis with Nevirapine with Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding should be started immediately.

This is considered a high-risk infant because the mother was diagnosed with HIV only at 34 weeks of gestation, meaning Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) was started late and there was inadequate time for full viral suppression. At the time of delivery, her viral load was high at 1200 copies/mL, which is more than 1000 copies/mL, which increases the risk of vertical transmission. Hence, prophylaxis with Nevirapine with Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding should be started immediately.

Immediate postnatal ART prophylaxis is crucial in reducing HIV transmission risk and improving long-term health outcomes in exposed infants. Mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV is the primary route of pediatric HIV infection, occurring during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding. 

For ART prophylaxis, a single drug or dual drug regimen is followed, depending on the risk of transmission, which can be low or high risk.

* Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load (<1000 copies/mL) which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 

* High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks (>1000 copies/mL), or mothers newly diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.

HIV Risk ART prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants

Syrup Nevirapine or Syrup Zidovudine (in situations where Nevirapine will not be effective)

 Birth to 6 weeks of age, irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Dual prophylaxis with Syrup Nevirapine plus Syrup Zidovudine

In case of:

  • Exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks 


Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) is recommended for all HIV-exposed infants. At 6 months of age, these infants should be offered complementary foods along with breast milk.

Risk Factors for MTCT: 

* High maternal viral load

* Advanced maternal HIV disease or primary infection during pregnancy

* Rupture of membranes for more than four hours

* No maternal ART use

* Chorioamnionitis or placenta previa

Diagnosis in infants under 18 months requires HIV DNA/RNA PCR testing at 6 weeks using a dried blood spot test. If positive, confirmation is needed with a second whole blood test. Antibody tests are unreliable before 18 months due to passive maternal antibody transfer.

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count, and clinical stage and should be continued lifelong.



Pearl PM2199: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

* HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.

* Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.

* Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers

* Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)

* Exclusive breastfeeding counseling

* Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby

* Initiation of ARV in babies:

* Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age

* High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)

* Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women

* Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: 118. A 60-year-old man presents with weakness, fatigue, and bleeding tendencies. His peripheral smear showed 25% blast-like cells, as shown in the image. What is the most common type of genetic abnormality seen in this hematological malignancy?
questions.solution:
A peripheral blood smear revealing 25% blast-like cells along with prominent faggot cells (blast cells containing multiple Auer rods) strongly points towards acute myeloid leukemia (AML) subtype M3, also known as acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The most common genetic association with this leukemia is t(15;17), resulting in a PML-RARA fusion gene.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a malignancy of hematopoietic progenitor cells with impaired differentiation, causing accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the bone marrow. This replacement of normal blast cells in the marrow leads to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia, along with their associated clinical manifestations. Anemia causes weakness and fatigue, thrombocytopenia increases bleeding tendencies, and neutropenia predisposes to fever and infections.

In AML-M3, the malignant cells release large quantities of procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors that can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and further increase the bleeding tendency. This subtype of AML can be treated with targeted therapy that uses all-trans retinoic acid and arsenic salts. They have the best prognosis among different subtypes of AML and a high cure rate.

The following image demonstrates typical myeloblasts containing Auer rods as seen in acute myeloid leukemia.



Other options:

Option A: inv(16) or inversion 16 is typically observed in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).

Option B: t(8;21) is characteristic of AML with maturation (AML-M2).

Option C: AML with NPM1 is recognized as a distinct entity per the WHO classification that shows normal cytogenetics with the NPM1 gene mutation.

Pearl PM1998: Important Translocations in AML

Translocation t(8,21)

(most common) 

 t(15,17) t(16,16) or inv(16)
Fusion gene

RUNX1-RUNX1T1

 PML-RARα CBF-β (Core binding factor)
FAB classification

Blasts with maturation/M2

 Acute promyelocytic leukemia/M3 Myelomonocytic/M4
Clinical association Myeloid sarcoma/ chloroma DIC Eosinophilia
Prognosis Good Very good Good


Pearl PM1244: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

* Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion

* AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion

* AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion

* AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion

* AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion

* AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion

* AML with KMT2A rearrangement*

* AML with MECOM rearrangement

* AML with NUP98 rearrangement

* AML with NPM1 mutation

* AML with CEBPA mutation

* AML, myelodysplasia-related#

* AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

* AML with minimal differentiation

* AML without maturation

* AML with maturation

* Acute basophilic leukaemia

* Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia

* Acute monocytic leukaemia

* Acute erythroid leukaemia

* Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: 119. A 20 year old male athlete while playing football, has an eversion injury, which ligament is most commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an ankle fracture with deltoid ligament injury. 

The deltoid ligament, or medial collateral ligament, is a strong triangular band attached to the apex, the anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep. The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibres anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibres in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibres posteriorly. Deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibres, tibiocalcaneal in the middle and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly.

It is primarily responsible for maintaining stability on the medial aspect of the ankle. The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilises the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are seen when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture or eversion. 

The image given below shows the ligaments attached to the medial side of the ankle.



The anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly injured with inversion sprains. Important ligaments of the ankle present on the lateral side (lateral collateral ligament), and therefore likely to be injured in inversion sprains, include:

* Anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) 

* Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL)

* Calcaneofibular ligament (CFL)

questions.text: 120. Which of the vaccines given below would you use for the immunisation clinic in your hospital?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Pearl PM0698: Vaccine Vial Monitors

* Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.

* It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

* If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.



* Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.

* The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.

* VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

Pearl PM0697: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: 121. A 40-year-old male patient presented with complaints of drowsiness and was admitted for evaluation. Sodium was found to be 98 mEq/L, which was corrected to 110 mEq/L with 3% saline in 24 hours. The patient recovered for a while and had an altered sensorium later. Now, he developed quadriparesis and bilateral conjugate gaze palsy. Which is the investigation to be done in this case?
questions.solution:
MRI Brain (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is the investigation to be done in the given case.

This is a typical history of sudden correction of hyponatremia leading to central pontine myelinolysis, a common complication associated with the treatment of hyponatremia. MRI Brain is the investigation that is used to make a diagnosis of this condition.

Central pontine myelinolysis/ Osmotic demyelination syndrome is seen due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia (hyponatremia lasting for more than 48 hrs). It results in the efflux of organic osmolytes from brain cells, which reduces intracellular osmolality and osmotic gradient, and water entry. 

Rapid correction of hyponatremia, i.e., >8–10 mEq/L in 24 h (12 mEq/L in this case) or 18 mEq/L in 48 h, causes hypertonic stress in astrocytes within the brain, causing demyelination without inflammation at the base of the pons, with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.

Clinically, patients present one or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, diplopia, a “locked-in syndrome,” dysphagia, dysarthria with/without loss of consciousness. 

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without paraplegia.

Prevention can be done by restoration of severe hyponatremia gradually, i.e., by ≤10 mmol/L (10 mEq/L) within 24 h and ≤20 mmol/L (20 mEq/L) within 48 h.

The image shows the MRI finding of central pontine myelinolysis with axial fat-saturated T2-Weighted MRI showing hyperintense signal in the central pons (trident sign or omega sign).

questions.text: 122. A patient presents with pain on the lateral side of the thigh. The doctor diagnosed him with meralgia paresthetica. Identify the nerve affected?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a neuropathic pain syndrome affecting the anterolateral thigh due to compression or entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN), which is marked as "3" in the given image.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury, especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament, just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension, which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

Patients may develop meralgia paresthetica as a complication of inguinal hernia repair. The initial management of this nerve entrapment involves conservative measures like rest, application of ice, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, and local injections of corticosteroids and anesthetics. If symptoms persist, treatment may progress to medications like gabapentin or its analogues.

Other nerves marked in the image:

Marking Nerve
1 Illiohypogastric nerve
2 Genitofemoral nerve
4 Femoral nerve


Pearl PM1236: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve. 

The following table shows the branches of the lumbar plexus, their root value, muscles innervated, and cutaneous branches:
