questions.text: 123. Following a building collapse, a male patient was brought with a copious amount of debris in the mouth. The following procedure was done. Which of the following statements regarding the given procedure is true?

choices.text: It is used for effective ventilation upto 6 hours
It is used to measure central venous pressure
Work of breathing is more than bag and mask ventilation
It should be followed by tracheostomy

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the given procedure is that it should be followed by tracheostomy.

In this case, the presence of copious oral debris makes intubation and ventilation difficult, so a surgical airway is required. The image shows cricothyrotomy, a temporary emergency airway that must be followed by tracheostomy because of risks such as perichondritis, subglottic edema, and laryngeal stenosis.

If intubation fails, options include a laryngeal mask airway, laryngeal tube airway, or surgical airway. Surgical airway is indicated in airway obstruction from glottic edema, laryngeal fracture, or severe oropharyngeal bleeding. 

Cricothyrotomy can be of two types:

* Needle cricothyrotomy: A needle is introduced through the cricothyroid membrane to provide short-term ventilation. This may be combined with percutaneous transtracheal oxygenation at 15 L/min using a cannula and Y-connector. Intermittent insufflation (1 sec on, 4 sec off) provides oxygenation but inadequate CO2 clearance, so it is limited to 30-45 minutes.

* Surgical cricothyrotomy: A transverse incision is made over the cricothyroid membrane, and a tube is inserted. It is preferred in emergencies over tracheostomy as it is faster, easier, and associated with less bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Surgical cricothyrotomy can be used for effective ventilation up to 24 to 48 hours. Needle cricothyrotomy can be used only for 30 to 45 minutes.

Option B: Cricothyrotomy is used for emergency airway management and not for the measurement of central venous pressure.

Option C: In cricothyrotomy, the upper airway is bypassed, resulting in less resistance to airflow. Therefore, the work of breathing in cricothyrotomy is less, not more, than with bag-mask ventilation.

questions.text: 124. In 'De facto' method of census data collection, information is collected based on which of the following?

choices.text: Location at the time of enumeration

questions.solution:
In 'De facto' method of census data collection, information is collected based on location at the time of enumeration. 

A census is defined by the United Nations as the total process of collecting, compiling and publishing demographic, economic and social data pertaining at a specified time to all persons in a country. There are two methods of census in India:

De facto method - In this method, a date will be fixed for the census of the whole country. Usually, such an operation is carried out during the night, known as the census night. Enumerators count the people on this night wherever they are found, based on location at the time of enumeration. The De facto concept is equivalent to taking a snapshot of the population at a reference time point. Since the enumeration is rounded off in a day, it is also called the date system or one-night enumeration system. The De facto method of census was carried out till 1931.

De jure Method - In this method, every individual in a particular area is personally counted, and the requisite information is obtained. The temporary residents are enumerated at their permanent place of residence. All persons who usually live in a country/territory at a particular reference time-point (usually taken as the middle of a year)  will be counted as the population of the country/territory. The enumeration work is prolonged for two to three weeks, which is known as the enumeration period. This method is also known as the period system, because census taking is confined to a particular period and not confined to a particular date. India's census is presently based on the De jure method.

questions.text: 125. A 30-year-old pregnant female with a history of enlarged inguinal lymph nodes and toxoplasmosis 5 years ago tested positive for IgG to toxoplasmosis. She should ____

choices.text: Be counselled that the foetus is at risk of severe infection and pregnancy should be terminated
Be counselled that there is no risk to the foetus and pregnancy can be continued
Undergo amniotic testing to confirm infection to the foetus

questions.solution:
The pregnant female should be counselled that there is no risk to the foetus and that pregnancy can be continued.

This woman’s IgG positivity for toxoplasmosis reflects a past infection, in her case from 5 years ago, and indicates that she has developed long-term immunity and there is no risk for fetal infection. In pregnancy, the concern arises only when a new infection (indicated by IgM positivity) occurs, as that is when Toxoplasma gondii can cross the placenta and infect the fetus. Since her infection happened well before conception, there is no active parasitemia and thus no risk of vertical transmission to the fetus. Therefore, she simply needs reassurance that her pregnancy can continue without specific interventions for toxoplasmosis.

If the current infection is confirmed, the following measures are taken:

* Amniocentesis and cordocentesis for the detection of IgM antibody in the amniotic fluid and fetal blood.

* PCR for T. gondii gene is also done

* Ultrasonography findings suggestive of fetal infection are: ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcification, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites and IUGR at 20-22 weeks

* If the fetus is infected and hydrocephalus is present, counselling for termination is to be done.

Acute toxoplasmosis during pregnancy is treated with Spiramycin (3 g orally daily for 3 weeks), which helps reduce the risk of congenital infection and long-term sequelae. Pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine with leucovorin can be used later in pregnancy (not in the first trimester) for four to six weeks if needed.

questions.text: 126. A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory investigations reveal decreased B cells, T cells, and a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Recurrent infections, failure to thrive, decreased B-cell and T-cells, along with the deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA), are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

SCID affects both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses, primarily impacting T cells and resulting in the absence or severe underdevelopment of lymphoid tissues like lymph nodes and tonsils. The thymus biopsy shows remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. 

Affected children present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

* Candida albicans

* Pneumocystis jiroveci

* Pseudomonas

* Cytomegalovirus

* Varicella

There are two main types of SCID:

* X-linked SCID: The most common form, caused by a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. This leads to reduced T-cell numbers and impaired antibody synthesis despite normal B-cell counts. The thymus shows undifferentiated epithelial cells.

* Autosomal recessive SCID: Often due to ADA deficiency, causing toxic metabolite accumulation that damages T cells, resulting in greater T-cell reduction. Other, less common autosomal recessive causes of SCID involve RAG and JAK3 mutations.

In both forms, the thymus is small and lacks lymphoid cells, but ADA deficiency uniquely features remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles.

Other options: 

Option A: Hypogammaglobulinemia is characterized by reduced immunoglobulin levels, affecting humoral immunity. Transient hypogammaglobulinemia can occur in children under 6 months of age and is marked by low IgG levels. This condition typically resolves after 6 months of age.

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome results from a deletion of chromosome 22q11, leading to loss of T cell-mediated immunity. Its characteristic features can be remembered by the mnemonic CATCH-22: Cardiac abnormalities, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia. The absence of the thymus in this condition causes recurrent infections.

Option D: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by protein misfolding that impairs the secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. This condition affects the liver and the lungs.

Pearl PM0536: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: 127. A patient with HIV with a CD4 count of 250 cells/mm³ is newly diagnosed to have rifampicin resistance TB. Which of the following is the appropriate regimen, and what should be monitored?

choices.text: Isoniazid, Ethambutol, Steptomycin, Pyrazinamide for 9 months and optic neuritis
Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid, and Moxifloxacin for 6 months and immune reconstitution syndrome
Isoniazid, Ethambutol, Levofloxacin, Pyrazinamde for 6 months and hepatotoxicity
Isoniazid, Ethambutol, Clarithromycin, Pyrazinamide for 12 months and pyridoxine deficiency

questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for the given condition is Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid, and Moxifloxacin for 6 months. The patient should be monitored for the development of immune reconstitution syndrome.

This is a case of HIV infection with multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). The BPaLM regimen, consisting of Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid, and Moxifloxacin for 6 months, is the new treatment protocol recommended by the WHO for MDR-TB.

In HIV-positive patients newly diagnosed with TB, initiating anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) can trigger immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). This is a paradoxical worsening of symptoms and radiographic manifestations due to immune recovery after simultaneous initiation of ART and ATT.

Clinically, patients may develop high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intrathoracic lesions, and worsening chest X-ray findings. The diagnosis is made only after excluding treatment failure and other opportunistic infections.

Severe cases of IRIS are managed with corticosteroids such as prednisone (1-2 mg/kg for 1-2 weeks), followed by gradual tapering. To reduce the risk of IRIS, the timing of ART initiation should be optimized. ATT is started first, and ART is added once ATT is tolerated, usually between 2 weeks and 2 months.

In patients with CD4 counts <50/μL, ART should be started as early as possible, since the benefits outweigh the risk of IRIS. In those with higher CD4 counts, ART can be delayed, but should still be introduced within 8 weeks (2 months) of starting ATT

Pearl PM1720: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases.  All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months HRZE 4 months HRE (Only HR as per WHO guidelines)


Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

* Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

* Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 

* Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

* Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.

* Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.


  Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.

Pregnant and lactating women

Patients with uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia that requires medication
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None


Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

Hh: High Dose Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

Pearl PM2302: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: 128. A patient with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus complains of numbness and burning sensations in the extremities. On examination, he has absent ankle reflexes and has no sensation to touch, vibration, or pain in his lower limbs. The loss of sensation in his extremities has a stocking distribution. What type of neuropathy is associated?
questions.solution:
As per the given clinical scenario and the patient’s symptoms, this is a case of symmetric distal polyneuropathy.

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy. It presents with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove distribution and predisposes to foot ulceration. As the disease progresses, pain subsides while sensory deficits persist, and the patient develops motor weakness. On clinical examination, there may be loss of ankle reflexes, impaired position sense, muscle atrophy, or foot drop.

Other options:

Option A: Autonomic neuropathy is a common complication and presents with postural hypotension, silent myocardial infarction, hypoglycemia unawareness, erectile dysfunction, overflow incontinence, gastroparesis, and enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea.

Option B: Mononeuropathy can affect peripheral nerves (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial nerves (especially oculomotor). Mononeuropathy multiplex can also occur.

Option D: Proximal motor neuropathy (diabetic amyotrophy) involves the lumbar plexus or femoral nerve, leading to severe pain in the thigh or hip. It is associated with hip flexor or extensor weakness.

Pearl PM2075: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

* Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

* Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders

* Drugs and toxins

* Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis

* Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

* Cancer (paraneoplastic)

* Sjögren’s syndrome

* Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)

* Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents

* Vitamin B6 toxicity

* Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 

* Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy

* Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus

* Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: 129. An 8-year-old child presents with progressive phimosis and a white sclerotic lesion seen on the penis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with progressive phimosis and the image showing a white sclerotic lesion on the penis, is suggestive of  Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans.

Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans is a chronic, preputial inflammation that may also affect the distal urethra. It is rarely seen before 5 years of age and can occur due to autoimmunity. Boys present with progressive phimosis and white, hard preputial skin, dysuria and ballooning on micturition. It is treated by circumcision, but some boys respond to topical corticosteroids. Follow-up is required to prevent meatal stenosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Meatal stenosis occurs as a complication of Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans.

Option B: Hypospadiasis is a congenital malformation in which the urethral opening lies on the ventral aspect of the penis, anywhere from the proximal glans to the perineum in association with a ventral curvature (called a chordee) and a ventrally deficient foreskin leading to a dorsal ‘hooded’ prepuce. 

The image below shows penoscrotal hypospadias.



Option C: Paraphimosis is a condition where the prepuce retracts back over the glans and cannot be brought forward again. The glans swells and becomes painful. The image below shows paraphimosis.

questions.text: 130. A newborn presents with deformity in all four limbs, and there was no index finger in the right hand. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is amniotic band syndrome, as the absence of the index finger along with limb deformities is characteristic of constrictive amniotic bands disrupting normal development. 

Disruptions are caused by destruction of a previously normally formed body part. One mechanism is entanglement and tearing apart or amputation of a normally developed structure by strands of amnion within amniotic fluid called as amniotic bands. This sporadic congenital anomaly is known as amniotic band syndrome. The other mechanism is interruption of blood supply causing infarction, necrosis, and resorption of structures distal to the insult. If interruption occurs early, absence of a body part may result. 

Other options:

Option A: CTEV is an isolated deformity of the foot and does not involve absent fingers or all four limbs, so it cannot explain the presentation.

Option C: Cerebral palsy is a neurological disorder causing abnormal tone and movement. It does not cause congenital structural malformations or missing digits, so it’s not the likely diagnosis.

Option D: Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita causes multiple joint contractures at birth involving all four limbs, but digits are present. Absence of the index finger rules this out.

questions.text: 131. The following image depicting bile duct injury shows which type of Strasberg classification?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bile leak from the cystic duct stump and a minor biliary radicle in the gallbladder fossa. According to Strasberg’s classification, the image given belongs to type A bile duct injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location:

* Type A: Bile leak from the cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radicle in the gallbladder fossa

* Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct

* Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct

* Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss

* Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury

* E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus

* E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus

* E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication

* E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts

* E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

MRCP is the gold standard for evaluating the biliary tree's morphology completely. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. An HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

For an unstable patient, temporary external biliary drainage is achieved by passing a catheter percutaneously into an intrahepatic duct. When the condition improves, definitive surgery can be undertaken. The main principle of surgery is to maintain the duct length and the restoration of biliary drainage.

questions.text: 132. If a frameshift mutation is introduced in a coding gene at the 4th nucleotide of a 900-nucleotide mRNA, what will be the most likely outcome?

choices.text: No change in function due to post-translational modification

questions.solution:
If a frameshift mutation is introduced in a coding gene at the 4th nucleotide of a 900-nucleotide mRNA, there will be a complete loss of protein function. 

A frameshift mutation occurs due to the addition or deletion of bases. Insertions of one or two or non-multiples of three nucleotides into a gene result in an mRNA in which the reading frame is distorted on translation. From the point of insertion onwards, the reading frame of the codons is altered. The reading frame shifts and all the triplet codons thereafter. This leads to a completely different amino acid sequence and can also result in premature stop codon and a non-functional protein.

The corresponding mRNA, when translated, would contain a garbled amino acid sequence. Hence, there is a complete loss of protein function. The deletion of a single nucleotide leads to similar results.

If three nucleotides or a multiple of three nucleotides are deleted from a coding region, translation of the corresponding mRNA will generate a protein that is missing the corresponding number of amino acids. The reading phase will not be disturbed for those codons distal to the deletion because the reading frame is a triplet.

questions.text: 133. A patient presented with skin tightening and arthralgia. Raynaud's phenomenon was positive. Lab investigations showed ANA positive and Anti-Scl-70 (Anti-topoisomerase-1) antibody. The presence of which of the following conditions is associated with this Anti-Scl-70 antibody?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with ANA and Anti-Scl-70 positivity, is suggestive of systemic sclerosis. Anti-Scl-70 positivity in this disease is associated with a high risk for interstitial lung disease (ILD).

Systemic sclerosis (SSc), also called scleroderma, is an autoimmune rheumatic disease with a 4:1 female predominance. A wide spectrum of clinical features is seen in SSc. Early in the disease, patients may experience Raynaud’s phenomenon, with episodic color changes of the fingers in response to cold or stress, and arthralgia due to joint involvement.

The skin initially becomes puffy with nonpitting edema, and as the disease progresses, it becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures, resulting in sclerodactyly and characteristic skin tightening. Severe pruritus, vasospasm, and digital ulceration may also be present.

Facial features include mask-like facies due to tight, waxy skin and lack of wrinkles, an expressionless face, mat-like telangiectases, microstomia (fish mouth appearance), perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose.

Most patients have dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux from esophageal involvement, and fibrosis of the skin and internal organs can significantly affect quality of life.

Immunologically, the nucleolar ANA pattern, with fluorescent spots within the nucleus, is most often seen in SSc. Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies are associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and a higher risk of ILD, while other autoantibodies linked with ILD include anti-U3-RNP, anti-PM/Scl, anti-Ro52, and anti-U11/U12-RNP.

Other options:

Option A: Calcinosis cutis is classically seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis and is associated with anti-Centromere autoantibodies. 

Option B: Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is associated with anti-RNA polymerase III autoantibodies.

Option D: Myositis in a patient with systemic sclerosis is associated with anti-Ku and anti-U1-RNP autoantibodies.

         Autoantibody Associated disease

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-Smith SLE

Rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP Rheumatoid arthritis
Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome

questions.text: 134. A 65-year-old male with a fractured arm presents with bleeding from his gums and perifollicular haemorrhages. His diet mainly consists of tea, biscuits, buns and bread since he stays alone. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this man?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male with a fractured arm presenting with bleeding from his gums and perifollicular haemorrhages suggests Vitamin C deficiency. Prolyl hydroxylase will be deficient in this man.

Proline is incorporated into the protein and then hydroxylated to hydroxyproline by the enzyme prolyl hydroxylase. The hydroxylation requires molecular oxygen, vitamin C (ascorbic acid), iron and alpha-ketoglutarate. Vitamin C deficiency leads to poor hydroxylation. It is the major biochemical defect in scurvy and also affects the formation of collagen. Amla, guava, lime, and green leafy vegetables are rich sources of Vitamin C, which are not part of this patient's diet, resulting in a vitamin C deficiency.

In vitamin C deficiency, collagen is abnormal, and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. Therefore, capillaries are fragile, with a tendency to bleed even under minor pressure. Wound healing is delayed. In mild deficiency, petechiae can be seen, and in severe cases, haemorrhage may occur in the conjunctiva and retina. Internal bleeding may be seen as hematuria or melena. Gums become painful, swollen and spongy.  

In the bones, the deficiency results in the failure of the osteoblasts to form the intercellular substance, osteoid.  The deposition of bone is arrested without the normal ground substance. This results in weak bones that fracture easily. There can also be haemorrhage into joint cavities. 

Other options:

Option A: ALA synthase requires Vitamin B6.

Option C: Glutathione reductase requires Vitamin B2.

Option D: Galactosyl transferase does not require any specific vitamin.

Pearl PM2306: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)


Pearl PM1960: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

* Generalised osteopenia

* Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning

* Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage

* Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions

* Hemarthrosis

* Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding

* Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 

* Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line

* Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis



Pearl PM1153: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

questions.text: 135. A 65-year-old man presents with a bony lesion in the lower limb. He also gives a history of an increase in hat size. On examination, bones feel warm to the touch and bowing of the leg is present. X-ray showed a mixed lytic-sclerotic bone lesion. ALP levels-250 IU/L, Normal- serum calcium, phosphate and PTH. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the likely diagnosis to be Paget's disease of bone.

Paget's disease is characterised by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localised sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal, and the bone is unusually brittle. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase are seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal.

Deformities are usually seen in the lower limbs. Bending of long bones occurs due to mechanical stress. The tibia bows anteriorly and the femur anterolaterally. The limb looks bent and feels thick, and the skin is unduly warm. This is known as osteitis deformans. If the skull is affected, it enlarges, and the patient gives a history of an increase in hat size. The skull base can also become flattened, giving the appearance of a short neck.

The radiological signs seen are:

* Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.

* Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull

* Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

The image shows a cotton wool appearance of the skull seen in Paget's disease.



Tam o'Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph resembling the Scottish Tam o'Shanter hat.



Other options:

Option B: Primary Hyperparathyroidism is caused by increased parathyroid hormone. It causes osteoclastic resorption of bone, leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, and depression. Subperiosteal resorption of the phalanges is a diagnostic feature of hyperparathyroidism. The X-ray skull shows a salt-and-pepper appearance, as shown in the image below.



Option C: Osteomalacia: The classical lesion is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in a normal-looking bone. These zones occur due to incomplete stress fractures, which heal with callus lacking in calcium. Raised levels of alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone can be seen.

The image below shows the Looser zone:



Option D: Metastatic disease of the bone presents with pain, swelling, pathological fracture, spinal cord compression and hypercalcaemia. The lesions can be osteoblastic or osteolytic.

      ↓    ↑        ↑     ↑

 ↑: Increased,  ↓: Decreased, N: Normal

Pearl PM0655: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

* Fracture after minor trauma

* Pain at the site before the fracture

* Multiple recent fractures

* History of primary malignancy

Causes:

1. Generalized bone disease: 

* Osteoporosis

* Metabolic bone diseases

* Osteogenesis imperfecta

* Paget's disease

* Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia

* Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

* Chronic infection

* Solitary bone cyst

* Aneurysmal bone cyst

* Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

* Chondrosarcoma

* Osteosarcoma

* Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

* Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: 136. A 20-year-old female with heartburn and acid taste in mouth was diagnosed with GERD. Which of the drugs will facilitate with increased gastric emptying and increased Lower Esophageal Sphincter tone?
questions.solution:
Metoclopramide will facilitate increased gastric emptying and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone. 

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic that leads to coordinated contractions that enhance transit and is a first-line therapy in patients with gastroparesis. The effects are more prominently seen in the upper digestive tract, where it increases lower esophageal sphincter tone (LES) and also stimulates antral and small intestinal contractions. 

It has the following pharmacological actions:

* Dopamine receptor antagonist 

* Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 

* Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist

* Sensitisation of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle.

The adverse effects of metoclopramide are primarily extrapyramidal effects, including acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Other options:

Option A: Omeprazole is a proton-pump inhibitor that causes suppression of gastric acid secretion without blocking any transmitter receptor.

Option C: Vonoprazan is a potassium-competitive acid blocker for the treatment of gastroduodenal ulcers.

Option D: Sodium alginate increases the viscosity of gastric contents, forms a thick frothy layer that floats on them like a raft and prevents contact of acid with the esophageal mucosa. It does not affect LES tone.

questions.text: 137. A 75-year-old male smoker presents with complaints of hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. He is diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and undergoes surgery. What is the surgical procedure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a post-operative tracheal stump created for breathing in patients undergoing total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

* T3 lesions

* All T4 lesions

* Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage

* Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement

* Lesions of the posterior commissure 

* Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery

* Transglottic cancers with cord fixation

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Other options:

Option A: Partial laryngectomy is a conservation procedure that involves the excision of the vocal cord and anterior commissure region in partial front lateral laryngectomy and the excision of supraglottis in partial horizontal laryngectomy. This surgery is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening. 

Option B: Percutaneous tracheostomy is done in ICU patients under sedation when the patient is already intubated and being monitored. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.



Option C: Standard tracheostomy can be therapeutic (used for respiratory obstruction, remove tracheobronchial secretions or assisted ventilation) and prophylactic (for anticipated respiratory obstruction or aspiration of blood or pharyngeal secretions).

questions.text: 138. What is the most appropriate statement regarding the given investigation?

choices.text: Invasive and can be therapeutic treatment for bladder calculi
Non invasive and used to diagnose ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Non invasive and gold standard for bladder cancer
Requires percutaneous access to the renal pelvicalyceal system

questions.solution:
The given image shows Intravenous Urography (IVU). It is non-invasive and used to diagnose ureteropelvic junction obstruction.

IVU is a non-invasive radiographic study of the renal parenchyma, pelvicalyceal system, ureters and urinary bladder using intravenous contrast medium.

IVU can help to identify:

* Ureteric obstruction, Ureteropelvic junction obstruction

* Papillary necrosis

* Anatomical variants such as a horseshoe kidney

* The course of the ureters

* Renal function

Intravenous access is required for the injection of a contrast agent. It can be one of two main forms: bolus or drip infusion urography.

questions.text: 139. A baby presents with low phenylalanine levels. An apparent tyrosine deficiency was seen. But phenylalanine hydroxylase levels were normal. The deficiency of which of the following coenzymes can lead to this manifestation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a baby with low phenylalanine levels and tyrosine deficiency, but normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels, is suggestive of Biopterin, also known as tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) deficiency.

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism seen due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria) and, less commonly, due to a deficiency of dihydrobiopterin reductase or the enzyme synthesising biopterin (non-classical). These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

Examination of cerebrospinal fluid may reveal decreased levels of dopamine and serotonin metabolites. Molecular testing and enzyme assay also help in the diagnosis. Oral supplementation of BH4, control of hyperphenylalaninemia, and supplementation with neurotransmitter precursors are some measures to treat this condition. Sapropterin dihydrochloride is a synthetic form of BH4 and is commercially available, but is expensive.

Other options:

Option A: SAM (S-adenosyl methionine) helps in methyl transfer reactions.

Option B: Tetra hydro folic acid helps in the conversion of serine to glycine.

Option D: Pyridoxal phosphate helps in transamination reactions.

Pearl PM2305: Phenylketonuria



* BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: 140. An industrial worker presented with hearing loss. Rinne’s test was negative on the left side and positive on the right side. Weber lateralised to the left side. Pure tone audiometry was done with results as shown below. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The tuning fork test and pure tone audiometry (PTA) findings are suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness. 

Interpretation of the tuning fork tests:

* Rinne's Test: Negative on the left side (BC > AC) and positive on the right side (AC > BC).

* Weber's Test: Lateralized to the left ear (worse ear).

Interpretation of the above audiogram:

* Blue color indicates the left ear.

* ] indicates BC (bone conduction) and the threshold is <25dB. BC is normal, which means the sensorineural pathway is normal.

* × indicates AC (air conduction), and the threshold is >15 dB, and hence AC is abnormal.

* So, it indicates conductive deafness.

* The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.

* Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness.

Pearl PM1750: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its intensity can be increased or decreased by 5dB.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:

* For AC: 15 dB

* For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:



 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve


Pearl PM1800: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive


AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: 141. A 68-year-old male with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and an HbA1c of 8.2% is being evaluated. He has chronic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 35% and is currently taking metformin and glargine insulin. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to add for glycemic control in this patient?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin is the most appropriate drug to add for glycemic control in this patient.

This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus with poor glycemic control (elevated HbA1c) and chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Empagliflozin, an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is the most suitable choice here, as it not only improves glycemic control but also provides significant cardiovascular and renal protection.

It acts in the proximal renal tubules by blocking SGLT-2, leading to increased urinary glucose excretion. This mechanism is independent of insulin and contributes to lower blood glucose levels. Promoting natriuresis and mild diuresis, it helps reduce intravascular volume and cardiac workload.

In addition, it is associated with modest weight loss, blood pressure reduction, and has been shown to reduce mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients with heart failure.

Adverse effects include dehydration, urinary tract and genital mycotic infections, euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis, and in some cases fractures or amputation risk (particularly with canagliflozin), as well as possible bladder cancer risk with dapagliflozin.

Other options : 

Option B: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that potentiates the action of GLP-1. It is orally absorbed, undergoes minimal metabolism, and is largely excreted unchanged in the urine. Dose adjustment is required in renal impairment, but not in liver disease. Sitagliptin is generally well tolerated. Nausea may occur, but it is not a prominent side effect.

Option C: Glibenclamide (Glyburide) is a sulfonylurea and stimulates insulin release by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K+ channel in beta cells of the pancreas. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally.

Option D: Pioglitazone is an activator of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ), which is involved in the regulation of genes related to glucose and lipid metabolism. Its adverse effects include increased incidence of heart failure (hence, contraindicated in this patient), peripheral edema, weight gain, macular edema, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: 142. What is the diagnosis in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a hand with an edematous and putrefied appearance of the fingers and palm, with a poor line of demarcation, suggestive of Wet Gangrene.

Wet gangrene results from the blockage of both arterial and venous blood supply, along with a superadded infection and tissue putrefaction.

Dry gangrene Wet gangrene 
Clear line of demarcation  Vague line of demarcation 
Dry, shriveled, mummified appearance  Edematous putrefied discoloured appearance 
Slow, gradual loss of blood supply Sudden loss of blood supply
Separation by aseptic ulceration  Separation by septic ulceration 
Treatment - limited amputation  Treatment - aggressive amputation 
Causes - Thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), atherosclerosis, etc Causes - emboli, trauma, etc


The following image shows dry gangrene of the 4th right toe:



Other options:

Option C: Tenosynovitis, which is an inflammation of the tendon sheaths of infectious/non-infectious origin, is characterized by Kanavel signs, which include a swollen finger held in flexion, severe pain on passive extension, tenderness along the tendon sheath, with the greatest tenderness over the part of the ulnar bursa located between the transverse palmar creases.



Option D: Raynaud's phenomenon occurs due to peripheral vasospasm, resulting in pallor, cyanosis, followed by reactive hyperemia in the extremities.

questions.text: 143. An elderly male patient presents with fatigue and pallor. After further examination, he is found to have anaemia due to CKD. What will he likely benefit from?
questions.solution:
The patient with anaemia due to CKD will likely benefit from Darbepoetin alpha.

Anaemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Anaemia associated with CKD is treated with erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) such as darbepoetin and epoetin. Darbepoetin alfa is approved for use in patients who are anaemic secondary to CKD. It is longer-acting than epoetin and hence needs to be injected once a week, and is more convenient.

It can lead to a sudden increase in haematocrit, blood viscosity and peripheral vascular resistance. These can lead to hypertensive episodes, serious thromboembolic events, and occasionally seizures. 

Other options:

Option A: Parenteral iron therapy can be used in conjunction with darbepoetin for the treatment of anaemia due to CKD, but it is not the primary choice.

Option C: Filgastrim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor and is used in chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression in non-myeloid malignancies.

Option D: Folic acid is used in the treatment of megaloblastic anaemia.

questions.text:
144. A 45-year-old man with midline neck swelling presented with odynophagia and dyspnea. The swelling showed cells with variations in size and morphology. Amyloid deposit was also seen. The swelling was positive for IHC markers TTF-1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?

IHC - Immunohistochemistry
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with biopsy showing amyloid deposits and positivity for TTF1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid arises from the parafollicular C cells. Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits, derived from altered calcitonin molecules, are present in the stroma. Calcitonin can be readily demonstrated in tumor cells and the stroma by immunohistochemistry.

Features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include:

* Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy

* Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion

* Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility (VIP secretion)

* Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production

* Blood-borne metastases

Diagnosis is established by careful family history, physical examination, elevated calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid can be associated with RET gene (chromosome 10) mutations in cases of MEN-2A and MEN-2B syndromes. 

The following image shows the histopathological slide of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid:



Other options:

Option A: Papillary thyroid carcinoma shows papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei. Psammoma bodies, a form of dystrophic calcification, are its microscopic hallmark.



Option C: Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized histologically by uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid, resembling a normal thyroid gland, or sheets of cells without colloid.



Option D: Undifferentiated (anaplastic) carcinoma of the thyroid displays varied morphology with giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both, minimal follicular differentiation, and intratumoral necrosis.

questions.text: 145. A 50-year-old female has complaints of right flank pain since the past 6 months. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female with complaints of right flank pain for the past 6 months, and the coronal section of the CT abdomen showing a right renal mass, suggests the lesion to be a right renal neoplasm.  

Renal neoplasm is usually seen in individuals aged 50 to 70 years and usually presents with flank pain, palpable mass in the flank or hematuria. CT is commonly used for the evaluation of a renal mass. On non-contrast CT, lesions are of soft tissue attenuation, while larger lesions frequently have areas of necrosis. Some lesions also have calcification.

The image below shows a normal CT section of the abdomen.

questions.text: 146. Few mosquito larvae are seen. In one of them, palmate hair is seen on the abdomen, it has no siphon tube, and it is seen lying parallel to the surface of water. Which species does it belong to?
questions.solution:
The larva described belongs to the species Anopheles, which can be identified as it lies parallel to the undersurface of water. It doesn't have a siphon tube in its larval stage, but has palmate hairs on abdominal segments. 

Anopheles eggs are laid singly and are boat-shaped with lateral floats. The larvae rest parallel to the water surface, have no siphon tube, and possess palmate hairs on the abdominal segments. The pupae have a broad, short siphon tube. Adults at rest are inclined at an angle to the surface, have spotted wings, and long palpi in both sexes. The Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors for malaria.

On the other hand, Aedes, Culex and Mansonia larvae (Option B, C, and D) are suspended with the head downwards at an angle to the water surface. They lack palmate hairs and have a siphon tube. Eggs are oval-shaped without lateral floats. Culex and Mansonia lay eggs in clusters or rafts, while Aedes lays them singly but without lateral floats. Adults also differ in resting posture and have unspotted wings.



Pearl PM1668: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

* Mosquitoes are global in distribution

* The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia

* Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters

* The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days

* Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

* The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 


 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.



 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.



Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: 147. A 50-year-old male with COVID developed ARDS and is on mechanical ventilation, with a PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio of 100. What is the most appropriate ventilator strategy for this patient?

choices.text: High PEEP and low tidal volume
Low PEEP and low tidal volume
High PEEP and high tidal volume
Low PEEP and high tidal volume

questions.solution:
The ventilator setting recommended for ARDS is high PEEP and low tidal volume.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a clinical syndrome of severe dyspnea of rapid onset, occurring within 7 days of clinical insult, hypoxemia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and may not demonstrate cardiomegaly, pleural effusions, leading to type 1 respiratory failure. Lung injury may be direct, as occurs in toxic inhalation, or indirect, as occurs in sepsis 

PaO2/FiO2 ratio is the ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). It is a key indicator of oxygenation.

ARDS severity is assessed using the PaO2/FiO2 ratio at a minimum PEEP of 5 cm H2O as per the Berlin Criteria:

Severity PaO2/FiO2 (mmHg)
Mild 200 - 300
Moderate 100 - 200
Severe ≤100


Recommended therapies in ARDS with clinical or supportive evidence:

* Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.

* High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of expiration and improves oxygenation.

* Prone position

* Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

questions.text: 148. A 20-year-old patient presents with recurrent ear discharge and conductive hearing loss with 30 dB loss. Which of the following is the management of choice?
questions.solution:
Myringoplasty is the management of choice in this patient.

The given clinical scenario, along with the otoscopy image, points towards a diagnosis of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with subtotal perforation of the tympanic membrane, with all ossicles intact. The management of choice in this condition is Myringoplasty or type I tympanoplasty.

Myringoplasty is the closure of a perforation in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane, which is done by placing a graft over or under the remaining tympanic membrane. Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft to the lamina propria of the tympanic membrane remnants and the fibrous annulus.

The grafts used in tympanoplasty include temporalis fascia (most common), areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia, tragal perichondrium, cartilage, vein, and periosteum.

In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to the malleus in both techniques.



Other options:

Option B: Modified radical mastoidectomy is a surgical procedure performed to remove disease from the middle ear and mastoid, often due to chronic infection or cholesteatoma, while preserving or reconstructing the middle ear structures to maintain hearing. The surgery involves removal of the disease from the attic and the antrum, and exteriorization of the mastoid cavity to the external auditory meatus by removal of the posterior meatal wall and the lateral attic wall.

Option C: Atticotomy, also known as epitympanotomy, is a procedure in which the lateral wall of the attic or the epitympanum is removed. This is done in the cases of limited cholesteatoma.

Option D: Exploratory tympanotomy is a diagnostic surgical procedure that enables direct evaluation of the middle ear, allowing the surgeon to plan and perform appropriate treatment based on intraoperative findings. It is typically indicated in patients with conductive hearing loss who have a normal tympanic membrane, normal tympanometry, and unremarkable temporal bone CT scans.

Pearl PM0433: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate exposed
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)


Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:



SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: 149. A friend of Mr.K, an MBA student, describes him as being focused on rules and being very rigid. He often delays submission of assignments due to wanting them to be perfect. He also reports that Mr K keeps items that are worn out even if they don't hold any sentimental value. Mr K thinks himself to have high moral values. The friend describes that Mr K was often called 'rigid' during adolescence. When confronted with these facts, Mr K denies them outright. What is the most likely personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The most likely personality disorder is obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD), also known as Anankastic personality disorder.

According to ICD-10, the diagnostic guidelines for OCPD require the presence of at least three of eight traits or behaviours given below. These include feelings of

* Excessive doubt

* Preoccupation with details

* Perfectionism that interferes with task completion

* Excessive conscientiousness

* Excessive pedantry

* Adherence to social conventions

* Rigidity and stubbornness

* Unreasonable insistence that others submit to exactly their way of doing things

* Intrusion of insistent and unwelcome thoughts or impulses

This disorder is more often seen in males, and major depressive episodes are frequent in such patients. Psychodynamically, this disorder is believed to result from fixation at the anal sadistic phase, with reaction formation as a defense mechanism. These patients are usually treated with psychotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Dependent personality disorder requires the presence of at least three of six traits or behaviors, according to ICD-10, which include

* Allowing others to make decisions for them

* Subordination of one’s own needs to those of others and undue compliance with their wishes

* Unwillingness to make even reasonable demands on the people 

* Feeling uncomfortable or helpless when alone

* Preoccupation with fears of being abandoned by a person with whom one has a close relationship

* Difficulty in taking even the usual decisions without consultation or support from others

Option C: Narcissistic personality trait is characterized by ideas of grandiosity and an inflated sense of self-importance. The person has an attention-seeking, dramatic behavior, needs constant praise, and is unable to face criticism.

Option D: Paranoid personality disorder requires the presence of at least three out of seven traits or behaviors according to ICD-10. These traits include excessive sensitiveness, a tendency to persistently bear grudges, significant suspiciousness, a combative and tenacious sense of personal right, repeatedly doubting the partner, a tendency to experience excessive self-importance, and preoccupation with unsubstantiated conspiratorial explanations of events.

Pearl PM0379: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: 150. A 15-year-old girl came with painless swelling, gradually progressed over one year. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with painless swelling, gradually progressing over one year, and the given image suggest the most probable diagnosis to be a dermoid cyst.

A dermoid cyst is a choristoma that occurs due to the displacement of ectoderm to a subcutaneous location along embryonic lines of closure. They are lined by keratinised stratified squamous epithelium, have a fibrous wall and contain dermal appendages such as sweat glands, sebaceous glands and hair follicles.

They can be superficial, located anterior to the orbital septum or deep, located posterior to the orbital septum. A superficial orbital dermoid cyst presents in infancy with a painless nodule in the superotemporal and occasionally in the superonasal part of the orbit. It is mobile under the skin but is usually attached to the adjacent periosteum, and the posterior margins are easily palpable.

A deep dermoid cyst presents in adolescence or adult life with a gradually increasing proptosis of the eye or acutely with an inflamed orbit due to rupture. It has indistinct posterior margins. Imaging is done to rule out dumb-bell or subperiosteal extension. Superficial dermoid cyst shows a well-circumscribed heterogeneous cystic lesion, while deep cyst shows a well-circumscribed lesion that may be associated with bony defects or may extend into the inferotemporal fossa or intracranially.

A dermoid cyst is treated by excision in toto. Care must be taken to prevent the leaking of keratin into the surrounding tissue because it can result in severe granulomatous inflammation.

Other options:

Option A: Lacrimal gland mass presents as a smooth, firm, non-tender, painless, slowly progressive mass in the superolateral eyelid mass leading to proptosis with inferonasal dystopia. It is usually seen in older age groups.

Option B: Hemangioma that presents as a proptosis is located deeper, while the superficial ones present as a red-coloured cutaneous lesion.

Option C: Osteoma is a palpable bony nodule, but does not usually present in the eye.

questions.text: 151. What is the nerve supply to the following labelled muscles?

choices.text: a - Nerve to mylohyoid, b -Facial nerve
a - Hypoglossal nerve, b - Ansa cervicalis
a - Mandibular nerve,  b - Facial nerve
a - Accessory nerve, b - Mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The structures marked in the given image are the anterior (a) and posterior (b) bellies of the Digastric muscle. The anterior belly (a) is supplied by the nerve to the mylohyoid, and the posterior belly (b) is supplied by the facial nerve.

The digastric muscle is a hybrid muscle, i.e., it is supplied by two different nerves with different root values. The digastric muscle has two bellies, anterior and posterior. The posterior belly arises from the mastoid notch on the temporal bone and slopes downward and forward. The anterior belly arises from the digastric fossa on the inner surface of the mandible, which slopes downward and backward. The two bellies connect at the intermediate tendon. The intermediate tendon passes through a connective tissue loop attached to the hyoid bone.

Other hybrid muscles of the head and neck include:

* Sternocleidomastoid (SCM): Motor supply is by the spinal accessory nerve, and proprioception is by the ventral rami of cervical nerves (C2, C3).

* Trapezius: Motor supply is by the spinal accessory nerve, and proprioception is by the ventral rami of cervical nerves (C3, C4).

questions.text: 152. A 10-year-old boy presents to the OPD with a subcutaneous xanthoma on his elbow. His father also had a similar lesion, and he died prematurely due to a myocardial infarction. Laboratory investigations show the following: total cholesterol - 480 mg/dL, triglycerides - 146 mg/dL, LDL-C - 300 mg/dL and HDL-C - 26 mg/dL. Which of the following types of hyperlipoproteinemia does this boy have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with subcutaneous xanthoma, with elevated levels of LDL, and a history of premature death of his father due to myocardial infarction suggests Type 2A hyperlipoproteinemia.

Dyslipoproteinemias  
Hypolipoproteinemias 
Name Defect

Features
Abetalipoproteinemia Defective loading of apo B with lipid

No chylomicrons, VLDL, or LDL formation

Intestinal Malabsorption

Treated by the administration of large doses of vitamin E. 

Familial α-lipoprotein deficiency 

Tangier disease 

Fish-eye disease 

Apo A-I deficiencies 

 Low or near-absent HDL is seen in all 

Hypertriacylglycerolemia

Low LDL

Atherosclerosis
Hyperlipoproteinemias

Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (type I) 

 Defect in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II

Increased chylomicrons and VLDL

Low LDL and HDL

No increased risk of coronary artery disease

Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIA) 

Defective LDL receptors

Mutation in the ligand region of apo B-100

Elevated LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia result in atherosclerosis and coronary disease, presence of xanthoma

Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIB) 

 Increased apolipoprotein B

Corneal arcus

Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, familial dysbetalipoproteinemia

 Defective apo E

Increased chylomicrons and VLDL remnants.

Hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis are seen

Familial hypertriacylglycerolemia (type IV)

 Overproduction of VLDL

Increased VLDL and cholesterol levels

Commonly associated with coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, alcoholism, and administration of progestational hormones. 
Hepatic lipase deficiency

Accumulation of large triacylglycerol-rich HDL and VLDL remnants.

Familial hyperalphalipoproteinemia 

  Increased HDL Beneficial condition, but rare 


Pearl PM2169: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and eruptive xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and tendon xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL  Atherosclerosis, palmar and tuberoeruptive xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis


Pearl PM0742: Lipoprotein: Types, Sources and Action

Lipoproteins

Source
