questions.text: 153. A 35-year-old lady with amenorrhea presents with galactorrhea. She is diagnosed with pituitary adenoma. What is the most probable cause of the condition?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause of this condition is decrease in GnRH.

In this case, the 35-year-old woman has amenorrhea with galactorrhea, and the underlying cause is a pituitary adenoma, most likely a prolactinoma. The excessive secretion of prolactin in such tumors has a direct inhibitory effect on the hypothalamus. Prolactin inhibits the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus. This inhibition, in turn, suppresses the formation of the pituitary gonadotropic hormones - luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone. This pathophysiology is shown in the flowhcart below:



Prolactinoma usually presents with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends outside the sella, visual field defects or other mass effects may be seen. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is likely with a prolactin level >200 μg/L. An MRI is recommended in all patients who present with hyperprolactinemia.

Microadenomas can be managed with regular monitoring of prolactin levels and MRI scans, if fertility is not a requisite. Oral dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline are used for medical management. Resistance or intolerance to these drugs requires surgical debulking. Cases that do not respond to medical or surgical management can be treated with radiotherapy.

questions.text: 154. General anesthetic sevoflurane and succinylcholine were administered to a patient undergoing abdominal surgery. Post operatively, patient developed persistent muscle contractions, hyperthermia and tachycardia. Which of the following drugs is life-saving in this situation?
questions.solution:
The life-saving drug for the given condition is Dantrolene.

The clinical picture of hyperthermia, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity following administration of sevoflurane and succinylcholine is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the RyR1 receptor of skeletal muscle. When exposed to triggering agents, the defective receptor leads to uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, resulting in persistent muscle contraction, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and elevated end-tidal CO2.

Patients with positive family history and patients with congenital myopathies are at increased risk for the development of this condition.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

* Succinylcholine

* Halothane

* Isoflurane

* Sevoflurane

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive management includes rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia.

Pearl PM0183: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

* Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

* Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane

* Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

* Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis

* Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia

* Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria

* Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

* Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents

* Hyperventilation with 100% O2

* Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).

* Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 

* Cooling the patient

questions.text: 155. A 68-year-old farm labourer presented with a swelling over the right foot for 2 years, which was initially asymptomatic but now has serous discharge and occasional black granules. KOH mount of the discharge will reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
KOH mount of the discharge is most likely to show septate hyphae of 4 to 5 microns. 

A chronic foot swelling with draining sinuses with black granules is classic for eumycetoma, mainly caused by Madurella mycetomatis. On KOH mount, the crushed black grains typically show slender, septate hyphae 4–5 microns in diameter.

Mycetoma is a localized chronic infection caused by various species of fungi (eumycetoma) and aerobic actinomycetes (actinomycetoma). The causal organisms produce a chronic inflammatory reaction leading to focal neutrophil abscess formation, with scattered giant cells and fibrosis. Grains in the form of white, yellow, red or black granules are found in the centre of the inflammatory response, and may be discharged in pus through multiple sinuses onto the skin surface.

A tentative diagnosis can be made on the basis of grain colour, texture and direct microscopic appearance. Pus should be examined under the microscope for the presence of grains, which may then be processed for histology or examined directly in potassium hydroxide.

If the infection is eumycotic, when crushed under the cover slip, the grains will be seen to consist of masses of fungal mycelium with septate hyphae of 4 to 5 microns. The final identification of the infecting fungus requires the isolation of the causal agent in culture or by molecular diagnostic techniques. 

Other options:

Option A: Arthrospores are seen in dermatophytes (tinea infections).

Option B: Budding yeast with pseudohyphae is typical of Candida infections.

Option C: Hyphae with flower-like conidia describe Sporothrix schenckii (sporotrichosis).

Pearl PM0568: Differences between Eumycetoma and Actinomycetoma

Feature

Eumycetoma

Actinomycetoma

Etiology

Filamentous fungi

Fungus-like bacteria

Grains

Madurella mycetomatis and grisia- black grains

 Actinomadura madurae and Nocardia asteroids- white-yellow grains

Progression

Slow

Rapid
Sites of involvement

 

Feet and hands

Involvement of covered parts

Swelling

Well circumscribed and marked in the later stage

Ill-defined and merges with surrounding tissue

Tissue destruction

Marked in the later stage

Involvement of bone is earlier and extensive

Filaments

Wide (2–5

μm) and septate hyphae, Periodic Schiff (PAS) positive and gram-negative easily visualized at ×400

Slender (0.5–

μm) and nonseptate, PAS negative and gram-positive filaments difficult to visualize even at ×800

Response to treatment

Unresponsive and requires surgical debulking

Good response

questions.text: 156. A patient presented with right-sided weakness, aphasia, and irregularly irregular pulse for last 2 hours. On CT brain, no hemorrhage can be seen. What should be the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this condition is rtPA administration.

Sudden-onset hemiparesis, aphasia & irregularly irregular pulse with no signs of hemorrhage on CT indicate ischemic stroke secondary to atrial fibrillation in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis using a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator - rtPA should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period, i.e., within 3-4.5 hours (2 hours in the given case) of symptom onset.

Intravenous Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (IV rtPA) 0.9 mg/kg up to a maximum of 90 mg, 10% as a bolus, the remainder as infusion over 60 min is given. Tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus over 5s is also used. IV rtPA is given only after checking for the indications and the contraindications for its administration. 

The following flowchart explains the management and patient flow in a case of an acute stroke:

questions.text: 157. A 30 year old female underwent the procedure shown in the image following a burn injury. Which statement is true regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Done to save the artery in the arm

questions.solution:
The given image shows escharotomy, which is done in circumferential burns.

Emergency surgery is required for circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs and torso. The burn has a tourniquet-like effect, which can lead to a compromise in respiration (torso) and peripheral circulation (limbs). The tourniquet effect of this injury is treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns.

For the chest, two longitudinal and two horizontal incisions are made. There should be evidence of immediate improvement of respiration and, if intubated, the ventilation pressures after performing escharotomy. For the limbs, the escharotomy incision is performed in the midaxial line to avoid major nerves. An escharotomy can cause significant blood loss, and hence, the use of cutting diathermy and appropriate dressings must be considered along with the availability of blood for transfusion.

Key features of escharotomy placement:

* Chest: Down the chest lateral to the nipples, across the chest below the clavicle and across the chest at the level of the xiphisternum

* Upper limb: Mid-axial, anterior to the elbow, medially to avoid the ulnar nerve

* Hand: Midline in the digits. Release muscle compartments if tight, and this is best done in theatre. 

* Lower limb: Mid-axial. Posterior to the ankle, medially to avoid the saphenous vein.

The image below shows escharotomy.

questions.text: 158. Patient underwent chemotherapy and developed tumour lysis syndrome with elevated uric acid levels. He was treated with Pegloticase. What is the mechanism of action of Pegloticase?

choices.text: Inhibition of URAT1 in renal tubules

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of pegloticase is the oxidation of uric acid.

Pegloticase catalyses the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble inactive metabolite and can be easily eliminated by the kidney. The urate oxidase enzyme, which converts uric acid to allantoin, is absent in humans. 

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug decreases if antibodies are produced against it, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. This requires monitoring of plasma uric acid levels, with rising levels as an indicator of antibody production.

Pegloticase can cause adverse reactions like vomiting, nausea, chest pain, constipation, diarrhoea, erythema, pruritus, urticaria, anaphylactic reactions and hemolysis in G6PD-deficient patients. It can also lead to flare-ups of gout during treatment.

Other options: 

Option A: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Probenecid inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by acting on URAT-1 in renal tubules.

Pearl PM1929: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs Aspirin (low dose) Niacin Thiazide Lasix (furosemide) Ethambutol Alcohol Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: 159. According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012, protection against sexual harassment, sexual offences, and pornography is provided to?
questions.solution:
According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012, protection against sexual harassment, sexual offences, and pornography is provided to all children (both male and female) under the age of 18.

As per the POCSO Act, 2012, all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years are considered children and are protected from sexual abuse. 

The offenses and respective punishments in the provisions of this act are as follows:

S. No. Offense Punishment If aggravated
1. Penetrative sexual assault Imprisonment for 7 or more years; May extend for life with a fine. Imprisonment for 10 years or more; May extend for life with a fine.
2. Sexual assault without penetration Imprisonment for ≥ 3-5 years and fine Imprisonment for ≥ 5-7 years and fine
3. Sexual harassment Imprisonment for 3 years and a fine  
4. Child pornography

Imprisonment for 5 years and a fine.

A subsequent conviction is liable to 7 years of imprisonment and a fine.

  


Sexual abuse offenses, when committed by a person in a position of authority over the child (police/ member of security forces/ public servant), are deemed to be aggravated.

All sexual offenses must be reported to the police as a rule. Failure to comply with this mandatory provision of the POCSO Act can attract imprisonment for up to 6 months, a fine, or both.

questions.text: 160. A 40 year old patient presented with fever, cough and dyspnea. BAL sample showed septate hyphae with dichotomous branching on microscopy. What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and BAL sample showing septate hyphae with dichotomous branching on microscopy suggest the likely organism to be Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus fumigatus causes invasive disease in immunocompromised human beings. It can cause:

* Invasive aspergillosis: It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs.

* Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

* Aspergilloma 

* Superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so the periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

The microscopic image above shows septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles and a typical conidiophore is characteristic of Aspergillus.



Other options:

Option A: Candida has yeast and pseudohyphae as shown in the image below.



Options B and C: Lichtheimia corymbifera and Rhizopus oryzae are Zygomycetes and have non-septate hyphae.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



 

Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



 

Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
161. An elderly patient presents with increased frequency of breathing and weakness. ABG is given. What is the likely diagnosis?

* pH = 7.3

* pCO2 = 44 mmHg

* pO2 = 85 mmHg

* HCO3- = 16 mEq/L

* Na+ = 132 mEq/L

* Cl- = 86 mEq/L

* Base excess = -12 mEq/L

choices.text: Acute metabolic alkalosis with AG 16 mEq/L
Acute respiratory acidosis with AG 16 mEq/L
Acute metabolic acidosis with AG 30 mEq/L
Chronic Respiratory acidosis with AG 30 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The most likely acid-base disorder in the patient is acute metabolic acidosis with an anion gap (AG) of 30 mEq/L.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.3 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: The plasma HCO3- is 16 mEq/L below normal (22 - 28 mEq/L), and the pCO2 is 44 mmHg, which lies in the normal range (35-45 mmHg). This, along with low pH, signifies metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using the following formula: Decrease in pCO2 = 1.25 X Δ HCO3-  Decrease in pCO2  = 1.25 X (24 - 16) = 10 mmHg Expected pCO2  = 40 - 10 = 30 mmHg The measured pCO2 is 44 mmHg (which is more than the expected value), indicating that there is no respiratory compensation.

Step 4: The anion gap can be calculated using the following formula: Anion Gap = [Na+] - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]) Anion Gap = 132 - (16 + 86) = 30 mEq/L

Thus, the ABG shows metabolic acidosis with an anion gap of 30 mEq/L.

Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: 162. A 46-year old nulliparous woman with a history of irregular periods presents with amenorrhoea for two months and a positive urine pregnancy test. How will you accurately assess the gestational age?
questions.solution:
In early pregnancy, the crown–rump length is the most accurate method for assessing gestational age.

Gestational age refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of the LMP. It is usually expressed in weeks. In case of irregular periods, gestational age calculated with the help of LMP will be inaccurate.

First-trimester ultrasound measurement of CRL is the best method to assess gestational age. It is measured from the outer margin of the cephalic pole to the rump in the midsagittal plane with the embryo or fetus in a neutral, nonflexed position. The embryofetal crown-rump length in the first trimester is accurate up to ± 5 to 7 days. 

CRL measurement is shown in the image below:



The best ultrasonographic parameters for estimation of the gestational age according to the trimester are as follows:

Trimester

Parameter

1st 

Crown-rump length (CRL)

2nd  

Biparietal diameter (BPD)

3rd

 Femur Length. (FL) 


Other parameters like abdominal circumference (AC) and head circumference (HC) can also be used. The following images show the three landmarks used to accurately measure the abdominal circumference:





On TVS, the gestation sac could be seen as early as 4.5-5 weeks. Fetal gestational age can also be estimated by measuring the Mean Gestational Sac Diameter (MSD ), but it is less accurate than CRL and is only used when the embryo is not yet visible.

Pearl PM1827: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

* The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.

* The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.

* Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)

* CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy

* CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.

* The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: 163. The given graph shows pCO₂ and pO₂ of the right lung along with the ventilation and perfusion ratio. Which point on the graph represents the V/Q ratio if there is a complete block of the blood supply at the alveolar level of the right lung due to pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Point 4 in the graph represents the V/Q ratio of this patient's right lung due to pulmonary embolism.

The ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is defined as the ratio of lung ventilation to pulmonary blood flow (perfusion) at rest. The average V/Q ratio in the lungs is approximately 0.8. Normal venous blood has a pO2 of 40 mm Hg and a pCO2 of 45 mm Hg.

If perfusion to the alveolus is blocked by an embolus (Q = 0), gas exchange cannot occur. Although alveolar ventilation remains normal (V > 0), there is no blood flow to allow diffusion. Thus, the V/Q ratio becomes infinite (since the denominator, Q, is zero), which corresponds to point 4 on the graph.



Other options:

Option A: Point 1 represents a V/Q ratio of zero (V/Q = 0), occurring when ventilation is blocked (V = 0) but perfusion remains (Q > 0). This is seen in the case of foreign body obstruction.

Option B: Point 2 corresponds to Zone 3 of the lung, where the V/Q ratio is the lowest.

Option C: Point 3 corresponds to Zone 1 of the lung, where the V/Q ratio is the highest.

questions.text: 164. A 35-year-old female with hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and hyponatremia is diagnosed with Addison's disease. Which of the following hormones is responsible for her hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) is the hormone responsible for hyperpigmentation in a patient with Addison's disease.

In primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) due to the loss of glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid secretion, the negative feedback to the HPA (Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal) axis is lost, leading to excessive secretion of ACTH and MSH (Melanocyte-stimulating hormone). The main cause of hyperpigmentation is excess ACTH, which has a similar effect as MSH and stimulates the melanocytes for melanin formation.

The image below shows hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease:

questions.text: 165. A 65-year-old male presented with fever, cough, and chest pain. Identify the lesion in the given Chest X-ray.
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray shows right upper lobe consolidation.

The given clinical scenario of fever, cough, and chest pain suggests pneumonia. The chest X-ray shows an opacity in the right upper zone of the lung with a sharply defined lower border likely corresponding to the superior margin of the horizontal fissure, without tracheal deviation. These findings are consistent with right upper lobe consolidation.

Other options:

Option B: In right upper lobe collapse, the horizontal fissure shifts superiorly and medially toward the hilum, becoming concave. There is tracheal deviation to the right, along with compensatory hyperinflation of the right middle and lower lobes.

Option C: Lung malignancy usually appears as an irregular mass. It may be associated with collapse or consolidation, calcifications, or lymphadenopathy.



Option D: A lung abscess typically presents as an irregular mass-like lesion with cavitation, often containing an air-fluid level.

questions.text: 166. Identify the type of anal fistula seen in the image.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. 

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal communication extending from the anorectal lumen (the internal opening) to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttock (or rarely, in women, to the vagina). The majority are idiopathic or cryptoglandular and are lined by granulation tissue. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and discomfort.

As per the American Gastroenterology Association Classification, anal fistulas can also be classified into simple or complex:

* Simple fistulas are low (superficial or low inter- or low trans-sphincteric tract) and have a single external opening

* Complex fistulas are high (high inter- or trans-sphincteric tract). They have an extra- or suprasphincteric tract with the presence of an abscess or collection. They include ano-vaginal fistula and anal stricture.



Pearl PM1269: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

 Type of Fistula

Arises due to 

Begins from

Track

Ends in

Inter-sphincteric

Perianal abscess

Dentate line

In inter-sphincteric space

Perianal skin or perineum

Trans- sphincteric

Ischiorectal Fossa abscess

Dentate line

Crosses the internal and external sphincters 

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Penetrates the inter-sphincteric space, continues above puborectalis, and penetrates levator ani

Perineal skin or perineum

Extra- sphincteric

Penetrating injury

Crohn’s disease

Carcinoma rectum

 Rectum or sigmoid colon 

Outside the external sphincter, penetrating the levator ani 

 Peri-anal skin via ischio-rectal  fossa.

questions.text: 167. A 30-year-old female came with a history of chronic abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year. The MRI shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 30-year-old female with a history of chronic abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year and the MRI showing an enlarged globular uterus with thickening of the junctional zone is suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, pelvic discomfort, and backache, while some patients are asymptomatic. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to a 12-14 week size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination.

TVS findings include alternating vertical stripes of hyperechoic and hypoechoic bands, which is called the Venetian blind appearance. On MRI, a diffuse, widened low-intensity junctional zone ≥12 mm predicts adenomyosis with high accuracy, while a junctional zone ≤8 mm excludes it with high accuracy. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision/Levonorgestrel-containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.



Other options: 

Option A: Fibroid clinically presents similarly to adenomyosis, but fibroid is usually focal, well-circumscribed, the uterus can get more enlarged, and the uterine contour is usually irregular. There is no thickening of the junctional zone as seen in the image.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are overgrowths of benign endometrial stroma covered by columnar epithelium. They appear as smooth polypoid masses arising from the endometrium into the uterine cavity. The USG below shows a characteristic feeding vessel sign on the colour Doppler.



Option D: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the endometrial lining. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung. MRI shows haemorrhages, deep pelvic lesions and fibrosis.

questions.text: 168. A 68-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain. The X-ray spine is as follows. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic lower back pain and X-ray spine showing forward shift of the upper part of the spinal column (L5) on the stable vertebra below (S1), and elongation of the arch of the spine, suggests the diagnosis to be Spondylolisthesis.

Spondylolisthesis is a condition where there is forward displacement of one vertebra over the one beneath it, most often seen in L5 over S1. It usually presents with backache and sometimes with sciatica. Symptoms worsen on standing or walking. It is usually asymptomatic and is detected on a routine X-ray taken during screening.

On examination, there may be a visible or palpable step (step sign) above the sacral crest due to the forward displacement of the spinal column along with increased lumbar lordosis.

The Scottie-dog sign/ Scottish terrier dog sign is a sign used to describe a normal oblique view of the dorsolumbar spine. On an oblique view, the pars interarticularis area of the vertebra appears like a Scottish dog. Whenever there is a fracture or other abnormality in the pars interarticularis, this dog is abnormal. If the Scottish dog appears to be beheaded, with a large distance between the "head" and the "body" of the dog, it is suggestive of spondylolisthesis. 

The image below shows a beheaded Scottish dog :





Below is an image of a normal Scottish dog sign:



Other options:

Option A: If the Scottish dog appears to be wearing a collar, then it is a defect in the pars interarticularis, namely spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is a condition in which there is a break in the pars interarticularis, usually seen in the L5 lumbar vertebra. An image of a Scottish dog wearing a collar is shown below:





Option B: Klippel feil syndrome- There is a congenital short and stiff neck due to fused or deformed cervical vertebrae.



Option C: Crushed vertebrae are usually seen in fractures.

questions.text: 169. A 25-year-old female patient with diagnosed recurrent migraine despite Sumatriptan, has 3-5 episodes/week and presents with features of anxiety and palpitations. There is no clinical neck swelling, no history of coronary artery disease; however, there is a family history of CHD. She reports experiencing chest tightness after taking the medication. What is the most appropriate agent to add for migraine prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate agent to be added for migraine prophylaxis in this patient is Propranolol.

Drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine include:

* Beta-blockers: Propranolol

* Calcium channel blocker: Flunarizine (Verapamil and Nimodipine have no role)

* Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, Venlafaxine (SSRIs such as Fluoxetine are not used)

* Anticonvulsants: Valproate, Topiramate

* 5-HT2 antagonist: Pizotifen

* CGRP antagonists: Erenumab, Fremanezumab, Galcanezumab, Eptinezumab

Other modalities of preventive treatment include:

* Greater occipital nerve block

* Onabotulinum toxin A

* Supraorbital transcutaneous stimulation

Propranolol is contraindicated in patients with severe asthma, COPD, peripheral vascular disease, severe bradycardia, and heart blocks. In this case, the patient does not have a history of coronary artery disease. The chest tightness experienced after taking the medication is most likely a side effect of sumatriptan rather than coronary heart disease. Hence, propranolol is not contraindicated in this patient.

Moreover, Propranolol will also be beneficial in addressing palpitations and anxiety that are seen in the patient.

Other options:

Option A: Topiramate is less preferred in this patient as she is a woman of reproductive age and it has teratogenic potential. Valproate is also less preferred due to the same reason.

Option C: Naratriptan belongs to the same class as sumatriptan (Triptans), and hence, adding it for prophylaxis will not be beneficial and worsen her chest tightness.

Option D: Ergotamine is a non-selective 5-HT agonist that is used in acute attacks of migraine and not for prophylaxis.

questions.text: 170. A 42-year-old woman had a non-specific right upper quadrant pain. The gross section of the excised tumor is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of non-specific right upper quadrant pain, with the given gross specimen showing a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar, is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma. It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic, and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern. It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase, and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

The contrast-enhanced CT image of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is shown below.



Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as a hotspot on a Tc 99m sulfur colloid scan.

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation; therefore, asymptomatic patients do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

Another tumor that can show a central stellate scar is renal oncocytoma.

Other options:

Option A: Metastatic tumor is the most common tumor of the liver. It typically presents as multiple nodular masses leading to hepatomegaly, and these nodules may replace large areas of liver parenchyma. Occasionally, metastatic lesions can appear as a solitary nodule.

Option C: Hepatic adenoma is a well-defined, discrete liver mass that may sometimes be multiple. It is often associated with hemorrhage and carries a risk of rupture, which can lead to massive abdominal bleeding.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver. It may present as a single large mass or diffusely infiltrate the entire liver. The lipid-rich clear cell variant of HCC shows abundant fat and glycogen in tumor cells. The external surface of the tumor is usually nodular or congested with a tan appearance, while the cut surface is solid and variegated, with areas of cystic change.

Pearl PM1924: Liver tumors - commons

* Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor

* Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma

* Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma

* Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma

* Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma

* Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma

* Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: 171. A 45-year-old male presented with difficulty in swallowing and weight loss. The barium swallow gives the following finding along with bronchectatic changes on chest X ray. What is the investigation of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance, is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Manometry is the investigation of choice.

Pearl PM1528: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

* Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

* Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

* Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)

* Regurgitation

* Chest pain

* Weight loss

* Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy



Pearl PM2445: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance



Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.



Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.



Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.



Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.



Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.



Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.





Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: 172. A patient presents with an asymptomatic macular lesion since childhood. Diascopy was inconclusive and Wood lamp examination showed white accentuation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is nevus depigmentosus.

This condition presents as a stable, congenital or early childhood hypopigmented macule. On Wood’s lamp examination, the lesion shows white accentuation. The lesion remains non-progressive and asymptomatic throughout life, which fits the case scenario. 

Nevus depigmentosus is a stable, well-circumscribed hypopigmented patch that is present at birth and may become more noticeable during the first year as the surrounding skin pigmentation develops. There is usually a single oval or rectangular lesion, but the presence of three or more nevus depigmentosus or hypomelanotic patches in a newborn should raise suspicion for possible tuberous sclerosis complex. It is a congenital nonprogressive hypopigmented macule or patch that is stable in its relative size and distribution throughout life. 

Nevus depigmentosus can be diagnosed using the following criteria:

* Leukoderma present at birth or of early onset

* No alteration in the distribution of leukoderma throughout life

* No alteration in texture or change in sensation in the affected area

* Absence of hyperpigmented border.

Diascopy test is negative in nevus depigmentosus but positive in nevus anemicus. Wood's lamp examination demonstrates an off-white color. Histopathologic examination shows normal to decreased number of melanocytes with S-100 stain. Mostly it does not require any treatment as it is non-progressive and adequate counseling is sufficient.

Other options:

Option A: Nevus anemicus are pale macules or patches most often on the trunk. They can be distinguished from other differentials because of their response to firm stroking. Stroking evokes an erythematous line and flare in normal surrounding skin, but the skin of a nevus anemicus does not redden.

They can also be diagnosed by diascopy, in which pressure of the skin with a glass slide will obscure the borders of a nevus anemicus. In this case, diascopy was inconclusive, making nevus anemicus less likely. The image below shows nevus anemicus:



Option B: Vitiligo is an acquired condition resulting from the progressive loss of melanocytes.It is characterised by milky‐white, sharply demarcated macules. Under Wood’s lamp, vitiligo lesions appear chalky white due to the complete absence of melanin. Since the lesion here has been stable since childhood and not progressive, vitiligo is ruled out.



Option D: Indeterminate leprosy presents as hypopigmented macules with reduced sensation and poorly defined margins. The case mentions an asymptomatic lesion with no sensory loss, making indeterminate leprosy unlikely.

questions.text: 173. Which statistical test can be used to compare the mean haemoglobin values of two independent groups?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the unpaired t-test would be used to compare the mean haemoglobin values of two independent groups when the data is normally distributed. Since the study involves independent groups and a continuous variable (mean haemoglobin), the unpaired t-test is the most appropriate choice.

Tests of significance are used to check for a significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups.



Other options:

Option A: Chi-square test is used to test whether the difference between the two proportions is significant. It is used for categorical data and is not suitable for comparing means of continuous variables. It can also be used when more than two groups are to be compared. 

Option C: Paired t-test is a parametric test and analyses the mean difference in a paired sample, like pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare means across three or more groups, not just two.

Pearl PM1104: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

* See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?

* If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.

* If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

* If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

* If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

* Unpaired t tests

* Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.

* It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.

* Paired t tests

* "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"

* So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 

* Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.

* It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.

* It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

* T scores 

* The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.

* The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

* The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

* The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

* It is a test of proportions and associations.

* A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.

* If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: 174. A 58-year-old male, known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension, presents with nasal bleeding. If the initial conservative management, such as nasal packing, was not successful in controlling the bleed, which of the following arteries should most importantly be ligated to control the bleed?
questions.solution:
The most important artery to be ligated in a case of epistaxis that is not controlled by conservative management is the sphenopalatine artery, as it is the main artery contributing to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Little's area is the most common site of epistaxis. It is present in the anteroinferior part of the septum. Four arteries (anterior ethmoidal, septal branch of superior labial, septal branch of sphenopalatine, and greater palatine) anastomose here to form Kiesselbach’s plexus.

The image below shows the blood supply of the nasal septum and areas of epistaxis.



The first step in treating epistaxis is to pinch the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The patient should sit leaning slightly forward over a basin to spit out blood and breathe through the mouth (Hippocratic or Trotter’s method).



If the bleeding point is localized, cauterization can be done with electrocautery. In cases of uncontrolled bleeding or when the bleeding is posterior into the throat, anterior or posterior nasal packing may be required, respectively. If bleeding continues despite these measures, endoscopic procedures or vessel ligation close to the bleeding point can be considered.





The recommended hierarchy of ligation of vessels in a patient with epistaxis is given below:

Sphenopalatine artery ↓ Internal maxillary artery (The greater palatine artery is a branch of this artery, option D) ↓ External carotid artery ↓ Anterior ethmoidal artery (option A)  ↓ Posterior ethmoidal artery (option B)

The sphenopalatine artery is ligated first through a trans-nasal endoscope (transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation) at the sphenopalatine foramen, which is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

However, if the bleeding persists, internal maxillary artery ligation is done at the pterygopalatine fossa via the Caldwell-Luc approach. If bleeding is still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation is done just above the origin of the superior thyroid artery.

If the bleeding site is located superior to the level of the middle turbinate, the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries should be ligated via Lynch incision in the medial wall of the orbit.

questions.text: 175. Which of the following is not a functional component of the marked nerve in the given image?
questions.solution:
The nerve marked in the image is the Vagus nerve (X). General Somatic Efferent is not its functional component.

The Vagus nerve (X) exits the skull through the jugular foramen. In the neck, it descends within a carotid sheath between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

The following are the functional components of the Vagus (X) nerve:

* Sensory from the ear: General Somatic Afferent (option C)

* Sensory from pharynx/larynx: General Visceral Afferent (option D)

* Taste from the root of tongue and the epiglottis: Special Visceral Afferent

* Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen: General Visceral Efferent (option B)

* Motor to 4th/6th arch derivatives: Special Visceral Efferent (branchial efferent/branchiomotor)



Pearl PM2242: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE


abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.

questions.text: 176. A patient with hypertensive episodes, with an MRI abdomen showing a suprarenal mass, is planned for surgery. 24-hour urine shows metanephrine levels to be elevated. What drug will be given preoperatively and also intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis to be Pheochromocytoma. The drug that will be given preoperatively and also intraoperatively is Nicardipine.

The medical management of pheochromocytomas requires blood pressure control and volume repletion. Nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker that is commonly used preoperatively. It inhibits norepinephrine-mediated calcium transport into vascular smooth muscle. Nicardipine also helps to control blood pressure intraoperatively. Calcium channel blockers are indicated in patients who are not able to tolerate alpha blockade because of profound orthostasis or for those patients who need additional blood pressure control. It is as effective as alpha and beta blockers, both preoperatively and intraoperatively. 

Preoperatively, blood pressure control is primarily with alpha blockers. Irreversible, long-acting α-blockers such as phenoxybenzamine are started 1 to 3 weeks before surgery. Selective alpha-blockers such as prazosin, doxazosin, and terazosin can also be used. Beta-blockers such as propranolol can be added preoperatively in patients who have persistent tachycardia and arrhythmias. Beta-blockers should be given after adequate alpha-blockade and hydration to avoid the effects of unopposed alpha stimulation, such as hypertensive crisis and congestive heart failure.

Nicardipine, Nitroprusside, Nitroglycerin, and Phentolamine are used for intraoperative control of blood pressure. Esmolol can be administered to control heart rate.

Other options:

Option B: Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that can be used to manage intraoperative arrhythmias.

Option C: Clonidine is an alpha-agonist that suppresses neurogenically mediated catecholamine excess but not secretion from pheochromocytomas.

Option D: Phenoxybenzamine is a long-acting α-blocker that is given preoperatively, usually 1 to 3 weeks before surgery.

Pearl PM1140: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

* Classical triad of symptoms:

* Headaches – most common symptom

* Profuse sweating

* Palpitations and tachycardia

* Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign

* Anxiety, panic attacks

* Hyperglycemia

* Hypercalcemia

* Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction

* Polyuria and polydipsia 

* Orthostatic hypotension

* Dilated cardiomyopathy

* Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)

* Constipation

* Abdominal pain

* Weakness

* Weight loss

* Nausea

Pearl PM0788: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

* When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.

* Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.

* Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

* An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)

* High number of Ki-67-positive cells

* Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

* Measurement of the plasma metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test.

* MRI is the IOC.

* Biopsy and CT Contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid a hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

* Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.

* Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy

* Preop Alpha blockers should be given

questions.text: 177. A female presented with recurrent headaches. Identify the lesion in the given MRI.
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

Meningioma shows a ‘dural tail’ extending from the tumour along the dura mater.  It is a well-defined, hyperintense and homogeneously enhanced mass that arises from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges. They mostly arise in the supratentorial region, but can also be seen in the infratentorial region.

Meningomas are more commonly seen in females and are associated with the NF-2 mutation. Many small meningiomas are found incidentally and are entirely asymptomatic. Most common presentations include headache, paresis and change in mental status. 

Other options:

Option A: Gliomas are intra-axial tumours.

Option C: Ependymoma arise from the neoplastic transformation of the ependyma. They are usually intraventricular, but extraventricular rests of ependymal cells may give rise to cerebral hemisphere tumours.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. MRI reveals a cystic mass.

questions.text: 178. An abattoir worker presented with a pustular lesion on the dorsum of the hand with induration surrounding it. The organism cultured from the lesion shows McFadyean positivity and is a gram-positive bacilli. What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the likely organism to be Bacillus anthracis.

Anthrax is a zoonotic disease. Human beings acquire anthrax via 3 routes:

* Cutaneous mode- via spore entry through abraded skin

* Pulmonary anthrax via inhalation of spores

* Intestinal anthrax via ingestion of the carcasses of animals containing anthrax spores.

Hide porter's disease (cutaneous anthrax) commonly occurs in dock workers and abattoir workers (people working at an animal slaughterhouse). It is characterised by a malignant pustule which evolves to a painless vesicle, followed by the development of a black eschar. The eschar is a pustular lesion with induration surrounding it.

Lab Diagnosis of Anthrax:

* Gram staining: Gram-positive, large, rectangular bacilli. Shows McFadyean's reaction and Ascoli’s thermo precipitation test. 

* Culture:

* Nutrient agar: medusa head appearance colonies

* Blood agar: dry, wrinkled, non-hemolytic colonies

* Gelatin stab agar: inverted fir tree appearance

* Selective media: Solid medium with penicillin shows a String of pearl appearance, PLET medium.

* Culture smear: Gram-positive rods with a bamboo stick appearance.



Other options: 

Option A: Clostridium perfringens is a capsulated, non-motile, gram-positive bacillus. It has subterminal bulging spores, but does not produce spores in tissues or culture media. It causes gas gangrene.

Option B: Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative coccobacillus that leads to plague.

Option D: Listeria monocytogens is a gram-positive bacillus and causes listeriosis.

questions.text: 179. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever and seizures. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
Diazepam is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this child.

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine, a class of drugs primarily used as sedatives and anti-anxiety agents, but they also have antiseizure properties. In this case of febrile seizures, diazepam acts by increasing the frequency of openings of GABA-activated chloride channels, making neurons less excitable and helping stop seizure activity. It has a well-defined role in the management of seizures because it works quickly to suppress the spread of convulsions and reduce high-frequency neuronal firing. 

The image given below depicts the management of status epilepticus in a flowchart:

questions.text: 180. A 20-year-old man presents with chronic back pain. The pain is worse in the morning and reduces with physical activity within 1.5 hours. He has a history of anterior uveitis. The X-ray of the sacroiliac joint was normal. On examination, lumbar lordosis was lost, and spinal flexion was reduced. What is the diagnostic modality for early diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ankylosing Spondylitis. The diagnostic modality for early diagnosis of this condition is MRI of the sacroiliac joint.

MRI of the sacroiliac joint allows detailed investigation of the sacroiliac joints, and may show typical erosions and features of inflammation, such as bone oedema.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of seronegative spondyloarthritis (Rheumatoid factor negative) characterised by early morning stiffness and backache, which improves with exercise. The majority of the patients who suffer from ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive. Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray spine shows fused vertebrae looking like a bamboo tree (bamboo spine), which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. Other clinical features are loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and diminished spinal movements.



X-ray findings:

* Erosion of sacroiliac joints- earliest sign

* Periarticular sclerosis in later stages 

* Squaring of vertebrae due to the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change

* Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae

* Wedging of the vertebra leading to hyperkyphosis



Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

Other options:

Opton A: X-ray of the Dorsolumbar spine will not be able to show features of inflammation very clearly, and X-ray of the sacroiliac joint has already been done in the patient.

Option B: Anti-CCP antibodies are tested in patients suspected of Rheumatoid arthritis.

Option C: CT of the sacroiliac joint also helps in identifying changes, but MRI is more sensitive.

Pearl PM1379: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis


Pearl PM1728: Uveitis Associated with HLA B-27-associated Arthritis

* Ankylosing spondylitis

* Psoriatic arthritis

* Reiter’s syndrome

* Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (previously known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis)

Pearl PM1921: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: 181. A 4-year-old was brought to the OPD by the child's mother, with a history of intense perianal itching, worse at night. The mother mentioned that she has found small, white, thread-like structures in the child's undergarments. The stool was examined, and the microscopy is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal itching at night time, thread-like structures in undergarments and stool culture showing a planoconvex egg is suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. 

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. They are oviparous. Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larvae through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. 

At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and lays its sticky eggs on the perianal skin. This leads to pruritus, and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina, causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Since pinworms are rarely released in faeces, faecal examination is not useful in the diagnosis. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.



Another method of demonstrating eggs is the scotch tape method. Here, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides, and transferred to a glass slide. A drop of toluene is added and examined under the microscope.The below image shows the scotch tape method.



The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema. Frequent hand washing, fingernail cleaning, regular bathing, and frequent washing of night clothes and bed linen should be done. Infection can be treated with pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, or mebendazole as single-dose therapy.

Other options:

Options B and C: Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infect a person by direct penetration of the skin by filariform larvae. They develop into adult worms in the small intestine. Segmented eggs are passed in faeces, and these develop into filariform larvae in the soil.

They can cause severe local itching, cutaneous larva migrans, and respiratory symptoms. Adult hookworm disease is characterised by anaemia, epigastric pain, dyspepsia, vomiting, and reddish black stools. Diagnosis is by demonstration of eggs or larvae in faeces. The egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres. They have identical eggs. The life cycle is shown below.



Option D: The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colourless outer membrane and an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs are non-bile-stained and float in a saturated salt solution.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. They are usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may be present due to an allergic response.

questions.text: 182. An 18-month-old baby presents with weakness of limbs, a cherry red spot on the macula and seizures. The mother has a history of one spontaneous abortion at 4 months. Laboratory investigations showed a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase. Which of the following biochemical molecules is accumulated in this baby?
questions.solution:
Ganglioside GM2 will be accumulated in this baby.

Ganglioside GM2 accumulates in neuronal lysosomes due to a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, which converts GM2 into GM3. Diseases associated with the accumulation of GM2 Ganglioside are Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff's disease.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. There is an accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. The child presents with a delay in developmental milestones and gradually loses the ability to stand, sit, and vocalise. The onset of dysphagia is earlier than in children with other GM2 gangliosidoses. Other manifestations are early hypotonia developing into progressive spasticity, convulsions, macrocephaly, blindness, deafness, and cherry-red spots in almost all patients. Molecular genetic testing can be done to evaluate for variants in the HEXA or HEXB gene to confirm the diagnosis. Death usually occurs due to aspiration or bronchopneumonia. 

Sandhoff's disease occurs due to a deficiency of the enzymes hexosaminidase A and B. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities. The juvenile form of this disorder presents as ataxia, dysarthria, and intellectual deterioration, but without visceral enlargement or a macular cherry red spot. The diagnosis of infantile Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease is suspected in an infant with neurologic features and a cherry red spot, and the two can be distinguished based on deficient enzymes.





Other options:

Option B: Galactocerebroside gets accumulated in Krabbe disease due to a defect in the enzyme beta-galactosidase.

Option C: Sphingomyelin gets accumulated in Niemann-Pick disease due to a defect in the enzyme Sphingomyelinase.

Option D: Ganglioside GM1 gets accumulated in generalised gangliosidoses due to a defect in the enzyme beta-galactosidase.

Pearl PM0856: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

questions.text: 183. A patient presented with odynophagia and cervical lymphadenitis. On examination, an ulcerated growth was present on the base of the tongue, which was found to be squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most common organism associated?
questions.solution:
HPV is the most common organism associated with squamous cell carcinoma.

In the oropharynx, most of the squamous cell carcinomas (SCC), particularly those involving the tonsils, the base of the tongue, and the pharynx, occur due to oncogenic variants of HPV.

Early detection of HPV-associated head and neck SCC can be delayed because the anatomic sites of origin (tonsillar crypts, base of tongue, and oropharynx) are not readily accessible for cytologic screening (unlike the cervix) for premalignant lesions. The presenting features of oropharyngeal SCC include multiple large cystic cervical lymph nodes with a small primary lesion.

Early-stage tumours may be cured by transoral laser surgery, transoral robotic surgery or radiotherapy. Intermediate- or late-stage disease is usually managed with concurrent chemoradiotherapy or with open surgery and reconstruction using myocutaneous pedicles or free flaps. Larger lesions with recurrences require open surgery and reconstruction. Neck dissection is required in most cases where surgery is the primary treatment modality and is also required for patients who have only partially responded following chemoradiotherapy.

Pearl PM2174: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   


 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

Pearl PM0271: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

* UV exposure

* Male sex- due to more sun exposure

* Environmental factors-

* Psoralen and UVA (PUVA)

* Physical agents such as ionizing radiation

* Chemical agents such as arsenics

* HPV-16 & 18

* Immunosuppression 

* Smoking

* Chronic nonhealing wounds, burn scars, and chronic dermatosis

* Hereditary conditions such as xeroderma pigmentosum, epidermolysis bullosa, and oculo-cutaneous albinism

* Premalignant conditions like actinic keratosis, Bowen’s disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat

questions.text: 184. Patient presented with high-grade fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity for the past 1 day. Meningococcal meningitis was confirmed. Which of the following is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis for the contacts of this patient?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis for the contacts of this patient with meningococcal meningitis.

Antibiotic chemoprophylaxis is recommended for close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease to prevent secondary cases. Prophylaxis should be administered to all contacts simultaneously to prevent recolonisation by meningococci transmitted from untreated contacts. It should also be used as soon as possible to treat early disease in secondary cases. The drugs used in chemoprophylaxis are:

* Rifampicin was earlier used widely, but is not optimal due to the high risk of adverse events, emerging resistance, and the need for compliance for four doses.

* Ciprofloxacin - widely used as a single oral dose, but it cannot be given in pregnancy.

* Ceftriaxone - can be given in pregnancy and all ages as a single IM or IV dose. However, reduced susceptibility of isolates to ceftriaxone has occasionally been reported.

questions.text: 185. As per the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation programme, what dose of IFA tablets is provided to children in the 10-19 year age group?

choices.text: 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron and 50 mcg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid
100 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid

questions.solution:
As per the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation programme, IFA tablets containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid are provided to children in the 10-19 year age group.

Earlier, the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) programme, launched in 2012, was targeted mainly at adolescents in the 10–19 year age group. Under this, they were provided one IFA tablet containing 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid once weekly, along with biannual deworming with Albendazole. However, since 2018, WIFS has been brought under the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy as part of the 6x6x6 initiative.

Under AMB, iron and folic acid supplementation has been expanded to cover ages from 6 months of age up to 49 years, including children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant and lactating women. Under AMB, the prophylactic IFA supplementation for adolescents (10–19 years) has been revised to one blue-coloured tablet per week containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 µg folic acid. 

The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare had launched the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) Programme to reduce the prevalence and severity of anaemia in the adolescent population (10-19 years). The target groups included school-going adolescent girls and boys in 6th to 12th class enrolled in government/government-aided/municipal schools and out-of-school adolescent girls.

The key interventions included:

* Administration of supervised Weekly Iron-folic Acid Supplements using a fixed day approach.

* Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anaemia and referring these cases to an appropriate health facility.

* Biannual deworming (Albendazole 400mg), six months apart, for control of helminthic infestation.

* Information and counselling for improving dietary intake and for taking actions for prevention of intestinal worm infestation.

Pearl PM2210: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: 186. The parents of a 16-year-old girl are alleging kidnapping and rape charges against a 25-year-old man. The accused says he loves the girl and wants to marry her, and that the sexual activity was consensual. The girl also agrees that it was consensual. Examination confirms recent sexual activity, but there are no injuries. What is the likely legal problem under Indian law?

choices.text: No offense since the man says he loves the girl and wants to marry her
Parents should prove that there was an assault and physical resistance
No offense since no injuries present
Consent is immaterial since the girl is less than 18 years old

questions.solution:
The most likely legal issue under Indian law in this case is that the consent is immaterial since the girl is less than 18 years old.

According to Section 63(d)(vi) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), previously Section 375(d)(6) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), sexual intercourse with a girl below 18 years is treated as statutory rape, even if she gives consent. 

As per Section 63(d) of BNS, application of a man's mouth to the vagina, anus, or urethra of a woman, or making her do so with him or another person, is considered rape under the following circumstances:

* Against her will.

* Without her consent.

* With her consent obtained by putting her or someone she cares for in fear of death or hurt.

* With her consent, when he knows he is not her husband, but she believes him to be the man she is lawfully married to.

* With her consent, when, due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or administration of a stupefying substance, she cannot understand the nature or consequences of that consent.

* With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.

* When she is unable to communicate consent.
