questions.text:
187. A young patient presented with PND, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. However, the patient succumbed to her illness. On autopsy, the lungs showed hemosiderin-laden macrophages. In which of the following can it occur except:

PND - Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea
questions.solution:
The above clinical case describes heart failure cells, which are intra-alveolar hemosiderin-laden macrophages that indicate chronic passive congestion of the lung leading to pulmonary edema. These cells are not seen in protein-losing enteropathy.

In chronic pulmonary congestion, red blood cells leak from the engorged alveolar capillaries into the alveoli, where they are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages. Within these macrophages, hemoglobin is broken down, leading to the accumulation of brown hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm. Because of their strong association with pulmonary congestion in congestive heart failure (CHF), these macrophages are called heart failure cells. The following image shows heart failure cells:



Protein-losing enteropathy causes excessive protein loss, leading to reduced intravascular oncotic pressure. This results in fluid shifting into the extravascular spaces, producing ascites, pleural effusion, or pericardial effusion. Occurrence of pulmonary edema is uncommon, and therefore it is not associated with heart failure cells. 

Other options:

Option A: Right heart failure most commonly develops as a consequence of left heart failure, where ↑ Left Ventricular End-Diastolic Pressure (LVEDP) → ↑ Left Atrial Pressure (LAP) → ↑ Pulmonary Venous Pressure. This venous congestion results in pulmonary edema and the appearance of heart failure cells.

Option C and D: Pulmonary venous obstruction and volume overload can both produce chronic passive congestion of the lungs, resulting in pulmonary edema and the presence of heart failure cells.

questions.text: 188. A G2P1L1 with a history of previous caesarean section presented in active labour. During trial of labour, there was foetal bradycardia and maternal tachycardia. Persistent suprapubic pain between contractions was also noted. On examination, the cervix was 8 cm dilated, and the vertex was at -1 station. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of scar dehiscence, and the next best step in management is emergency LSCS.

The presence of fetal bradycardia, maternal tachycardia, and persistent suprapubic pain between contractions in a woman with a previous caesarean section indicates scar dehiscence which may lead to uterine scar rupture. On examination, the cervix was 8 cm dilated and the vertex at –1 station, meaning the fetal head is still 1 cm above the ischial spines and not yet engaged, making instrumental delivery unsafe. Hence, the next best step is an Emergency Lower Segment Caesarean Section (LSCS) to prevent complete rupture and prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

Uterine rupture is defined as a disruption in the continuity of all the uterine layers (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa) after 20 weeks of pregnancy. It is a potentially life-threatening maternal complication, often associated with an unsuccessful Trial of Labour after Caesarean (TOLAC).

The risk factors of uterine rupture include: 

* More the number (>2) of prior cesarean delivery

* lnterpregnancy interval <24 months

* Induced labor, especially with misoprostol

* Augmentation of labor with high dose oxytocin

* Women having single layer uterine closure in prior cesarean delivery compared to double layer closure

Clinical features include dull abdominal pain over the scar area with slight vaginal bleeding. There are varying degrees of tenderness on uterine palpation. FHS may be irregular or absent. CTG tracings reveal variable or late deceleration (most consistent finding). If the fetal presenting part has already entered the pelvis with labour, loss of station may be detected by pelvic examination. 

To prevent uterine rupture, undue delay in the progress of labor in a multipara with a previous uneventful delivery should be viewed with concern, and the cause should be sought for. Attempted forceps delivery or breech extraction through incompletely dilated cervix should be avoided. The only effective measure to save the fetus is by immediate delivery via emergency LSCS. Following complete rupture during TOLAC, hysterectomy may also be required.

questions.text: 189. The time between the receipt of the infectious agent into the host's body and the period of maximum infectivity is known as:
questions.solution:
The time between the receipt of the infectious agent into the host's body and the period of maximum infectivity is known as the generation time. It is not the same as the incubation period because the time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. 

Other Options: 

Option B: The incubation period refers to the time between invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease. The median incubation period refers to the time between exposure to a pathogen and the onset of symptoms in 50% of cases

Option C: Communicable period is the time during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected individual to another individual.

Option D: Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Pearl PM0361: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.



Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: 190. An 8-year-old boy has been limping painlessly for 10 months. Given the provided X-ray, what's the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 8-year-old boy limping painlessly for 10 months, with the X-ray showing a fragmented head of the left femur, suggests the probable diagnosis to be Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-9 years. The incidence is higher in boys than in girls.

It is usually a unilateral disease, but can occur bilaterally in 10% of cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

The disease is characterised by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in osteonecrosis and the cessation of bone growth. The lateral epiphyseal artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone, which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and is relieved by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip, and abduction with internal rotation is limited.

X-ray findings depend on the stages 

* Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus

* Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis

* Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase

* Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The radiograph below shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.



Other options:

Option A: DDH (Developmental dysplasia of the hip) is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen.



Option B: SCFE (Slipped capital femoral epiphysis) presents in early adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin or knee. In a normal hip, Klein’s line intersects the epiphysis, but failure to do so results in a positive Trethowan sign and indicates a slip.



Option D: TB hip is a painful condition that can lead to limb shortening, as shown in the X-ray below.

questions.text: 191. A 14-year-old developed rapid growth and had long legs and large hands, and coarse facial features. Which of the following tests are used to make a confirmatory diagnosis?

choices.text: No supression of GH after glucose administration
No suppression of IGF1 after glucose tolerance test

questions.solution:
A confirmatory diagnosis of the given clinical condition can be made by observing no suppression of Growth Hormone (GH) after glucose administration.

The given scenario and the presence of rapid growth, long legs, large hands, and coarse facial features point towards a diagnosis of gigantism. An oral glucose tolerance test with GH levels is used to confirm gigantism.

Giagantism is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra-pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs after the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to acromegaly. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 µg/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of gigantism/acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Age-matched IGF1 levels are used for screening the disease. IGF1 levels are increased (option B) in the case of acromegaly/gigantism.

Pearl PM1525: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: 192. A 40-year-old female was treated for long-term with hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and developed renal stones. The mechanism of action responsible for this is:
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action responsible for this is decreased citrate secretion.

Urine citrate is a natural inhibitor of calcium-containing stones, and hence, lower urine citrate excretion increases the risk of stone formation. Alkalization of urine increases the excretion of citrate. However, Hydrochlorothiazide causes acidification of urine due to loss of hydrogen ions. This acidification of urine decreases the excretion of citrate. 

Increased consumption of foods rich in alkali (i.e., fruits and vegetables) can increase urine citrate. For patients with lower urine citrate, the addition of supplemental alkali, like potassium citrate or bicarbonate, leads to an increase in urinary citrate excretion. 

Other options:

Options A and C: Hydrochlorothiazide decreases urinary calcium excretion and hence prevents calcium-containing stones in the urine. It prevents the formation of calcium-containing renal stones by reducing calcium excretion.

Option B: Increased oxalate absorption leads to an increased risk of renal stones, but Hydrochlorothiazide doesn't affect oxalate absorption.

questions.text: 193. A child presents with trigeminal neuralgia associated with painful vesicular lesions around the mouth. On inoculation of the cell culture, multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions were seen. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child complaining of painful vesicular lesions around the mouth, with histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be oral herpes caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).

Herpes infection can be caused by the HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes which is characterised by vesiculoulcerative lesions of the penis of the male or the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female. Genital herpes is often accompanied by symptoms like fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia, pain, itching, dysuria, vaginal and urethral discharge, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

* Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)

* Virus isolation 

* Histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells

* Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. 

The following image shows the histology of HSV inclusion bodies.



The image given below shows Tzanck cells.

Pearl PM0587: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

Morphological changes in the cells that are caused by viruses are known as cytopathic effects (CPE) and the viruses causing these CPEs are known as cytopathogenic viruses. These CPEs can be detected by a light microscope.

questions.text: 194. Which of the following crystalloid infusions, when given in large quantities, is likely to cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Infusion of NS (0.9% Normal Saline) in large quantities can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

0.9% NaCl is isotonic normal saline, but this solution is neither chemically nor physiologically normal. It contains 9 grams of NaCl per liter. This translates to sodium and chloride concentrations of 154 mEq/L each (osmolality = 154 + 154 = 308 mOsm/L). This is higher than the normal chloride concentration in the body, i.e, 96-106 mEq/L. Due to high chloride concentration, the excessive infusion can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

The following table summarizes the composition, osmolarity, tonicity relative to blood, and pH of various intravenous fluids:

questions.text: 195. A patient presents with bleeding due to factor IX deficiency. In which of the following conditions will you find an improvement after administering Vitamin K parenterally?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K administration will lead to an improvement of bleeding manifestations in a patient with bile duct obstruction.

Factors II, VII, IX, and X are vitamin K-dependent factors, and the deficiency of vitamin K can lead to a deficiency in any of these factors. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin, and hence its absorption is impaired in bile duct obstruction. In this case, if vitamin K is administered parentrally, it will lead to an improvement in the bleeding manifestation.

Other options:

Option A: Pernicious anemia is caused due to autoimmune destruction of parietal cells, which leads to a deficiency in intrinsic factor, which plays an important role in the absorption of vitamin B12. Bleeding manifestations or factor IX deficiency are not associated with this disorder, and hence, vitamin K administration plays no role in its management.

Option C: Hepatitis A can lead to a decline in the synthetic function of the liver, leading to a deficiency in clotting factors. This is not caused by a deficiency of vitamin K, and hence administering vitamin K in a patient with hepatitis A will not improve the bleeding manifestations.

Option D: Classical hemophilia or hemophilia A is a genetic disorder in which there is a deficiency of factor VIII. In this, the ability of the body to produce factor VIII is impaired, and hence, vitamin K injection will not lead to improvement in this condition.

questions.text: 196. Which of the following diseases is shown by the pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree chart is indicative of the Mitochondrial pattern of inheritance, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome is an example of mitochondrial inheritance.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

* Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum), as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.

* Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease, while an affected father cannot transmit it, and the mother passes it on to all her offspring.

80% of mitochondrial DNA codes for mitochondrial RNA, and therefore most mitochondrial DNA mutations lead to functional problems, which may be manifested as muscle disorders.

Kearns–Sayre syndrome (KSS) is characterized by progressive external ophthalmoplegia (PEO), pigmentary retinopathy, and cardiac conduction defects, most often heart block. The disease typically presents before the age of 20 years and may be associated with cerebellar ataxia, progressive myopathy, cognitive decline, and elevated CSF protein levels. A distinctive feature of KSS is white matter disease related to cerebral folate deficiency. It is usually a sporadic disorder caused by mitochondrial DNA deletions.

Other options:

Option A: Prader-Willi Syndrome is a genetic disorder due to an imprinting defect involving the paternal chromosome 15.

Option B: Achondroplasia is an Autosomal Dominant condition caused due to a mutation in the FGFR3 gene.

Option D: Williams Syndrome is mostly sporadic, but the inherited cases follow an Autosomal Dominant pattern of inheritance.

questions.text: 197. A 19-year-old athlete was training. While doing the hyperextension exercises, he felt a sharp pain in the shoulders. His trainer suspected avulsion of the long head of the triceps. From which site was the muscle detached?
questions.solution:
The long head of the triceps is attached to the Infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

Triceps form the extensor compartment of the upper arm. It has three heads- long, lateral and medial. The long head arises by a flattened tendon from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula. Its muscular fibres join the lateral head and the medial head to form a common tendon.

The lateral head arises from the posterior surface of the humeral shaft and the lateral intermuscular septum. The medial head, which is overlapped posteriorly by the lateral and long heads, is attached to the entire posterior surface of the humeral shaft, the medial border of the humerus, the medial intermuscular septum, and the lower part of the lateral intermuscular septum.

The fibres insert into the olecranon process of the ulna. Triceps is innervated by branches from the radial nerve. The blood supply is derived mainly from the profunda brachii artery and the superior ulnar collateral artery, with an accessory supply from the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

questions.text: 198. A mother is feeding her 7-month-old baby thick homemade cereal as supplementary feeds besides breastfeeding. What is the volume and frequency of feeds most appropriate for this baby in a period of 24 hours based on the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF)?
questions.solution:
½ –1 katori 3 times a day, along with frequent breastfeeding is the most appropriate for this 7-month-old baby in a period of 24 hours based on the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF).

The quantity of complementary food to be offered as per the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF) is given below:

Age Frequency Amount at each meal
6 months 2 times per day plus frequent breastfeeds 2-3 tablespoons
7-8 months 3 times per day plus frequent breastfeeds Increasing gradually to 2/3 of a 250 ml katori/ bowl (which is roughly stated as 1/2 to 1 katori)
9-11 months 3 meals plus 1 snack between meals plus breastfeeds 3/4 of a 250 ml katori/ bowl
12-24 months 3 meals plus 2 snacks between meals plus breastfeeds A full 250 ml katori/ bowl or more

questions.text: 199. A 25-year-old following a RTA with head injury was brought to the ER, and a CT scan showed normal findings, but the patient died within 3 hours. Autopsy showed petechial hemorrhages in the corpus callosum, focal lesions in the brain stem, and retraction ball appearance in the internal capsule. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and the given autopsy findings are probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.

A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.

Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter within the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.



Pearl PM2128: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

* Changes in permeability of the axolemma

* Axonal swelling

* Intracellular calcium accumulation

* Proteolysis

* The collapse of the cytoskeleton

* 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.

* Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: 200. A patient presented with lump on right breast. Biopsy was done, which confirms breast cancer. Identify the stage of breast cancer.
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema, edema, and dimpling (peau d'orange appearance) on the right breast, suggestive of the T4d stage of breast cancer.

T4d suggests inflammatory breast carcinoma with peau d’orange appearance and redness involving >1/3rd of the surface of the breast, with or without a breast lump. Peau d’orange refers to the orange peel appearance of the skin of the breast and is a sign of locally advanced disease.

Pearl PM0877: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present


 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0

Any T, N3

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.



Prefixes for TNM staging:

* c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)

* p: pathological (histological) staging

* y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)

* r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

* m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours
